results.description:
Women, have you ever wondered if you can have the sexual fulfillment you long for?

• Is your desire and arousal elusive?

• Do you find it challenging to stay present, feel safe in your body and connected  to your partner during love making?

• Do you have a hard time relaxing into your pleasure or reaching climax?

• Do you feel guilty for not meeting your partner’s needs?

• Do you worry that something is wrong with you?


You are not alone.

For years my sexuality was completely shut down. I was simply not interested. So much so that I thought I was asexual. I had no idea how much aliveness and passion was underneath the numbness.


There is freedom and pleasure on the other side.

It was a long process of trying many varieties of healing modalities, personal growth work, and body-mind disciplines before I discovered what a potent source of aliveness, freedom, connection and pleasure my sexual energy truly is.

I am passionate about supporting you.

I am passionate about sharing the wisdom and tools I have cultivated and synthesized over the past twenty years so that you can move so much more quickly and effortlessly through your blocks and into your power and pleasure.


You are invited.

This evening is an invitation to come out of isolation and take the FIRST STEP in reclaiming your whole, happy, healed, and empowered sexual Self. You will be guided in some simple meditations and exercises to connect with yourself and bring some gentleness, loving kindness and compassion to your heart and soul.


Discover the Healing Potential.

I will share with you insights from my journey of sexual healing and awakening. You will connect with other women on their healing journeys and discover that you are not alone! You will get a taste of the tender nurturing, inspiration and healing potential of sisters coming together with the intention of sacred healing and empowerment.

Donation: $20 in advance; $30 at door

To secure your spot at the discounted rate REGISTER HERE!

This evening will give you a solid taste of what to expect in the Venus Rising: Women's Sexual Empowerment Retreat, Nov 6-8.

What past participants of the Goddess Weekend are saying:

“Such an amazing weekend !! I felt so supported and was able to have some major breakthroughs!! Thank you!”

“It was an unforgettable experience. I am grateful and I desire more, much much more.”

“Beyond grateful and full of appreciation for a very powerful experience.”

BONUS Gift to You:

If you want to experience a more loving, pleasurable relationship with your body and your sexuality, I invite you to sign up here for my personal GIFT to you: this inspiring  “Women’s Sexual Empowerment” Audio. In it I share my own story of sexual trauma and healing, and shed light on the Six Steps to Sexual Healing and Awakening that can take you from shutdown to deeply connected.
results.name: Venus Rising: An Evening of Women's Sexual Empowerment

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

results.description:
So, the title is meant literal: I challenge you to capture the Zodiacal Light, as I have never done so. Images need to be taken during this event period, old photos don't count. Are you a morning person? Good, the best time to do this is 12-24 October before dawn.

Zodiacal light is a faint, roughly triangular, diffuse white glow seen in the night sky that appears to extend up from the vicinity of the sun along the ecliptic (the apparent path that the sun takes across our sky). It is best seen just after sunset in spring, and just before sunrise in autumn, when the zodiac is at a steep angle to the horizon. Caused by sunlight scattered by space dust </a>in the zodiacal cloud, it is so faint that either moonlight or light pollution renders it invisible. That means: shooting over the ocean on the beach gets you best results, but you will need a clear night without much marine layer fog.


In the northern hemisphere, the light appears as a faint cone of light above the eastern horizon before sunrise (or the western horizon in spring). Its light intensity is greater than the Milky Way. Typically, the light is colorless, but in rare circumstances it can have blue, green, yellow, or red hues. If the conditions are right, it is easy to see the zodiacal light, but because it is so faint and occurs near the horizon, most viewers think they are seeing twilight or the light from a distant town (both of which we eliminate by shooting before civil twilight and over the ocean). It is best seen when the sun is between 18 and 12 degrees below the horizon, that means during nautical twilight.


The best time then is 5:30 to 6:30 a.m. during the period 12-24 October, after that it gets too bright (sunrise is around 7, in case you want to capture, that, too). Even though the light can be seen well in general in October and November, the moon will be out of the way only during that period of 12-24 Oct (and again 11-23 November). If you have PhotoPills (iToy) or PlanIt! (Android), these apps can show you exactly where the sun would come up, that is where you have to point your camera - typically due East (90°) to about 100°.


<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiacal_light">Here is more info about it on Wikipedia

and

some examples on Google

.

Shooting settings are the same as for star points or Milky Way: wide open aperture (f/2.8 or wider), maximum exposure time in seconds is determined as 400/focal length in mm (300/FL for cropped sensor cameras) and ISO between 1600 and 3200 (6400 is usually too noisy and diminishes the beauty of the faint light). Compose to have something interesting in your foreground, could be silhouettes, as long as it is not a plain straight beach. Try some dunes, or if you plan to go into the mountains, that works, too.


Useless trivia: Brian May, guitarist of the rock band Queen moonlighted (!) as a scientist and completed a PhD thesis on A Survey of Radial Velocities in the Zodiacal Dust Cloud.


Post pictures here as you get them.
results.how_to_find_us: This is not a group event, it is an individual challenge
results.name: Challenge: Capture the Zodiacal Light

results.description:
Hank Phillippi Ryan-- "An Inside Look at Mysteries, TV & the Mysteries of TV"

Meet Award-Winning News Reporter and Mystery Author Hank Phillippi Ryan at the North Shore Business Forum’s Meeting on October 16, 2015.

Get the scoop from featured speaker Hank Phillippi Ryan on how she took on an additional career in mid-life when she became a best-selling crime fiction author in addition to an EMMY-winning reporter. She will also have books available for sale and signing after the event.

How does a just-the-facts journalist add mystery fiction to her resume while juggling the roles of reporter, author, wife and grandmother? If you make a career change at mid-life, can it really work to follow your dreams? Hank Phillippi Ryan will discuss mixing the worlds of fact and fiction during a career that has included radio, Rolling Stone Magazine, and undercover investigations at Boston’s Channel 7, along with obstacles and rewards, mentoring, and taking risks.

About the Speaker: Hank Phillippi Ryan is the on-air investigative reporter for Boston’s NBC affiliate. She’s won 33 EMMYs, 13 Edward R. Murrow awards and dozens of other honors for her groundbreaking journalism. A bestselling author of eight mystery novels, Ryan has won multiple prestigious awards for her crime fiction: five Agathas, the Anthony, Daphne, Macavity, and for THE OTHER WOMAN, the coveted Mary Higgins Clark Award. National reviews have called her a “master at crafting suspenseful mysteries” and “a superb and gifted storyteller.” Her 2013 novel, THE WRONG GIRL, won both the Agatha Award for Best Contemporary Novel and the Daphne Award for Mainstream Mystery/Suspense, and is a seven-week Boston Globe bestseller. TRUTH BE TOLD is the Agatha Award winner for Best Contemporary Novel, an Anthony Award nominee and a Library Journal BEST BOOK OF 2014. Ryan also won a second Agatha Award in 2015 for Best Nonfiction, as editor of WRITES OF PASSAGE, an anthology of essays by mystery authors. Ryan’s newest novel, WHAT YOU SEE, is a RT Book Reviews Top Pick and received a starred review from Library Journal, which raves, “Mystery readers get ready: you will find yourself racing to the finish.” She’s a founding teacher at Mystery Writers of America University and 2013 president of national Sisters in Crime. Visit her online at HankPhillippiRyan.com, on Twitter @HankPRyan and Facebook at HankPhillippiRyanAuthorPage.

The North Shore Business Forum, Inc (NSBF) is a group of small business owners from Boston’s North Shore who meet for informal lectures given by business leaders on a wide variety of topics. Members are also invited to give their 30-second “elevator pitch.” All business owners are welcome: future, past, profitable, experienced or beginning. The NSBF meets the 1st and 3rd Friday of the month from 7:30 to 8:30 a.m. (registration starts at 7:15) at Acapulco’s, 900 Cummings Center, Beverly, MA. The $10 meeting fee includes networking, a featured presentation, and breakfast buffet.

No pre-registration required, but your RSVP on our Meetup page is appreciated.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Friday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

This walk is on a paved path through the woods. This path is stroller friendly or you could carry your child. It is a little hilly, but appropriate for most fitness levels. We alternate walks between the inner and outer loops which are both under 3 miles. It usually takes less than an hour. We walk past a playground too, so we could stop and play there for a while. Afterwards, we sit at the picnic tables under the trees by the visitor center and feed our babies, chat, etc. 

We will meet outside the visitor center in the upper parking lot on the Saugus side of the park, past the Kasabuski Skating Rink.  There are bathrooms with a changing table in the visitor center too.

Running late?  No prob. You can always meet up with us at the picnic tables next to the visitor center after we finish the walk. 

***By popular demand this is set as weekly event.  If the weather is bad we can change it to a different day or skip the week.

results.description:
Sherry Turkle discusses Reclaiming Conversation: The Power of Talk in a Digital Age

Tickets ($5) are on sale now HERE. This event includes a book signing. 

Friday; October 16th, 6pm (Doors at 5:30)


Brattle Theatre - 40 Brattle St., Cambridge

:: :: ::

Harvard Book Store welcomes renowned media scholar and MIT professor SHERRY TURKLE for a discussion of her latest book, Reclaiming Conversation: The Power of Talk in a Digital Age, an investigation on how a flight from conversation undermines our relationships, creativity, and productivity—and why reclaiming face-to-face conversation can help us regain lost ground. We live in a technological universe in which we are always communicating. And yet we have sacrificed conversation for mere connection. 

Preeminent author and researcher Sherry Turkle has been studying digital culture for over thirty years. Long an enthusiast for its possibilities, here she investigates a troubling consequence: at work, at home, in politics, and in love, we find ways around conversation, tempted by the possibilities of a text or an email in which we don’t have to look, listen, or reveal ourselves.  We develop a taste for what mere connection offers. The dinner table falls silent as children compete with phones for their parents’ attention. Friends learn strategies to keep conversations going when only a few people are looking up from their phones. At work, we retreat to our screens although it is conversation at the water cooler that increases not only productivity but commitment to work. Online, we only want to share opinions that our followers will agree with – a politics that shies away from the real conflicts and solutions of the public square.  

The case for conversation begins with the necessary conversations of solitude and self-reflection. They are endangered: these days, always connected, we see loneliness as a problem that technology should solve. Afraid of being alone, we rely on other people to give us a sense of ourselves, and our capacity for empathy and relationship suffers. We see the costs of the flight from conversation everywhere: conversation is the cornerstone for democracy and in business it is good for the bottom line. In the private sphere, it builds empathy, friendship, love, learning, and productivity. But there is good news: we are resilient. Conversation cures.  

Based on five years of research and interviews in homes, schools, and the workplace, Turkle argues that we have come to a better understanding of where our technology can and cannot take us and that the time is right to reclaim conversation. The most human—and humanizing—thing that we do.  The virtues of person-to-person conversation are timeless, and our most basic technology, talk, responds to our modern challenges. We have everything we need to start, we have each other. 

:: :: ::

Purchase the Book: Featured event books will be for sale at the event for 20% off. Thank you for supporting this author series with your purchases.

results.description:
Biodiversity for a Livable Climate


 and the  

Tufts Institute of the Environment

present  

Another landmark climate conference!

Restoring Water Cycles to Reverse Global Warming</a>

October 16th-18th, 2015
Tufts University
Medford, Massachusetts, USA

Register on <a href="http://www.eventbrite.com/e/restoring-water-cycles-to-reverse-global-warming-tickets-17028813640">Eventbrite!

Do you know . . . 

If we use eco-restoration to bring back healthy water cycles to billions of acres of degraded and desertified lands worldwide, we will make major strides in cooling the surface of the earth and reversing global warming.  Here's the very good news:

We know how to bring abundant water back to the land - quickly.Eco-restoration is safe and low- to no-tech.

It's very inexpensive - while there are startup costs, in a few years eco-restoration pays for itself - and makes a "profit" for Planet Earth!


Regenerating healthy water cycles pulls carbon out of the atmosphere, lowering greenhouse gases to create a livable climate.

There are countless benefits for communities worldwide, such as increasing food productivity, building thriving local economies,  reducing (or ending) drought and flood, eliminating conflict (food and water wars), and expanding environmental and climate justice.

A first step was our exceptional conference at Tufts, Restoring Ecosystems to Reverse Global Warming, in November 2014.  Much has changed since then.  In less than a year the word about the importance of biodiverse and living soils has begun to spread, and growing numbers of people are considering the lands that give us life. 

Restoring Water Cycles to Reverse Global Warming is the vital next step as we learn about holistic climate solutions that embrace the natural world as an enormous, complex, inter-connected system. Join us for a weekend with scientists, land managers, activists and the general public for ground-breaking discussions of how restoring the water cycle around the world can cool the earth and address climate catastrophe - even as we work intensively to reduce current elevated greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.  There will be many opportunities for discussion, sharing information and know-how, and practical networking among people from all over the world.  

Learn what you can do to create new climate hope - and new climate action! 

Conference fee is $150, sliding scale and volunteer opportunities are available. 

Information and registration on our website (note that you must register on Eventbrite, signing up on Meetup is optional).
results.name: Restoring Water Cycles to Reverse Global Warming - Tufts University

results.description:
In this hands-on workshop, hosted by former science journalist and research astronomer Dr. Joshua Roth, we’ll begin by watching dusk take over from day and look for the crescent Moon. We’ll then go into the 1827 Barn and learn how to find each season’s constellations using star wheels we’ll build ourselves. We’ll explore the fall Milky Way with the unaided eye and then with binoculars and small telescopes. Telescope-buying tips and myriad other resources will also be provided. Be sure to dress for the weather of the evening; we suggest planning for temperatures between 40-55 degrees F, so wearing warm layers is strongly urged (we’ll either be in the unheated 1827 Barn or outdoors for this workshop). Bring binoculars if you own them. We have lots of interactive activities planned, so come rain or shine!

Tuition is $20 per person. Workshop is hosted by Wright-Locke Farm. Registration via wlfarm.org is REQUIRED (option to pay the day of the event is available).

CLICK HERE TO REGISTER: https://www.wlfarm.org/get-involved?page=CiviCRM&q=civicrm/event/register&reset=1&id=194
results.name: Fall Stargazing Workshop for Kids and Adults

results.description:
My name is Linda Pascal, and I am part of Danno's Tuesday night ukulele class. Danno mentioned that a few people have asked in the past if there is a worship ukulele group. Well, you don't have to look any further. I am so excited about the possibility of hosting one in Braintree, MA. I also like different types of music, but I want to focus on playing mainly worship songs.

I just want to use this instrument to give God praise because if it was not for his grace, I would not be here today. A few months ago, I almost lost my life in a canoeing accident. To keep myself motivated, I have decided to learn to play the ukulele. Everyday, I continue to grieve the lost of my friend who drowned in that accident. When I feel down, I play worship songs on my ukulele and it helps tremendously with my post traumatic shock. I don't know what people are going through, But I know God can bring them peace through music. Please join us, so everyone can come together and take advantage of this opportunity to worship God through songs and praise with their ukuleles.
results.name: Worship Ukulele Group

results.description:
BPFF2015 will present over 30 films in Arabic with English subtitles at the Museum of Fine Arts and other free venues. Oct. 16, 7pm Opening Night film: Eyes of a Thief by Najwa Najjar. (dir. in attendance.) Inspired by a true event, the film opens at the height of the second Intifada, in 2002. Wounded and on the run, the enigmatic Tareq (Egyptian actor Khaled Abol Naga) initially eludes Israeli forces when nuns shelter him in a West Bank church crypt. Later captured and imprisoned for a decade, he returns to a world dramatically transformed and sets out to find Nur, the daughter he has never known. It is a search that pitches Tareq into a realm of dangerous secrets and moral uncertainties.
Algerian singer Souad Massi also makes her acting debut in the film.
Tickets/ info: http://www.bostonpalestinefilmfest.org/films/eyes-of-a-thief/
results.name: 9th Boston Palestine Film Festival Oct 16-25

venue.name: Wild Rover Bar Boston - 1 Block from Faneuil Hall

results.description:
Biagio puts on a great party and has graciously invited the members of the Boston Social and Cultural Club.  Biagio rented the whole 2nd floor of the Wild Rover to make this an awesome private party.

PLEASE DO NOT DOUBLE RSVP! ----PLEASE RSVP IN ONE GROUP ONLY!! 

Join the legendary crazy dancing at our Mix +Mingle Meetup Private Party for 120+ members with our own DJ, dance area, 2 bars +apps/food from 7-9PM.

7-9PM is the Social Mixer which the best because it allows you to get to know your fellow Meetup members. After 9PM the crazy dancing + loud music starts so please do not complain, since members come to dance to loud music after 9PM.

Bonus FREE KARAOKE on 1st  floor if you want to kick it KARAOKE style.

Its the party everyone loves since its the starting point for thousands of new friendships, real long term relationships and 57+ marriages. Remember this is not a Singles Party it's a Social party.

The BEST part!...Come between 7 and 8:20PM to get 1 included (FREE) drink ticket good for any beer, wine, or mixed drink! (Sorry no shots or top-shelf liquor). This 1 Drink ticket will expire at 8:20PM sharp!!.....Please don't forget to TIP your bartender for the included drink!

When you arrive please head upstairs, (please don't block the stairway). Meet/greet Biagio, say your first name, what group you're with, pay with a $10 bill in hand at the top of the stairs (no $1 or $5 bills, please). You'll get a wrist band to wear so you can go upstairs and downstairs.

1. Biagio collects $10 cash from everyone, but the invited Larger Meetup Group Head Organizers and some of the  Social Fun Organizers..

2. After 9 PM you'll have to pay the bar's cover charge, so stretch your dollar and come before 9PM. If you get in before 9PM you ONLY have to pay $10 to Biagio.

I hope you can all join us for this blast of a party. It should be fun so thanks and enjoy life!..........Ciao, Biagio (a new dad)

==========================================================

Parking for this event: Street parking can be tough so you can try it and of course it's hit or miss. Your best bet it take the T.

The closet T stop is the Aquarium stop on the Blue line, next would be State Street stop on the Orange line.

If you really must drive in and park then there is $10 Parking after 5PM and on weekends at International Place Garage . There is a coupon that lowers it to $7 but this  $7 coupon is accepted at Pay Station in building lobby ONLY.  http://bostonparking.spplus.com/Boston-1-International-Place-Parking.html
results.how_to_find_us: Look for Biagio at the top of the stairs.

results.description:
Please RSVP! (E51-315  - 70 Memorial Dr. Cambridge, MA - map, parking and road closing info at bottom of announcement.

40 Years of Astrology on Wall Street: How Planets Affect the Markets

By Bill Sarubbi

The movement of planets likely causes market cycles.  Bill Sarubbi will provide evidence and rationale as to how planets affect markets and the economy.  Also, he’ll talk about his current market outlook, and projections of market activity based on his market research.

Bill Sarubbi obtained his BS and MBA from NYU. He developed the first software that enabled the user to research the relationship between time series and planets. He has authored 3 books under the pen name Bill Meridian. Bill was an analyst on Wall Street until 1990.  Then he managed a fund in Abu Dhabi from 1990 until 2003, when he began advising institutional investors from his home in Vienna, Austria. He is a member of the KENOS Circle, a group of futurists based in Vienna.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

MIT Building E51 (The Tang Center) is located at 70 Memorial Drive, but the entrance is at 2 Amherst Street.  The section of Wadsworth Street East of Building E51 is closed for construction, and Ames Street is now two way from Memorial Drive to Amherst Street.  You can park behind the building, or one block West off Hayward Street.

Here is a map link: http://whereis.mit.edu/?go=E51

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

If you have a friend you talk stocks with, bring them with you! Food or drinks are not allowed in any MIT meeting room. We strongly urge each person to make his or her own decisions about investing their money. Investment ideas and recommendations made during our meetings and in our online dialogs bear no liability by anyone. This is a free and open meeting. No membership is required, but please RSVP.
results.name: Special Speakers Meeting: Bill Sarrubbi: 40 Years of Astrology on Wall Street

results.description:
Each and every Friday, we're proud to open the doors of our music school in Central Square for a FREE seminar, demo or meet-up. Hell, we'll even throw a classical music concert or two. What's in store this week? Let's find out: 

One of Ableton Live's most iconic features is its powerful audio warping capabilities. From chopping up drums, stretching vocal samples, to outright mangling sounds, Ableton Live allows any producer to transform any sound into something completely unique. Mmmmaven instructor Mitchell Owens will cover the various warping algorithms within Live and demonstrate uses for each in the context of sound design for music production. 

Mitchell Owens is a guitar player, sound designer, and electronic composer/producer from Durham, NC. He attended Berklee College of Music right here in Boston and has over 5 years of experience with Ableton Live producing and performing music under the moniker Subalias, as well as doing sound design and soundtrack composition for independent films and animations. Mitchell's music blends the organic and synthetic for a balanced fusion inspired by sample based Hip­Hop, Downtempo, House, Funk and R&B. He believes in freedom of creation and expression and likes to cater to students' specific needs in order to teach them the proper skills and techniques needed to achieve their musical goals.
results.name: Warping Audio in Ableton Live [10/16] #FREE

venue.name: Harvard Film Archive

results.description:
Directed by Fax Bahr, George Hickenlooper and Eleanor Coppola. With Francis Ford Coppola, Eleanor Coppola, Dennis Hopper
US 1971, 35mm, color, 96 min

Hearts of Darkness: A Filmmaker’s Apocalypse documents the sensational events that unfolded during the making of Francis Ford Coppola’s Apocalypse Now.Featuring several hours of Eleanor Coppola’s documentary footage of the Philippines production—complete with secret audio recordings she made of her husband—the film details the director’s self-financed creation, teetering on the brink of complete collapse. Amid intense flooding, battles with the Filipino government over helicopters, Martin Sheen’s heart attack, rampant drug use among both cast and crew, and Marlon Brando’s prima donna antics, Coppola likens the experience of filming to his own personal Vietnam. The covert recordings reveal the director’s serious self-doubt and fear of failure in cahoots with a maniacal ego driving him to continue on at any cost—even bankruptcy—to bring Joseph Conrad’s legendary novel to the big screen for the first time. Both Apocalypse Now and Hearts of Darkness ultimately succeed in spite of themselves as triumphs of single-minded vision and will, ultimately illustrating the heart of Conrad’s novel from both the war’s front and behind the scenes.

See You at the Movie,

John
results.how_to_find_us: We can meetup upstairs after the close of credits at the Carpenter Center to go to a local eatery for discussion. libations, and sup.
results.name: Hearts of Darkness: A Filmmaker’s Apocalypse

results.description:
Gewurztraminer is a pink-skinned grape variety that produces some of the most distinctively aromatic wines in the world, in an intense style that polarizes people. Ardent fans of Gewurztraminer adore its highly perfumed scents and slightly spicy flavors, while its detractors lament its obvious fruit tones. Few, however, would deny Gewurztraminer’s presence on the olfactory radar.

Suchi and Lovee will be providing Indian food and dessert to go with the wine.  Please bring $15 towards the food, a bottle of your favorite Gewurztraminer and a glass.
results.name: Gewürztraminer

results.description:
The Townshend is a new bar/restaurant in Quincy opened by some Drink alumni.  They bring some upscale food and cocktails to an area that's been wanting it for some time.

http://www.thetownshend.com/

There's a smattering of street parking, there's also a garage which isn't *too* pricey for the lazy ones like myself.  And Quincy Center T stop is a block away.  Townshend is located inside the HVMA building on the ground floor facing Hancock Street.

I plan to avail myself of some of their noms, as well as drinks.
results.name: Cocktails in Quincy

$8 in advance on Eventbrite/ $10 at tbe door gets you admission with one beer.https://www.eventbrite.com/e/funktoberfest-tickets-18904076602

This is gonna be the party of the Fall!

A funky Octoberfest celebration with amazing traditional German grub, fresh Notch pils and lager,and killer music. 

Currywurst, sauerbraten, roast pork with sauerkraut, and giant pretzels will be featured, as well as plenty of veg options, made with all 100% local, direct from the farm ingredients. Just like your grammy Von Schtuup used to make!

$10 admission gets you a pint of Notch session pils. The perfect accompaniment to the amazing sounds of the Oktober Brass Boys, who will be laying down German classics and polkas. In between sets, Brotherwayne, the funkiest DJ this side of the Isar will be spinning the soul and funk 45s for your boogieing pleasure. 

Traditional long tables will be set up Bavarian style and our beer maids will be serving the frothy gold all night long. Bring a group! 

Come ready to eat, drink, dance and party. Prost!

Sponsored by Notch Brewing Company.

Buy discounted advance tix here! 
https://www.eventbrite.com/e/funktoberfest-tickets-18904076602

(See dinner logistics below.)

*****************************

Followed by

The Light of Awareness - An Exploration

with Evan Root

By bringing attention to what is occurring as we meet together, there is opportunity for a dawning of awareness.

Donation welcome.

Bio

Evan Root moved to Boston in the mid 1960s to help the Kushis establish the Macrobiotic movement. With them he opened the Erewhon food store, followed by a restaurant. He then lived in Japan for several years, studying and working before returning to Boston and posts at the businesses he had helped to start.

In 1981, a shift in consciousness augured a new focus for his life. Since then he has held many courses and classes introducing and exploring simple awareness and the inherent openings, realizations, and possibilities that follow from that perspective.

In 1993, he founded an educational initiative, Kindling Point, to foster awareness of the non-separate nature of life and support the unfolding of human potential.

Since 2001, the hub of Kindling Point activities has been in the United Kingdom.

For more about Kindling Point go to: http://www.kindlingpoint.co.uk

For an article by Evan Root, go to: http://macrobiotics.co.uk/features/amacrobioticquest.htm

For an article about KP and Evan Root go to: http://www.aquarius-atlanta.com/articles/?issue=05-2001&i=910&article=awareness

*********************************************************

Come be in community and enjoy the healthiest meal on planet earth!

for reservations and directions.

venue.name: Roots and Wings Yoga and Healing ArtsCenter

results.description:
Our theme this time will be "Creating and connecting to your inner happy spot"!

Take some time to slow down, deeply relax, tune in, and connect deeply to yourself and others. 

Note: For now, we'll be meeting on the first and third Friday evening each month. Of course, you do not have to commit to attending every time, however, the more you attend, the more you will benefit; and the better we'll get to know each other!  Feel free to invite friends and family, too!


See end of description below for different payment options.

Here's the basic description, with a more specific focus/theme each time, as well:


Are you aware of the many benefits of meditating, but can’t get yourself to do it, or it’s too difficult to do on your own?

Do you enjoy the collective energy and ease of guided group meditations?

Meditation can be one of the easiest and most effective means to living with greater harmony, happiness and well-being. It’s also an opportunity to peacefully transform your problems, your fears, and any pain and stress in your life into something more positive.

I also consider meditating one of the most direct and easiest ways to connect to your greater Spirit-Self, and to access all that it has to offer you.


By participating in these group guided meditations, you’ll experience how simple,delightful and easy it can be. You’ll learn and practice:

• Simple yet profound techniques you can easily do for yourself for any length of time that is comfortable for you.

• How to easily get into a meditative state to deeply relax and to create positive, pleasurable feelings, including inner peace, love, ease and joy; and how to bring that into your daily living.

• Techniques to help you shift your perspective and experience of issues in your life causing you stress in some form, and to shift to a more positive perspective, instead.

• How to connect to your inner resources and your best self, to solution consciousness, and how to activate your body's natural healing response.

We have a different theme each time we meet to help build and reinforce positive thinking patterns, beliefs and inner narratives that will support you in living with greater inner peace, love, ease and joy.

We typically have 2-3 guided meditations, with discussion and instruction in between to help you carry the positive feelings and lessons experienced into your day and life.

This is a perfect time to let go of stress and "busy-ness", and to fully let go and relax into bliss. Come with whatever intentions suit you, and the evening is still sure to satisfy. It always works out magically that way.

You're encouraged to bring a journal or notebook and pen to class.

To encourage and support your practice, if you pay for 4 sessions, the fee will be only $60 (in-person, cash or check), to be used within 4 months of your payment.  Or, you can pay for one class at a time for $20.  Just RSVP each time you want to attend. RSVP is recommended and appreciated, as well as showing up or changing your RSVP in a timely manner.

“I'm leaving refreshed, optimistic, empowered, full of love, and excited about bringing more spirit into everything I do. I’m sure that practicing the techniques I learned tonight will help me very much. Thank you!!! "

"Great meditations! I had a marvelous experience with each of them and a lot to take with me: powerful imagery, good feelings, and new techniques for connecting myself with the Universe. Loved the “love ripple”!”

"I truly value our time together. I tried two other guided meditation classes with other instructors, and I enjoy your classes the most. Why? Because you give us time to reflect, journal and share. It really helps to deepen my experience and expand my perspective. And honestly, I relate more to your meditations and love the sound of your voice. Your guided meditations are like group therapy for the soul."


Class leader (and meetup organizer): Ann Ide, M.A., has been leading guided meditation classes for years, and is also a certified master practitioner in Neuro-linguistic Programming and Hypnotherapy, and certified NLP Life Coach. Ann coaches people to move beyond their personal struggles, to new levels of harmony, happiness and success. With her expert questioning, inner exploration processes and personal change interventions, clients become able to more easily create the happiness they desire.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be downstairs in the basement level Roots Studio, enter thru back parking lot, or if go in front door - walk down hallway and stairs will be on the left
results.name: Guided Meditations for Experiencing Greater Inner Peace, Love, Ease and JOY

results.description:
Meetup at MetroRock Gym in Everett, offering both toprope and lead


Meet at the left-side hexagonal picnic table next to the bench and cubbies.

I (Jens) will go up to the picnic table area from 7 - 7:15 PM to meet people who prefer to show up at the regular MeetUp time. Please check  the whiteboard near the bathrooms for a description of what I'm wearing. If anyone else arrives early, please write "MEETUP" and your name & what you are wearing on the Whiteboard.

If you have not already done so, please post a clear face picture of yourself on your profile so that I and other members can recognize you.

If arriving later, just come find us on the walls. Hopefully you can recognize me (see "Event Host" right) from my picture.

If you've never climbed here before, you'll need to take & pass a belay test for rope climbing. Call the gym or see the website below for more info. Full-access Day Pass $22. Bouldering-Only Pass $18. Free pizza for students.

More info and directions: http://www.metrorock.com/
results.how_to_find_us: At the picknic table next to the cubbies

results.description:
Papagayo is a concept started by Legendary Restaurant Group in 2010. The first was on Summer Street in South Boston and was the third concept developed by the group. Serving the finest food, with the freshest ingredients, hand muddling Margaritas and making fresh to order Hand Hacked Guacamole were some of our early ideas. Today Somerville will be our fourth location joining the Summer St, City Square Charlestown, and Downtown Crossing location.

Now serving over 180 tequilas Papagayo is the best Mexican Food – Tequila bar around. Inside you will find juxtaposition of old and new with old world wood and brick combined with bright colors, Mexican Art and colorful paintings. We believe we were the first to introduce the Coronita, a large freshly made Margarita with a 7 ounce Coronita turned upside down in the Margarita. Ole!!

Making our Margaritas from scratch with fresh fruit, agave nectar, 100% blue agave tequila, and orange liquor you will find them to be the best around. Our food is prepared with the finest local vegetables, fresh made tortillas and the freshest proteins found. Between the blend of mouth watering Margaritas and the freshest food Papagayo has become a regular stop in the Boston area.

http://papagayorestaurants.com/food-menu-somerville/

results.description:
Witch’s Woods Haunted Hayride and Halloween Screampark is only minutes from Boston, conveniently located near Rt-495 and Rt-2 in Westford, MA.


We will go on a haunted hayride. You can’t run from the zombies during the hayride, you’ll only escape if your tractor driver can outdrive them. Hold on and brace yourself for attacks from the witch, zombies, ghouls, ghosts, and maybe even something else that has no name.

We are working on getting a group discount rate for tickets. The regular ticket rate is $34

This includes access to 3 haunted houses.  In addition to the haunted hayride and haunted houses, there are 2 self-guided attractions. The Jack O’ Lantern Jamboree is a collection of professionally carved pumpkins in a brightly lit display. Horrorwood Chamber of Chills features vignettes from Horror films, decorated with scenery and characters from your favorite classic Halloween films. Don’t let your guard down yet, some of these characters might come to life while you watch, and they’ve become very hungry trapped in their glass jail cells.


Food and Drinks: There is carnival like food at the event.  We will go for dinner and drinks after the event at Outlook Restaurant and Lounge. This is all onsite.

Witch’s Woods is located at Nashoba Valley Ski Area. We will meet at Group Ticket Sales Buildings (Sign says Will Call Online Sales). You can pay there.

Will you enter the woods? Will you face the unknown with courage, cover your face in fear, or scream uncontrollably? Either way I will be laughing at you

Call or text to[masked] to find the group


http://witchswoods.com/
results.name: Haunted Hay Ride Theme Park Westford MA

Here's the game plan:

8:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

8:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

8:20 - Play!!!!!!

10:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing.

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

results.description:
Fridays, March – mid-November | 8:30 – 10:00 pm
Offering Format: Public Event
Recommended for grades Pre-K – 12 and adults
Museum of Science
Free

Did you know that the Museum offers our starry-eyed public a free evening full of astronomy-themed fun on weather-cooperative Fridays?

Between 8:30pm and 10pm each Friday, weather-permitting, visit the Gilliland Observatory on the roof of the Museum’s parking garage. On clear nights, you can view stars, planets, the Moon, and other astronomical phenomena. On cloudy nights, tour the inside of our Observatory, and participate in astronomy-related activities run by our knowledgeable staff.

This program does not run on nights when the weather is inclement. For more details, and to find out if Astronomy After Hours is running on a given Friday, call our hotline,[masked]-0267. We update each Friday by 5:30pm with the evening’s plans.

Astronomy After Hours runs seasonally, from the first Friday in March to the last Friday before Thanksgiving. Admission is free thanks to the generosity of the Lowell Institute (parking charges still apply).

Thanks to Don Doughty for letting us know about the museum.

Source: http://www.mos.org/public-events/astronomy-after-hours
results.name: Astronomy After Hours - Museum of Science

The first three SOLD OUT weeks of Best of Boston Sketch were packed full with weirdness, lunacy, and a bucketload of laughs. THIS IS YOUR FINALE. MAKE IT COUNT. Three brand-new, top-notch sketch groups to tickle you (not literally, there are laws) and make you happy!

CENTAUR STEVENS: Two brothers and a hissing rando bring you robots and misadventure. That's a sentence you read and you understand yourself a little better now. With Andy Hughes, Samuel Hughes, and Kelly Rizoli!

HIGH COUNTRY: The best college sketch team in the college sketch team universe are nerdy athletes and athletic nerds, simultaneously doing something and nothing and scratching your many itches. Also: theirs. With Mark Pump and Zach Russell!

MISTER BISMUTH: The howling mouth of madness fell open and these folks emerged, glistening and hilarious. A full-on funny assault on your sensibilities and a thorough celebration of how far people will go to make you laugh. With Khaled Abdel Ghani, Steven Richard K, Becca Van Horn, Lauren Walleser, Eric Trageser, Jonathan Case, Sara Siegel & Christopher Player!

ALL OUR OTHER SHOWS SOLD OUT. Seriously, don't get sold out of this one - it's going to be killer diller!

results.description:
Saba Trip - October 17th - 24th, 2015

NO TRIPS ARE BOOKED ON MEET-UP. 

You must call the store on[masked]-2216.

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6E_4zvMWiBw

Trip includes:
Evening meals included every night at a different local restaurant
All accommodations at Sea Saba
Ferry ride from St. Maarten
Deep Diving course included
Nitrox course included
Night Diving course included
Advanced Buoyancy course included
Photography course included
Afternoon Hike to the top of Mt. Scenery lead by Kat
Afternoon Yoga Session lead by Kat
Free afternoon science field trips – www.seaandlearn.org
1 night dive included
5 days of 2 tank boat dives including tanks, weights & refreshments
East Coast Divers certified instructor How much does this SWEET trip cost??

$2199 per person

Diving info: Four types of diving – ledges/walls of Tent Bay, volcanic off-shore sea mounts, lava flow spur and groove (with sulfuric hot sand) in Ladder Bay, and natural shallow reefs of the Windwardside. Great diversity, macro life, sharks on the sea mounts, juvenile turtles on Tent Reef.

~ October 17th – 24th on the beautiful island of Saba

There are a number of subtle, little things that make “the Sea Saba Difference”. Not only do they have the best boats that are most suitable for Saba’s diving, they also have an office/retail shop on the main corner of the main village. This means they are accessible to you for any helpful information from making a dinner reservation to organizing a hike or just to come in and chat or check out a fish or creature in our identification books. Another considerable Sea Saba Difference is the quality and enthusiasm of the guides. Although each of the staff members is an experienced instructor with multiple professional ratings, they still like to use the word guide as this is the primary function when on the dive boats. With a number of internal programs to keep the dive crew inspired, enthusiastic and continuing to learn more about the reefs and their inhabitants in order to be the best guides possible and to share that information with diving guests. At minimum, each of the instructors is a Level 3 REEF surveyor. At Sea Saba, they recognize divers work hard all year to have a dive vacation. They want to be able to offer you as much diving as you desire. Therefore, they have dive crew on stand-by for night dives on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays–They just need 4 divers to plan a night dive. Extra afternoon dives can be pre-booked or added once on Island.

Diving is Sunday-Thursday, 2 dives per day. Afternoon activities can be taxi tour ($15-20 additional cost), visit to Jo Bean’s glass jewelry (free demos, glass blowing lessons additional), nature hikes guided by Kat, may require taxi txfer to/from trailhead $5-10, Yoga class that is designed by Kat to be a standing-only class. We will also be on the island during Sea and learn month (www.seaandlearn.org) so afternoons could involve field projects with science experts, lectures, hikes, etc. All free unless involving transportation or boat time. Friday is a no-dive-day so we’re planning that day for the hike to the top if Mt. Scenery, the highest point of the island with breathtaking views on a clear day, on a cloudy day you get to walk among the clouds.
Night dive add-on is $80 pp, afternoon dive add-ons are $50 pp Safety is the highest priority
Friendly and professional
Highly qualified English speaking staff


- See more at: http://www.ecdivers.com/saba-fall-2015/#sthash.AlHnXrCa.dpuf
results.name: Saba Trip - October 17th - 24th, 2015

results.description:
So, the title is meant literal: I challenge you to capture the Zodiacal Light, as I have never done so. Images need to be taken during this event period, old photos don't count. Are you a morning person? Good, the best time to do this is 12-24 October before dawn.

Zodiacal light is a faint, roughly triangular, diffuse white glow seen in the night sky that appears to extend up from the vicinity of the sun along the ecliptic (the apparent path that the sun takes across our sky). It is best seen just after sunset in spring, and just before sunrise in autumn, when the zodiac is at a steep angle to the horizon. Caused by sunlight scattered by space dust </a>in the zodiacal cloud, it is so faint that either moonlight or light pollution renders it invisible. That means: shooting over the ocean on the beach gets you best results, but you will need a clear night without much marine layer fog.


In the northern hemisphere, the light appears as a faint cone of light above the eastern horizon before sunrise (or the western horizon in spring). Its light intensity is greater than the Milky Way. Typically, the light is colorless, but in rare circumstances it can have blue, green, yellow, or red hues. If the conditions are right, it is easy to see the zodiacal light, but because it is so faint and occurs near the horizon, most viewers think they are seeing twilight or the light from a distant town (both of which we eliminate by shooting before civil twilight and over the ocean). It is best seen when the sun is between 18 and 12 degrees below the horizon, that means during nautical twilight.


The best time then is 5:30 to 6:30 a.m. during the period 12-24 October, after that it gets too bright (sunrise is around 7, in case you want to capture, that, too). Even though the light can be seen well in general in October and November, the moon will be out of the way only during that period of 12-24 Oct (and again 11-23 November). If you have PhotoPills (iToy) or PlanIt! (Android), these apps can show you exactly where the sun would come up, that is where you have to point your camera - typically due East (90°) to about 100°.


<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiacal_light">Here is more info about it on Wikipedia

and

some examples on Google

.

Shooting settings are the same as for star points or Milky Way: wide open aperture (f/2.8 or wider), maximum exposure time in seconds is determined as 400/focal length in mm (300/FL for cropped sensor cameras) and ISO between 1600 and 3200 (6400 is usually too noisy and diminishes the beauty of the faint light). Compose to have something interesting in your foreground, could be silhouettes, as long as it is not a plain straight beach. Try some dunes, or if you plan to go into the mountains, that works, too.


Useless trivia: Brian May, guitarist of the rock band Queen moonlighted (!) as a scientist and completed a PhD thesis on A Survey of Radial Velocities in the Zodiacal Dust Cloud.


Post pictures here as you get them.
results.how_to_find_us: This is not a group event, it is an individual challenge
results.name: Challenge: Capture the Zodiacal Light

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]

=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to one of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Isolation. We will use Glen Boulder Trail, Davis Path, and Isolation Spur Trail to reach the summit where we will turn around to retrace our steps back to the trailhead. There will be a few steep sections along the way and we will spend some time above treeline. This is the long and hard way to get this single peak - it avoids the river crossings.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 10 people because we will be traveling within the Dry River Wilderness. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 12.1 miles and climb about 5,300 feet. It should take an average hiker about 8 hours 45 minutes to complete. This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/47-Mt-Isolation-4004


Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. Use this link for the current weather forecast:

http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.2148&lon=-71.3092#.ViBRhbTO5_Y


=== What to Bring ===


It is starting to get cold in the mountains - this means any water on the trail may freeze and it might snow. It's time to start transitioning to cold weather gear - you will now need warm layers, hat and gloves, and light traction (i.e. Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons. Use this link for a list of items needed for most three-season day hikes:

http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf 

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Glen Boulder Trailhead which is located on the west side of Route 16 about a mile south of the AMC's Pinkham Notch Visitor's Center. According to Google Maps this spot is about 160 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 58 minutes to drive there.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

https://goo.gl/maps/rjyr8tcZvev


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

The Energy & Environment Club at Harvard Business School would like to invite you to the 12th Annual Energy Symposium at Harvard Business School.

 Come join leading professionals and students from around the world in a high-intensity atmosphere of engagement as we collectively wrestle with the energy challenges of the future. 

On the boundary between conventional energy solutions such as oil and gas, and newer topics such as renewables and clean technology, the 12th Annual Energy Symposium will bring collective understanding as we build a brighter and cleaner future by leveraging the power of today’s energy experts. 

Join us on the Harvard Business School campus on Saturday, October 17th, as some of the industry’s leading executives, policy makers, and students engage in a vibrant discussion on the future of energy.

Keynote Speakers this year include: 
• Aldo Flores-Quiroga, Secretary General of the International Energy Forum 
• Ahmad Chatila, CEO of SunEdison 
• Miguel Galuccio, CEO of YPF 

Check out the Symposium website (http://harvardenergyclub.org/symposium/) for more information and register today! Please reach out to Nora Barr ([masked]) or Richard Buckner ([masked]­u) if you have any questions.

results.description:
Alright folks, this is the last group long run for the DC marathoners. Just 9 miles (on minuteman) this time! Please note the change of time.

Group run logistics: Please come prepared for a short run (or run/walk). Leave your bags, etc. at home or in your car so that you can run easily. Please make sure to arrive 10 minutes early to look for parking, find the location, etc. 
Coach will brief you at the beginning of the run about the distance and direct you through stretching exercises. It is absolutely OK to run/walk in the beginning. Many of us are first-time runners. So please don’t be shy :-). 

Program details:  TeamAIDAsha is a beginner-friendly marathon/half-marathon training and fund-raising program. We train runners for their full or half marathon races and runners raise donations for AID and Asha. Both beginner and experienced runners are welcome. Anyone is welcome to RSVP and join us for the group runs up to four time with no obligations. We request formal registrations after attending four group runs.

If you missed the information session you can get an overview of this training and fund-raising program from here.

Waiver: Lawyers make us do this :-).  By running with TeamAIDAsha program you are agreeing to our official waiver at: http://www.teamaidasha.org/waiver.html


About AID-Boston

Association for India's Development (AID) is a non-profit, volunteer movement committed to promoting sustainable, equitable and just development, especially at India’s grassroots. We meet once a week at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit AID-Boston at: www.aidboston.org

About Asha-MIT

Asha tries to catalyze socio-economic change in India through education of underprivileged children. We meet once a month at MIT. Anyone is welcome to attend. Visit Asha Boston/MIT at: http://www.ashanet.org/mit/

We will run down Comm Ave in the carriage lane to the Chestnut Hill/BC reservoir, with the option to run around the reservoir before turning around. This is an out and back course so the distance is flexible - you can run however many miles you want!  There are some hills - we will run 3 of the 4 Newton Hills along the Boston Marathon course (if you go at least 8 miles - 4 out and 4 back).

Meet outside at the tables next to Bruegger's and the ATM.  We will leave right at 8:30 AM (especially when it is cold out!).

The pace will vary depending on who shows up.  If there is a wide range of paces, we frequently end up splitting into smaller groups based on pace.  Even if your pace doesn't "match up" with anyone else, meeting up with the group and starting the run with everyone is a great way to get yourself out of bed on those early Saturday mornings!

results.description:
• [Don't be concerned if you don't see many RSVPs here... our members tend to RSVP via our members site at WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org.]

Please arrive at 9:00 am. From 9 to 9:15 am, we set up the meeting and network. We start the meeting at 9:15 am, and continue until 10:45 am. When you enter Church of the Good Shepherd, walk downstairs and take a left. If you arrive late, just walk in and have a seat at any open spot.

Please visit "Meeting Roles & Responsibilities" for more information about what to expect from a club meeting.

Here's a sample agenda for our meeting:

9:00 AM Setting up/Networking

9:15 AM President's Greeting and Club announcements

President opens meeting and welcomes guests

Toastmaster's Welcome

Introduces each role, its purpose, and the person who will perform the role.

Humorist/Invocation

Starts the meeting on a light-hearted note.

Grammarian's Word of the Day

Encourages each of us to add a new word to our vocabularies. Challenge us to use the new word spontaneously.

Scheduled Speeches

Club members give the speeches that they've scheduled and prepared in advance using the guidelines from one of the Toastmasters International communication manuals.

Table Topics

Our meeting's Topicsmaster provides our members and guests with an opportunity for demonstrating and honing their skills for impromptu speaking.

General Evaluator's Introduction

Introduces evaluation team members and evaluate the evaluators and the meeting in general.

Speech Evaluations

Club members provide helpful, supportive feedback to each of the scheduled speaker in a positive and friendly manner.

Grammarian's Report

Grammarian reports on how many times speakers used the Word of the Day and how we used the English language.

Ah-Counter's Report

Ah-counter reports how many filler-words and false starts were used by each participant, to raise speakers' awareness of these instances and to encourage improvement.

Timer's Report

Timer reports speaking times of all major speaking roles to encourage members learn to accomplish tasks within set time limits.

General Evaluator's Report

General evaluator provides a review of the meeting, what went well, and areas for improvement to encourage continual growth and an optimal quality of our meetings.

Toastmaster's Closing Remarks

10:45 AM President Adjourns Meeting

We usually have a convivial lunch at The Red Lentil. Hang around after the meeting for details.

WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org

<a href="http://watertownsaturdaytoastmasters.org/"></a>

Join us as we hike two of Mt. Monadnock's sister peaks to the east, Pack Monadock and North Pack Monadnock, in Miller State Park amidst fecund fall foliage. The trail begins at the parking lot on Rte 101 and principally follows the Wapack Trail north, with a summit loop and cliff trail encircling each respective summit. results.description:
Croiss-training combines biking and bakeries. Two weeks ago we went to Rhode Island. This ride takes us to New Hampshire. The route goes from Spy pond, heads west to Shade St in Lexington, out past Hanscom to Concord, an ice cream stop at Great Brook Farm, then Chelmsford, Tyngsboro, around Long Pond then into lowell for lunch at mile 45.  Then down to Billerica via a different Long Pond,  pick up the minuteman in Bedford and cruise home to Spy Bond.   Total distance just under 70 miles. 

This is a sociable ride -- nobody will be left behind.   Overall pace will be an hour for each 10 miles, including stops, with a moving average of about 12-13 mph.

If coming by T, take the minuteman from Alewife up to Spy Pond - it's about 10  minutes.  It's more scenic to wait for people by the pond than by the station!

For some reason, the meetup user interface keeps messing with my start point.   The real start point is spy pond circle at the end of Linwood Ave, not the 1165R Mass Ave that the software is putting there with no help from me.   I think the map is finally right -- I put in absolute coordinates.    Manish also gives a good link in the comments.

Any road bike should be fine - racing or hybrid.

Scene from Lowell this weekend...

Route map.
results.how_to_find_us: At the little circle off the minuteman trail on the south end of spy pond - ignore the auto-generated reference to 1165R provided by the meetup website!
results.name: Croiss-training Circuit To NH

results.description:
•  Do you want to make a difference but keep getting stuck in patterns that don’t serve you?

•  Do you want to be the “creator” of your life?

•  Do you want to see your vision become reality but don't know how to begin?

Here’s your chance to Maximize Your Impact!

When we become conscious of the impact we have and align with our purpose in an intentional way, we have the potential to create the change we want to see in the world.

Join Maria Yunis with Everyday Leadership for her 2-hour interactive workshop where through individual and group exercises including mindfulness, journaling, and experiential process you will be able to:


•  Stand more fully in your strengths

•  Release patterns and blocks that hold you back

•  Realign with your calling to make a difference

•  Identify yourself as the creator of your own life

•  Empower yourself to get into aligned action


Date:  Saturday, October 17, 9:45 a.m. – noon  

Where:  Watertown Center for Healing Arts, 22 Mt. Auburn St.

Because I value Trish and her work I would like to extend a special reduced price of $29 to you. Spaces are limited, so register TODAY!

Preregistration is required by October 16. Use discount code “TrishSpecial” at 

https://maximizeyourimpact.eventbrite.com/?discount=TrishSpecial

I’m looking forward to seeing you there!

Warmly,

Maria

Maria Yunis, CPCC
Everyday Leadership Coach
Empowerment for Change
[masked]

[masked]


See what others have to say about working with Maria:

"Maria's methods were unlike any I had experienced before. They included some traditional ideas about leadership, but then went much deeper into your own personal and professional leadership aspirations, uncovering blocks to reaching your full potential, and ways to tap into your Inner Source through mindfulness, journaling, sharing, and giving voice to it. Afterward I felt energized, empowered, and motivated to follow my own unique path to attain my goals. I highly recommend Maria's Everyday Leadership methodology to all my friends and colleagues. “                  —Michael, Senior Manager, Oracle

"Maria is an outstanding coach – and I don’t say that lightly. Before working with Maria, I struggled to stay grounded and focused on what was important to me as an individual, with my significant other and in my business. She has a way of honing in on what matters and calling forth my truth in a way that both allows me to relax and at the same time propels me forward. As a result I was able to balance my life more effectively, including making a firm commitment to self-care and to my relationship as well as making necessary changes to my consulting business. I am an Executive Coach and Organization Development Consultant, so I have had a lot of experience with people in the field. Maria is one of the best out there. There is a sort of magic to her approach - you just have to work with her to know exactly what I mean!”  
                  —Debra, Executive Coach and Organization Development Consultant


"Working with Maria will help you to improve as a professional and as a person. She is very insightful and can point out some of your behaviors - both small and large - that you may not even be aware of but that may not be serving you.  The greatest thing about Maria is that she does this WHILE she remains your biggest fan and supporter.”            —Senior VP, Non-Profit

________________

Maria Yunis, CPCC, is passionate about helping people who know they want to make a difference, own their leadership and have the impact they want to have.  Maria supports her clients in developing professional and personal clarity, presence and results. Working with Maria, clients become conscious and effective leaders regardless of title, as they claim and shape their impact, career and achievements. 

She draws on over fifteen years in corporate, academic and creative experience in the high-tech, consulting and pharmaceutical industries. Her corporate design and communications experience was at Arthur D. Little, Inc. and Harvard University Health Services. At Genzyme Corporation she was the primary contributor to the coaching curriculum for directors and senior executives. Maria's consultation as an executive coach and advisor included the Leukemia Lymphoma Society and Velcro, Inc. Maria is a certified coach through the Coaches Training Institute and has a B.A. from Wellesley College.

results.description:
Do you have a family member or friend who wants to get in shape but doesn't know how to start? Help get them walking or jogging.

We have 2 groups:

Our Walking Group will exercise and encourage one another towards walking a 5K. 

Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.

Using CoolRunning.com’s Couch To 5K program we introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 8-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles).

• Anyone from the community can participate. 

• Led by experienced runners. 

• Mondays through Thursdays 6:30pm-7:15pm; Saturdays 10 am-10:45 am 

• 45 minute time commitment (3 days a week) 

• Goal of jogging and finishing a 5K

• Our Fall session will begin on Monday, September 28.

(Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.)

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group at the Dedham High School Track.

Our Couch to 5K will end with the "Dedham Turkey Trot" on Thanksgiving morning.

Join us for an interesting walk through our beautiful garden style cemetery, focusing on both art and history. Explore early mourning customs, learn the significance of Victorian monument symbols and listen to engaging anecdotes about the people buried here.

The tours are conducted by local historian and Registrar of Deeds, Richard Howe, Jr.. Richardhowe.com

Saturday, October 17th 10:00 AM The fall tours will begin at the Knapp Avenue entrance. All tours are free to the public and reservations are not necessary. Remember to wear comfortable walking shoes and bring an umbrella if questionable weather conditions exist. There is plenty of free parking inside the cemetery.

Lowell Cemetery is like a mini Mt Auburn Cemetery. Beautiful gardens, nice walking paths, great place to watch bird migration and there's plenty of interesting stories about the captains of industry and famous people buried there.

results.description:
Boston Food Forest Coalition is delighted to have Pam Kristan, wild food forager, lead a Harvest Walk again! She will teach us how to identify and harvest edible foods in Franklin Park- specifically how to hull acorns and process them into acorn flour, as well as prepare dandelion coffee. Pam will provide hammers for you to use. Please bring bags for harvesting and a small digger or other hand tool, such as a sturdy, long, dull knife to dig out the dandelions. This event has been a hit in past years, so don’t miss out!

This event has been a hit in past years, so don’t mi
*Meet in Franklin Park at the Valley Gates Parking*
results.name: Wild Forage Walk with Pam Kristan

results.description:
Youthful Aging, Ageless Consciousness with Matthew Raider, MD

Based on his own experience as a gerontologist and someone who has been meditating for many years, Matthew will talk about what keeps you young even as your body ages. He will also explore the eternal nature of consciousness and explain how you can experience it for yourself.

Matthew is a national speaker and a contributing author to the book "Meditation as Medication for the Soul" by Rajinder Singh. His chapter "Meditation: 25 Years Experience in Primary Care Medicine" chronicles meditation as it has moved from "being considered a fringe practice to now being called the secret to optimum health."

A clinical physician and former faculty member at the University of Connecticut Medical School, he is currently coordinating director of the Geriatric Teaching Program in Family Medicine at Middlesex Hospital in Connecticut.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in Nordic Hall to the right of the foyer.

results.description:
UPCOMING TOURS FOR 2015
Join us for an interesting walk through our beautiful garden style cemetery, focusing on both art and history. Explore early mourning customs, learn the significance of Victorian monument symbols and listen to engaging anecdotes about the people buried here.

The tours are conducted by local historian and Registrar of Deeds, Richard Howe, Jr.. Richardhowe.com

Saturday, October 17th 10:00 AM The fall tours will begin at the Knapp Avenue entrance. All tours are free to the public and reservations are not necessary. Remember to wear comfortable walking shoes and bring an umbrella if questionable weather conditions exist. There is plenty of free parking inside the cemetery.

Lowell Cemetery is like a mini Mt Auburn Cemetery. Beautiful gardens, nice walking paths, great place to watch bird migration and there's plenty of interesting stories about the captains of industry and famous people buried there.

For more information please call[masked]-5191.

Please Note: NO Need to Respond "NO"
No PETS allowed in cemetery
results.how_to_find_us: Knapp Ave entrance to Cemetery
results.name: Lowell Cemetery Tour

group.name: Merrimack Valley Women: Outdoors and About

results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.
results.how_to_find_us: Come around to the right side of the school (left side of the church), enter under the green awning, then up two flights to the gym!

results.description:
"Vanity of vanities! All is vanity," says the writer of Ecclesiastes when he sets out to test the meaning of life, having a discerning mind and ample opportunity to pursue goals such as wisdom, pleasure, achievements, and riches.  Yet the book is certainly not a hopeless one: one can succeed at life if one only knows the secret.  On Saturday, October 17th, explore this book of Hebrew wisdom poetry in four engaging, one-hour lectures.

10 AM: Session 1, Ecclesiastes 1-2 - The Pointlessness of Life

11 AM: Session 2, Ecclesiastes 3-5 - The Plan of God

12 NOON: hour for lunch break

1 PM: Session 3, Ecclesiastes 6-8 - The Justice of God

2 PM: Session 4, Ecclesiastes 9-12 - The Conclusion of It All

Contact Justin for more information:[masked]
results.how_to_find_us: The Commonwealth Salon: Enter the library from the main entrance across from Copley Square.  Turn right to go through the courtyard, then exit to the corridor beyond.  The Commonwealth Salon is across from the Map Room (the exhibit, not the cafe).
results.name: What's the Point?

results.description:
To promote the Nave Gallery’s Wrap Around Project and the work of the Somerville Homeless Coalition, we are yarn storming trees in Powderhouse Park in Somerville. Each tree will have a social justice theme and an individual color scheme.

Theme: Food security
Color scheme: Purples, Greens, Creams, Tans

Theme: Education
Color scheme: Blues and Black

Theme: Housing
Color scheme: Oranges, Reds and Browns

Theme: Community
Color scheme: Browns, Pinks, Creams, Tans

We've begun the installation (stop by and check it out), and need to grow it. Join us in transforming one of the prettiest parks in Somerville in the name of good!

CONTRIBUTE TO THE INSTALLATION
Inspired by mosaic, The Caring Forest is based on the construction of the pieces on multiples of 4” (4”x4”; 4”x8”; 8”x16”; etc). We need squares and rectangles of all kinds: plain and elaborate. Acrylic yarn is the best material and we need the following colors:

-Black (with blues in it if possible)
-Oranges
-Reds
-Browns
-Pinks
-Creams
-Tans

DROP OFF OR MAIL CONTRIBUTIONS BY OCTOBER 10 TO:
Nave Gallery Annex (Davis Square)
53 Chester Street
Somerville, MA 02144

Note: Items can be dropped off at any time in the basket in the vestibule
results.name: The Caring Forest Install, Part Deux

results.description: It's always free to attend so please RSVP if you plan on joining us.
