results.description:
Let's meet for a Multi-Group Fall Saturday Morning Beginner-Friendly Hike & Picnic @ Ponkapoag Trail @ the Ponkapoag Golf Course! This is one of our favorite beginner-friendly hiking locations. This hike is so easy we sometimes call it a walk. We will be meeting near the map as you approach the golf course and will start and end our hike along the golf course. The sections along the golf course are mostly paved. The balance of the hike is groomed trails with mostly gentle hills with a couple of challenges. This is a Green-Dot Trail within the Blue Hills Reservation. Most Green Dot Trails have very few steep inclines, some rugged terrain with a mix of flat and sometimes paved terrain, and no climbing.

This Hike is approximately 4.5 miles (give or take 1/5 mi) and takes approximately 1 & 1/4 - 1 & 1/2 hours to complete (give or take 5-10 minutes depending on the speed of the group). While the first and last 1/2 mile is along the golf course on a paved path the majority of the Hike is in the woods is along a path on uneven ground, yet very beginner-friendly. This Hike is in the woods and near water so it is recommended that you wear bug spray. You may also want a hat, sunglasses and water. We use the paved path along the golf course for our warm-up and cool-down and get to watch some golf along the way.

This will be a great way to take in the fall foliage, enjoy a heart-healthy walk/hike and socialize with fellow South Shore Walkabouts and friends over a picnic lunch. There is a concession stand inside with some food, including hot dogs, sandwiches, chips and beverages. Please join us for a Beginner-Friendly Hike & Picnic!

This event is being held in conjunction with other local meetup groups as listed below. Please do not double-book or triple-book by RSVPing Yes on multiple meetup groups. It may co$t ya. Simply RSVP Yes w/ ONE Group and RSVP No w/ the rest stating in your comments that you "already RSVPed w/" whichever other group.

Social Fun: www.meetup.com/socialfun

South Shore Dining Out Meetup Group: www.meetup.com/ssdomg

South Shore Hike Bike & Social Club: www.meetup.com/socialnetwork-1414

South of Boston, Norwood Singles Social Events/Dating Meetup: http://www.meetup.com/Norwood-Singles-Social-Events-and-Dating-Meetup/

We are asking each group to have a co-host to help with attendance (for your particular group). Groups without a co-host will be limited to 6 participants, including the Host.

Additionally, we will ask for participants to volunteer in the following ways.

Sweep: 1-2 people to "bring up the rear" to make sure we have everyone with us.

Middler: 1-2 people to be somewhere in the middle of the pack so if the group is spread out more than 1/4 mile we will still be somewhat within sight of each other.

Lead: 1 person to help me lead the hike so I don't have to be at the very front the entire time but still in the lead group.

Note: While everyone walks/hikes at different speeds, we will meetup to regroup at most intersections and all that include a map. Additionally, it is recommended that your walking speed be at least 2.8mph (as our hiking speed is usually slower than our walking speed) and that you have walked or hiked at least 3.5 miles at least 3-4 times, including once or twice in the past month or so.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Ponkapoag Trail Beginner-Friendly Hike & Pinic!

Saturday, October 17th @ 10:30am

Ponkapoag Trail @ Ponkapoag Golf Course

2167 Washington Street

Canton, MA

No phone #.

Website: Google the DCR.

Meeting Location: Map near the entrance to the Golf Course.

Host(s)/Organizer(s): Angela & TBD / Each Group needs an Event Co-Host who will be in charge of Attendance for their Group.

Min/Max: We are requesting at least 10 Yes RSVPs among all groups (excluding the Host) at least one week prior to the event. Each group will start with a max of 6 which will be increased to 10 once we have an Event Co-Host in place and a WaitList. The maximum total for this event is 40 people between all groups and I will adjust the max in each group accordingly 4-5 days prior to the event. Guests: 1 adult per member is welcome if space allows.

Late Arivals: We will wait our traditional 5-10 minutes for late arrivals.

RSVP Deadline: Please finalize your RSVP by 6pm on Friday, October 2nd. Any changes made after this time may not be seen by an Event Organizer prior to the event and are subject to our No-Show policy.

Cost/Fees: There are currently no costs or fees associated with this event. If you want to make your annual voluntary contribution to Social Fun I will be happy to collect and mail it to Biagio.

Inclement Weather: Heavy rains will cancel. We will walk if it is overcast or there is a slight drizzle. Please plan to bring a lightweight jacket with a hood just in case. (We will do my best to notify everyone if this event is cancelled by 9am on the day of the walk.)

Rain Date: None at this time. We may or may not schedule another Hike @ Ponkapoag soon, depending on the foliage and weather (as the leaves will cover the path and we will not be able to see the dips and other 'obstacles' in our path, thus posing a safety risk).

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Directions:

Overview: The Ponkapoag Golf Course is located on Route 138 (Northbound-side) in Canton. There is a sign indicating a recreation area. This is it.

From Routes 128/95/93: Take Exit 2A/Route 138 S/Stoughton: Follow Route 138 Southbound (about 1 mile). Just before your first set of lights is the entrance to the Golf Course.

From Route 138 Northbound: Follow north past the lights at Randolph Street. Go straight through your next set of lights (you can only go straight or left). Immediately after you go through the lights, take a right into the parking lot.


PLEASE NOTE: This [free] parking lot tends to be quite crowded with golfers, walkers/hikers and those using the skating rink. If it's a really nice day out we recommend you allow a couple of extra minutes to park or consider carpooling from a public location a few miles away.

Note: All of my events are child-free and pet-free for adults 21+ only unless otherwise noted. Thank you for being respectful of this request.
results.how_to_find_us: Map near the entrance to the Golf Course.

results.description:
Time for our Annual Fall Foliage hike to Mount Major. Let's enjoy the vibrant fall colors, fresh air, good company and scenic views on our way to the top of the mountain.

We depart Boston early in the morning. Carpooling is recommended. 

Leave from Boston @ 8:30 am. 

Trail: Mt. Major Trail 

Mountains: Mt. Major (1784 ft.) 

Rating: Easy/Moderate 

Total: 3.0 miles (round trip hike), approximate time 2:30-3:00 hrs. 

Elevation Gain: 1180 feet 

Date: Saturday, October 17th, 2015 

Location: 11:30am Mt. Major Parking lot. We will leave promptly at 11:45 so don't be late! 

Time for our Annual Fall Foliage hiking trip. This should be a relatively easy hike, but of course it's still a hike. Here are some excerpts from the Hiker's Guide to the Mounts of NH: This is a popular, exciting hike to an open summit with sweeping views of Lake Winnipesaukee, central New Hampshire and into Maine. Although it is a short hike and popular with families, the mountain is quite steep with a couple of spots some hikers may find a little difficult. At the outset the trail coincides with a jeep road, branches off it and returns to it. After a brief level section, the trail departs left from the jeep road and climbs steadily to the summit. Rock slabs are ascended and views of the lake begin to open up. The wide open summit area is spectacular and the old stone enclosure will provide relief from the cooling breeze. Take the same route back down. 

Directions: From Boston, drive North on 93 until you get to NH 
Take Exit 20 (Tilton) in NH on Rte 93 
Follow NH-11 E/US-3 N 6.5 mi 
Turn right at NH-11 E/US-3 N/Laconia-Gilford Bypass (just beyond the Belknap Mall) 5.6 mi 
Take the NH-11 E exit 0.4 mi 
Keep left at the fork, follow signs for New Hampshire 11 E 233 ft 
Turn left at NH-11 E/Lake Shore Rd 
Continue to follow NH-11 E 10.7 mi. 
The Mt. Major Parking Lot will be on the right  

Transportation is the responsibility of the individual, however we will do our best to accommodate you. Please let me know if you need a ride or can take passengers and where you will be coming from. Please note that when you RSVP. Suggested carpool fee is $10 per person.

 Stuff to bring: Backpack with lunch, 2 liters of water, and extra layers like a sweater or sweatshirt. Polyester blend/ fast drying type of clothing and hiking boots are highly recommended.
results.name: Fall Foliage Hike #2 - Mount Major in NH

results.description:
Level 1 - Open to all kayak types as well as canoes

This event will open for RSVP 2 weeks prior on October 4th

NOTE: In the event of rain or bad weather the event will be re-scheduled for Sunday if possible.

Join us for a leisurely foliage paddle on the Concord River from Bedford MA to Concord. The Concord River is ideal for small boats, and the Bedford boat launch at the Carlisle Road bridge is a popular launching spot for canoes, rowboats & kayaks. The Concord River is a placid river with a light breeze; it swings around corners spreading out to submerge the bottoms of trees. On the sides, there are trees and bushes growing up out of the water, and if you are watching, you'll see turtles, beavers, and many different kinds of birds. There is a wildlife refuge on both sides with posted signs... great for nature watching. Paddling up river, we will eventually reach the Minute Man National Park. We can beach the boats at the North Bridge where the spark of the American Revolution ignited a war, walk around or sit on a bench and have lunch. There are Historians around the park that will tell you all about it, as well as the start of literary revolution with a new Western philosophy called Transcendentalism. Ralph Waldo Emerson, Henry David Thoreau, and a few others lived in Concord.

This paddle will last approx. 5 hrs with a round trip distance of 9 miles.

Life Jackets (PFD's) are always required to be worn when paddling with this group.

Note: I picked this date based on a Fall Foliage Tracker... I take no responsibility for its accuracy!

Fitness doesn’t need to be intimidating or extreme, but it does need to produce good RESULTS! Come join TFW Boston for an after-work happy hour… errr I mean workout. Our workouts make will make you BETTER, not just tired, and our fitness familia will help you enjoy your time and ENCOURAGE you to give your best!


What to expect:

A challenging, motivating, and downright fun environment for training - perfect for after a long day of work.

TFW signature workout as seen on ESPN, The New York Times, and Boston Fitness Magazine, which has created world champions in multiple professional sports, and is individually-adapted for every person that takes part, even beginners!

Effective warm-ups to get you in the zone, and energetic intervals to invigorate mind and muscle.

Sweat, smiles, and lots of high-fives.


What NOT to expect:

Bootcamp instructors barking in your face.

Workouts that put exhaustion before results and safety.

Participants that are there just to feel like they’re better than someone else.


If you want to have fun and lose fat, gain strength, and improve your confidence and health, this is the place to be. Please bring water, workout clothes and shoes, a hand to high-five with, and a friend.

results.description:
Greater Boston Humanists will continue to celebrate the Autumnal Equinox, plus the 323rd "New England Freethinkers Day" celebration (the Massachusett's Court's dismissal of 'spectral evidence' in 1692), together, at our Lunch and Lecture on Saturday, October 17 at 12:30 pm. Mark your calendar!

Our Speaker, Lee Mcintyre, a Research Fellow at the Center for Philosophy and History of Science at Boston University, is author of RESPECTING TRUTH: Willful Ignorance in the Age of the Internet. This book has been very favorably reviewed by E.O. Wilson and Michael Schermer, among others. 

He'll discuss the perils of the willful ignorance that our new era encourages, and how we can fight back by embracing rational, empirical standards of evidence and choosing those methods of belief formation that are most likely to lead to truth. This promises to be a presentation and discussion relevant not only to humanists, but to all those of us dealing with the brave new world of communications we've entered.

We'll have a buffet lunch provided by volunteers from Greater Boston Humanists, followed by the lecture at 1:30 pm.

___

Free PARKING will be available in the Littauer Lot of Harvard University near the Science Center (Enter the Dworkin Science Quadrangle from Oxford St. and proceed to the end of the road to the parking area near the Science Center behind Littauer Library. If nervous, leave a note in your dashboard that you are at the Humanist event at PBH.)
results.name: Lunch & Lecture: Lee McIntyre, 'Respecting Truth' in the Internet Age

results.description:
Queridos amigos,

Muchas gracias por vuestra participación en la charla del sábado.  ¡Y una cordial bienvenida a nuevos integrantes  Allison, Astrid, Joel, Susan, María, Stephanie, Teresa y Terri! Es un placer tener un grupo con personas de tantos países......

En la próxima reunión, el sábado 17 de octubre, volveremos a hacer frente a uno de los pesos pesados de la literatura universal: Jorge Luis Borges.  Comentaremos uno de sus obras tardías, una colección de relatos que intitulada “El libro de arena”.  La sinopsis es la siguiente: www.casadellibro.com/libro-el-libro-de-arena/[masked]/562304 El libro estará disponible en Schoenhof's a un precio de $22.36 después de nuestro descuento.  Antes de ir a comprar el libro, os recomendaría que llamaseis a Schoenhof´s para comprobar existencias y reservar un ejemplar. 

Para la reunión del 21 de noviembre, nuestra lectura será "El amante japonés" de Isabel Allende.  La sinopsis de este libro, que está gozando de buenas críticas, es la siguiente:  "La historia de amor entre la joven Alma Velasco y el jardinero japonés Ichimei conduce al lector por un recorrido a través de diversos escenarios que van desde la Polonia de la Segunda Guerra Mundial hasta el San Francisco de nuestros días. «A los veintidós años, sospechando que tenían el tiempo contado, Ichimei y Alma se atragantaron de amor para consumirlo entero, pero mientras más intentaban agotarlo, más imprudente era el deseo, y quien diga que todo fuego se apaga solo tarde o temprano, se equivoca: hay pasiones que son incendios hasta que las ahoga el destino de un zarpazo y aun así quedan brasas calientes listas para arder apenas se les da oxígeno."

Aquellos que deseéis comprar el libro en Schoenhof´s, que me aviséis cuanto antes por favor.  Además de la lectura, vamos a asistir a la comparecencia de Isabel Allende en Harvard Books, en Cambridge el 11 de noviembre.  Los que estéis interesados en acompañarnos en la visita ese día, os rogaría me lo indicarais lo antes posible por favor para que podamos organizarlo con Harvard Books. 

Espero que la lectura y la oportunidad de escuchar a la autora en persona sean de vuestra agrado. 

¡Gracias a todos y hasta octubre!

Un abrazo,

Mark

results.description:
PLEASE PRE-REGISTER HERE: http://www.massaudubon.org/get-outdoors/program-catalog#program:keywords=Beekeeping:program_code=41843

Instructor: Sadie Brown (President, Boston Area Beekeepers Association)

Did you know that you can keep bees in your backyard? Even small urban yards (or roof tops!) can play host to a hive of honey bees, and those who tend them can enjoy honey, beeswax, pollen and of course, the bees themselves.

In this three-hour workshop, you will learn what it takes to keep a busy, productive hive of bees happy. Learn where to get your bees, how to set up and maintain the hive, and what types of activities and time commitments are required throughout the year. The workshop will also include time for Q&A

This is a beginner’s course, so no previous knowledge is required. This Beekeeping 101 class is a great intro and a way to test the waters if you are eager to gain some basic knowledge and find out if beekeeping is right for you. For those serious about taking up beekeeping we recommend our/BABA's in-depth 6-session Bee School to be taught in Jan-Feb 2016. 

Registration for Beekeeping 101 is required & space is limited!

Register online or call[masked] to register by phone (a MeetUp RSVP does not guarantee you a seat in class).

Mass Audubon Members: $25.00
Non-members:$30.00
(Non-members can join today during checkout and take immediate advantage of member prices.)

Join us for the October 2015 Meetup!

ATC THEMES:


1. Personal addictions

2. TV shows (postponed from September)


3. Artist's Choice


...and a special Halloween swap.


BOOK CLUB: If you'd like to participate in the discussion, please read "The Silent Land, by Graham Joyce" (a novel, widely available).


DEMO/ACTIVITY:  Another monoprint possibility!  This is one you may well have learned in grade school, but we've got some interesting twists.

WHAT OTHER SUPPLIES SHOULD I BRING? There's a suggested list in "All About the NE ATC+ Meetup" (also at the top of the Message Board). But even if you show up empty-handed, that's fine--we have loaner tools.

POTLUCK LUNCH: You're invited, but certainly not required, to bring food or drink for our potluck lunch, or to just bring your own lunch. No need to sign up; bring whatever you like.

FREE STUFF/SALE ITEMS: You're welcome to bring items to give away or sell to other Meetup members onsite. Just remember to remove anything that doesn't get picked up or sold--we can't leave anything behind.

COST: $10, regardless of when you arrive or depart; it covers our costs for the day. Sorry, no partial payments or IOUs. Cash is preferred; small bills are greatly appreciated. If payment is a hardship, please let the organizer know--we can work it out.

RSVPs: Please RSVP "yes" to attend; that way, we'll have an approximate headcount, and you'll receive all notifications about the Meetup! If your plans change, and you will be unable to attend, please change your RSVP to "no" no later than 24 hours before the start of the Meetup, so we'll know not to expect you. Anyone who cancels within 24 hours, regardless of the reason, will need to pay the fee anyway to help cover our costs for the day. 

LAST-MINUTE UPDATES: Please check your email in box and the website before leaving for the Meetup. That way, in the unlikely event that we need to cancel due to bad weather or any other reason, you'll be sure to get the news.

Hope to see you there!

There will be no face to face meetup unless we reach 50 RSVPs by Thursday of the week. You must be enrolled in one of the 10 FREE courses below or similar courses. 

Our past experience is that 20% of the RSVP shows up in the weekend meetings. Considering that, unless we have about 50 RSVPs, we cannot have a face to face meeting. Please use the questions / answers / discussions below for now. While asking questions, please make reference to the name of the course and the related module within the course. 

Cousera offers the following classes towards obtaining highly valuable knowledge/skills in Data Science Specialization. It is sometimes hard to work on the exercises and homework without the help of an expert.  Receiving one-on-one help from an expert can improve the commitment of finishing the program with accelerated learning. With that in mind, we are experimenting with the following service.


An expert (MS or PhD in Statistics) will answer any question free that takes less than 10 minutes to solve. There are nominal fees for one-on-one interactive help.  Please use the following link to request for help, or just email [masked] or call[masked]-8864.

http://www.tutorteddy.com/courses/coursera-course-help.php 

You can get help for the following Data Science Specialization Classes:  (from https://www.coursera.org/specialization/jhudatascience/1?utm_medium=courseDescripTop )

The Data Scientist’s Toolbox

R Programming

Getting and Cleaning Data

Exploratory Data Analysis

Reproducible Research

Statistical Inference

Regression Models

Practical Machine Learning

Developing Data Products

Data Science Capstone

results.description:
In response to a national call for white allies to engage white folks in racial justice, Boston Doorknockers go door to door in predominantly white neighborhoods to distribute yard signs saying “Black Lives Matter” and to plug folks into racial justice efforts ongoing in the Boston area.


We're doorknocking in partnership with Boston Police Camera Action Team (BPCAT)! We will be working to generate support from white folks in key districts to support BPCAT's community-based policy governing the implementation and use of police body cams. 

The policy is available here:

http://www.bpcat.org/national-reports-and-studies/

Typically the group meets centrally for a brief training and orientation and to distribute materials before dispersing; then returns to debrief when we are done. You can join us even if you haven't attended a prior training.


To sign up, please fill out this form ASAP: http://goo.gl/forms/Zeabx3fW0j


Children are welcome at all doorknocking events; this project intends to engage white allies and folks of all races are welcome to attend

Door-knocking requires the ability to stand and walk for long periods of time, if you want to get involved in other ways email us!

This event is also posted on Facebook.  Find the most up-to-date info there. 

main doorknock event page:

https://www.facebook.com/events/1675428796018832/

If you have any questions, reach out to the doorknocking organizers at [masked] [Keep in mind they are volunteers and working through consensus, so response times may vary.]
results.name: #BlackLivesMatter doorknocking Southie - #12

results.description:
Just kidding!! I know you're not effing around!!

The overarching themes for this group are currently: embodied presence in the moment, and the basics of getting work in Film and TV.


Embodied presence: 


how cultivating awareness in the present moment creates a bridge between your imaginative world and your everyday world, and gives you space to be grounded in both. 

Getting work:


Knowing and exploiting your “type” as an actor

Having a good head shot

Having appropriate sides for auditions.

Putting a good demo reel together.

The importance of creating your own content ( becoming a filmmaker yourself).

Networking - getting known by CD's, agents, filmmakers etc..

We will do a brief meditation and warm up. And then divide up the time for  you to address your current issues and concerns around acting, in a way that works for each person attending.

It's a small space, and there is limited room. The $5 cost of attending goes toward administrative costs for group. ie. rent for the room, meetup fees, etc. If you can't pay online or can't afford it, and want to attend, contact me and we'll make arrangements.

We invite you to come with an intention around how you want to use a block of the groups time to explore what's currently relevant for you. Again, we will divide up blocks of time for each attendee to explore something relevant to them. Whether it be working on a scene, getting feedback on your head shot, doing an improv... whatever you need. It's a good opportunity to learn to be focused, clear, and assert what you want!

Looking forward to seeing you!

Bring your materials!! Head Shots, sides, resumes...etc.

Best,


Robert

p.s.

I've finally put together my first acting reel. Check it out at:

https://youtu.be/Q0XidRml1rc
results.name: How to stop effing around and Become a Working Actor already!

results.description:
This is co-posted with Boston Cultural Nomads.

THIS IS A DIFFERENT ROUTE FROM THE ONE POSTED THE LAST TIME! On this tour you're advised to stay with the group because there is so much more to see!!!

CHECK IN AT 2:00, put your backpacks in the lockers, get your tickets (free for Cambridge residents with ID), Meet & Greet then at 2:15 we're OFF!

(FOLLOWING THIS WE HEAD ACROSS HARVARD YARD TO FELIPE'S FOR REFRESHMENTS IN HARVARD SQUARE AT 4 :45.)   
For the 7th time, at this popular & incredible gem of a Museum meetup location. We meet just inside the main entrance & head (this time) to the elevators area by the stairs to the 2nd floor strait to the Fancy Silverware exhibition. We continue on past the masterpieces portraying George Washington and Napoleon, to the painting called Feigned Flight, Ingres' Studies for the Martyrdom, Moreau's Jacob and the Angel, The incredible Call to Arms sculpture by Rodin, Dante Rossetti, & Burne-Jones' works. Then until we get to the Bernini statuettes. 

HOST WILL PASS THROUGH SOME GALLERIES BECAUSE THERE WILL BE SO MUCH MORE TO SEE. At 3:45 PM regroup at the elevators and head back downstairs to the Surrealist Art (follow the host) --note the sculpture Detroit Queen. Loop through there and get to the Picassos and the last room back towards the entrance including the Bathers by Renoir & Van Gogh's last painting, --then meet us again back at the open area cafeteria. If you do lose us or get tired, look for others in the meetup at the cafeteria back on the first floor, where we gather again and leave AT 4:45 we head to Felipe's.

ADMISSION free for Cambridge residents with a drivers license with a Cambridge address. Otherwise it's $15. Backpacks not allowed. You can store them in lockers across from the admissions area, alternately there is another locker area down one floor from there.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet just inside the entrance
results.name: Harvard Art Museums Meetup

You should feel comfortable swimming at least a couple lengths continuously (but if you're not and would be interested in learning to swim, leave a comment and maybe we can organize something!).

results.description:
First and foremost, make it an obvious picture of color! Rather than looking for rocks, leaves, trees, waterfalls, birds, flowers, fire hydrants, starfish, boats, orchards, or bridges, focus your energy and vision on red, blue, yellow, orange, green, or violet. Color first, content second! - Bryan Peterson

Time to discover the beauty of this very special location in Cambridge.

By FRIENDS OF MOUNT AUBURN 

Nature, which had once been something to fear, had by the early nineteenth century become considered a thing of beauty, mystery and awe.  Mount Auburn’s founders embraced and celebrated the natural terrain of their new Cemetery.  The design philosophies of the picturesque were developed in response to this new celebration of nature and the unknown. 

To be "picturesque", a landscape should appear wild, yet be carefully planned with plantings that highlight its natural ruggedness as if to appear like a painting.  Hills were considered to be a vital component of a picturesque landscape.

The colors of New England in this picturesque setting make a perfect subject for our photography workshop. The contrast of vibrant color against the granite sculptures and winding paths offers many stunning opportunities for creative expression.

Photo By GardenDesign.

Learning to see creatively means slowing down to notice simple details right in front of you the have the potential to make a great photo. The things other people walk right by will suddenly jump out at you begging for your attention. For three whole hours, we will focus our attention on the beautiful element of COLOR.

First, we will meet at the entrance and I will introduce you to some simple step by step practices for creative seeing so you can find COLOR in the most unexpected places. I will show you some inspiring example photos to help get you started.

Some of the topics we will play in the three 45 minute assignments.....

• How to use viewpoint and framing to create the most powerful color impact

• How to use contrasting colors to create dynamic energy

• How to use color to tell a story and evoke an emotion

You will have a chance to try these out right away with my guidance. You will receive individual coaching and critique while we are in the field shooting. This way you can be confident that you will be able to repeat the process next time you are out on a shoot.

We will work with color, and composition to make our photos come to life. As always, this is a non technical jargon zone. It is all about the creative act of seeing and capturing the moments of life with a fresh eye.

After the official class, we will stop in a local cafe so we can look at your photos . We offer each other constructive critique and suggestions for improvement. We have great people in this group and I know you will enjoy this social part of the program so please join us and RSVP now.

This workshop is for you if:

You are attracted to colors in nature and want to know how capture them.

You love COLOR and would like to know how to use is more effectively in your photos.

Your photos are “nice” but not jaw dropping all that often. You are not sure what to do to make them more dramatic and stunning.

 This is a fun, fast paced workshop. So if you would like to meet other people who love photography and are curious about how to take better photos, I hope you will join us.

I am very excited about offering this intensive COLOR workshop. I know you will leave with 5 new tips and techniques for seeing creatively that you will be able to apply to any type of photography you do in the future.

The $30.00 tuition for the workshop is covered by my 100% SNAP HAPPY GUARANTEE.  If you are not happy with what you learn during the workshop, I will return your tuition to you on the spot.

We are going to have a great time! You have joined the group, now join the fun. RSVP right away to hold your space. I look forward to seeing you THIS SATURDAY October 17th from 2:00-5:00. Once you reserve your space you will receive an email with more details about what to wear and what to bring to make the most of our time together.

Hope to see you there! Just RSVP now and you are in!

Suzanne

results.description:
Saying thank you is easy. Don't put it off any longer! Come celebrate the people who have made a difference in your life, and put your gratitude in writing.

What is a Happiness Gathering?

Happiness Gatherings are opportunities to put love and gratitude into action, in a fun, safe environment. An interactive discussion of the evening's topic is followed by an opportunity to actually DO some of those feel-good things that you may not get around to on your own. And you don't have to cook dinner! 

This Evening's Topic: Saying Thank You

Who are some of the people who have helped you become the person you are today?  Do they know how much their words or actions meant to you? Whether it was a parent, teacher, friend, doctor, counselor, or even a celebrity, this event is your opportunity to reflect on their impact, and tell them, in writing, that they made a difference to you.

Cards and postage provided, along with pizza and seltzer.  Feel free to bring additional food, drink, or materials to share.

Suitable for adults and interested children ages 8+.

About the Facilitator

Anne Lafleur, MSW, is a speaker, facilitator, and coach specializing in happiness and human connection. She helps individuals and groups identify small gifts that would feel good to give, and practice giving them away unconditionally. More information is on her website, www.thegiftofhappiness.org.

results.description:
We will meet at the zoo to attend the Jack-O-Lantern Spectacular. The 2015 presentation, titled “Jack-O-Lanterns from A to Z,” will delight new and repeat visitors alike. Scenes filled with intricate pumpkin art will be arrayed in alphabetical order, with highlights from history and popular culture.

For example, D is for dinosaur, F is for fantasy, H is for Horoscope, J is for jungle, T is for famous thinkers, and so on. Another section will honor inspirational figures such as Princess Diana and Nelson Mandela.

Popular annual features will return, such as the childhood favorites and Halloween scenes, and the show’s dazzling grand finale, the Laughing Tree. Hundreds of glowing jack-o-lanterns on the ground and high up in the trees surround carved giants (well over 1,000 pounds) amid spooky fog and music, punctuated by its iconic catchy beat and laughter.

Show standards will return, such as the childhood favorites and Halloween scenes, and the show’s dazzling grand finale, the Laughing Tree. Hundreds of glowing jack-o-lanterns on the ground and high up in the trees surround carved giants (well over 1,000 pounds) amid spooky fog and music, punctuated by its iconic catchy beat and laughter.

Crews from Passion for Pumpkins, the show creators, will spend several weeks leading up to the event creating the magical display. Then, they will work nearly around the clock throughout the 32 night run to keep the show fresh for visitors.
results.name: Jack-O-Lantern Spectacular: Roger Williams Zoo

• Why cut cords

results.description:
Let's head over to the StorySlam at Doyle's Cafe to participate or just to enjoy. Every 3rd Saturdays of the month.


7:30pm | Saturday, October 17th


October's Theme: Intuition

What is a Story Slam?
A story slam is a competition based on the art of storytelling. It puts a major emphasis on content and secondary on performance, encouraging storytellers to focus on what they’re saying and how they say it. It is an exercise in crafting stories within a set time limit


More about Story Slams from MassMouth:
http://massmouth.org/2011/02/what-is-a-story-slam/

For Schedule and Tickets Link:
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/story-slam-sharing-life-the-mic-tickets-18350765634?aff=erelexporg
results.name: StorySlam at Doyle's Cafe

results.description:
Our discussion last week was so lively & it was great...but I think it left a few of us wanting 'more'....

So let's revisit the topic with "Morality, Part II" and let's have this week's specific topic be: "What is more important to you...'personal' morality or 'society's' morality? ...and I am fairly sure that it will lead us into further discussion about capital punishment, etc., and that's fine. We discussed that and so many other points regarding morality last time, that we have lots more to mull over, debate over, etc...(PS/thanks for keeping it all respectful last week....there are many hot- buttons here!)

I'm going to ask for a table in the back so that we  can hear each other speak. If they are not able to accommodate us at Mandarin Gourmet, I will select another place very close by to that in the Chestnut Hill/West Roxbury/Dedham area.

Hope to see you then.....and if you respond 'yes' but then can't make it, kindly update so that others who may be on waitlist can join us...

See you then,

Bev

results.description:
Hi Precious Soul!

I'm excited to announce our first quarterly SOCIAL!


This social is open to ALL, with the two-fold intention of:

• Inviting and welcoming new people into the community

• Reuniting with friends after the summer


During the first part of the evening, I will provide guided exercises that will help you move energy, open your heart and feel more present. Next you will be lead in mixer activities to get to know each other better. The final portion of the evening will be open for mingling, dancing and deepening our connections.


Please wear celebratory, comfortable clothing. Feel free to bring a single flower, and a beverage, some finger food, dark chocolate or fruit to share.

I’m excited to see everyone and strengthen our community of loving, spiritual, open minded Tantra practitioners!

Much love,

Brynn


PS - I will be unveiling some exciting upcoming opportunities to deepen your connections and your practice!

PSS - Invite curious friends! This is the perfect low-stress introduction to our Tantra community.

results.description:
Châteauneuf-du-Pape the place is no more than a stoney village in arid, scented Provençal countryside, dominated by a ruined papal summer palace. The wine that bears its imposing name, though, is the magnificent standard-bearer for the dynamic southern Rhône, making France’s most potent, and some of its most individualistic, wines – both red and white.


Many vineyards in this area have topsoil covered by a great number of rounded stones, known as "galets", which bear evidence of the time when the Rhône, then a torrent, tore fragments of rock from the Alps and deposited them along its course. The stones retain heat during the day and release it at night which can have an effect of hastening the ripening of grapes. The stones can also serve as a protective layer to help retain moisture in the soil during the dry summer months.

Please join us to taste this wine with its wide array of aromas and flavors reminiscent of a Provençal marketplace while its texture—rich and round, sumptuous and opulent—is virtually unmatched by most of the wines of the world.

Bring a bottle of Châteauneuf-du-Pape at about the $50-80 price range (in a paper bag), 4 glasses and a food item to share.
results.name: Châteauneuf-du-Pape

We are on the second floor of the office/clubhouse building. If for some reason, the front door isn't propped open, come around the back of the clubhouse, up the outside back stairs to the second floor, where you can enter through the sliding glass door on the deck.

You CAN park along the road or in the "future resident" spots, but please do not take the spots in front of the building next door that are "resident only."

You can bring food and drink. If you want to grab dinner on the way in, there is a good and inexpensive Italian place almost across the street that also does take-out (Linguine's) and there is a Chipotle's nearby but expect to wait in line for 40 minutes on a Friday night. Feel free to bring your own games and snacks/drinks. We do have a small kitchen available to us.

Don't forget - Randy is paying Meetup like $15 a month to run this group. Consider chipping in a couple bucks each year to help defray his costs.

results.description:
Let's Play Dodgeball!

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let'slationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

https://youtu.be/QPDs4zs3kzw

Remember when you used to get a lunch break AND recess? Let's return to our glory days for some school yard fun! So many relationships were formed while we were playing games-we made friends, scores were settled, and we figured out how to interact with the opposite sex. Well, some of us did :)

Worried about being branded with the logo from the rubber ball? Well, don't...we use soft squishy balls…without a visible logo :) So, if you really hope to get a tattoo, you'll have to find another way.

Dodgeball Details: Teams are chosen round robin style, so it doesn't matter if you ruled the schoolyard at one point. There won't be any awkward "I hope I'm chosen before the kid in the full body cast". The "rules" will be explained by the referee before playing starts. They aren't complex, and there won't be any instant replays for controversial calls.

It's designed to be fun, playful, and casual. The only rule I can remember is not aiming for someone's head. Ladies, I can't guarantee that the guys are going to follow that one : ) Guys, this is still not the best way to get a woman's attention….

All levels are welcome! We will be playing on a padded floor, wearing socks (remember to bring socks!). The arena is air conditioned and is smaller than a typical dodgeball court.

Dodgeball of Boston is located at 1 Broadway in Arlington, MA. There is a small parking lot, emphasis on small, and free street parking available on the side streets. Public transportation is probably the easiest way to get there. It's about one mile from Davis Sq Redline T and Alewife T Stations.

Cost: $10. PLEASE try to pay with a $10 bill, or some combination that adds up to $10 ($5 bills, $1 bills, etc…), as change is hard to make. The cover goes to pay the rent for the space.

After Dodgeball: We will head for drinks/appetizers nearby at:

Orleans Restaurant 
65 Holland Street 
Davis Square, Cambridge

We always have a lot of fun there too, drinking, eating and singing karaoke, and it's a great way to enjoy Friday night!

This will be a joint event with other meet up groups, please only RSVP in one group.

IMPORTANT: Please be sure to bring socks with you in order to play!

--Carla & Matt 
;-)

https://youtu.be/cXmt_iFLd58

results.description:
NOTE: Season 1 will be led by Leslie Glynn, Senior Percolator, and Gene Babon, Chief Percolator.  Rick Umali will be a stow-away on this adventure and we can call on him in the unlikely event that our ship drifts off course.  We set sail on Sunday, October 18.


Git is the #1 source control technology preferred by 69% of developers in a 2015 Developer Survey of more than 26,000 working professionals coordinated by Stack Overflow.

Git Lunch is our latest virtual self-study group focused on Git, a free and open source distributed version control system. This season debuts with the publication of a book authored by Boston PHP member, Rick Umali.

Season 1 introduces the discipline of source code control using Git. Whether you're a newbie or a busy pro moving your source control to Git, you'll appreciate how this book concentrates on the components of Git you'll use every day. The book's easy-to-follow lessons are designed to take an hour or less.

The book we will be using is Learn Git in a Month of Lunches which was released on October 1, 2015.

Access Chapter 1 -- Before Your Begin to see if this book and this self-study group is right for you.


Note: There is no classroom instruction. There are no webcasts. There are no scheduled appointments of any kind.

Once you have the book, you simply proceed at a pace that best fits into your current work/life schedule. You have the option to meet informally at the beginning of each Boston PHP Meetup, if you live in the Boston area. You DO NOT need to live in the Boston area to participate.  Invite your friends, family members and co-workers to join in the fun!

Additional details will be discussed at the Wednesday, October 14 Meetup -- Brief Intro to GitHub -- from 6:30 pm to 7:00 pm.

FAQs:

Q: How long will the course last?

A: We will cover 20 chapters in the book starting Sunday, October 18 and ending Saturday, March 5.  Refer to the Git Lunch, Season 1 -- Master Discussion List  for specific dates.

Q: Do I have to wait until Sunday, October 18 to begin?

A: No need to wait! Feel free to begin as soon as you obtain a copy of your book.  Simply post a message on the Introduce Yourself: Git Lunch, Season 1 message board once you receive your book so that we can gauge participation. Then, proceed at a pace that best fits your current work/life schedule.

Q: Do I have to live in Boston to participate?

A: Not at all. This program is virtual. We have successful graduates from many states and even have graduates from countries in Europe and Africa.

Q: What if I have additional questions?

A: Simply post a reply below and you will receive a response.

Let's Git Lunch!

Rick Umali
Rare Guest Appearances


Leslie Glynn
Senior Percolator

Gene Babon
Chief Percolator

results.description:
So, the title is meant literal: I challenge you to capture the Zodiacal Light, as I have never done so. Images need to be taken during this event period, old photos don't count. Are you a morning person? Good, the best time to do this is 12-24 October before dawn.

Zodiacal light is a faint, roughly triangular, diffuse white glow seen in the night sky that appears to extend up from the vicinity of the sun along the ecliptic (the apparent path that the sun takes across our sky). It is best seen just after sunset in spring, and just before sunrise in autumn, when the zodiac is at a steep angle to the horizon. Caused by sunlight scattered by space dust </a>in the zodiacal cloud, it is so faint that either moonlight or light pollution renders it invisible. That means: shooting over the ocean on the beach gets you best results, but you will need a clear night without much marine layer fog.


In the northern hemisphere, the light appears as a faint cone of light above the eastern horizon before sunrise (or the western horizon in spring). Its light intensity is greater than the Milky Way. Typically, the light is colorless, but in rare circumstances it can have blue, green, yellow, or red hues. If the conditions are right, it is easy to see the zodiacal light, but because it is so faint and occurs near the horizon, most viewers think they are seeing twilight or the light from a distant town (both of which we eliminate by shooting before civil twilight and over the ocean). It is best seen when the sun is between 18 and 12 degrees below the horizon, that means during nautical twilight.


The best time then is 5:30 to 6:30 a.m. during the period 12-24 October, after that it gets too bright (sunrise is around 7, in case you want to capture, that, too). Even though the light can be seen well in general in October and November, the moon will be out of the way only during that period of 12-24 Oct (and again 11-23 November). If you have PhotoPills (iToy) or PlanIt! (Android), these apps can show you exactly where the sun would come up, that is where you have to point your camera - typically due East (90°) to about 100°.


<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiacal_light">Here is more info about it on Wikipedia

and

some examples on Google

.

Shooting settings are the same as for star points or Milky Way: wide open aperture (f/2.8 or wider), maximum exposure time in seconds is determined as 400/focal length in mm (300/FL for cropped sensor cameras) and ISO between 1600 and 3200 (6400 is usually too noisy and diminishes the beauty of the faint light). Compose to have something interesting in your foreground, could be silhouettes, as long as it is not a plain straight beach. Try some dunes, or if you plan to go into the mountains, that works, too.


Useless trivia: Brian May, guitarist of the rock band Queen moonlighted (!) as a scientist and completed a PhD thesis on A Survey of Radial Velocities in the Zodiacal Dust Cloud.


Post pictures here as you get them.

We have 2 groups:

1. Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.
2. Our Alumni Jogging Group has a goal of keep jogging for those who have jogged at least once season with us.

We introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 10-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles) 

• Anyone from the community can participate

• Led by experienced runners

• Monday through Thursdays 6pm-6:45pm; Sundays 8am-8:45am, with a goal of joining us 3 of these sessions per week.

• 45 minute time commitment

• Goal of jogging and finishing the Stow Gobbler on Thanksgiving morning.

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group.

Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.

For more information please visit http://www.connectingpointchurch.org/couchto5k/

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]

=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to two of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Wildcat A and Wildcat D. We will use Nineteen Mile Brook Trail and Wildcat Ridge Trail to reach Wildcat A and then we will follow Wildcat Ridge Trail to get to Wildcat D. From there we will use the ski trails to get back to the cars.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.


The maximum group size for this trip will be 12 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 8.4 miles and climb about 3,400 feet. It should take an average hiker about 6 hours 15 minutes to complete. This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/20-Mt-Wildcat-4422--40-Wildcat-D-Peak-4050


Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. Use this link for the current weather forecast:

http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lat=44.2649&lon=-71.2403#.ViBrjrTO5_Y


=== What to Bring ===


It is starting to get cold in the mountains - this means any water on the trail may freeze and it might snow. It's time to start transitioning to cold weather gear - you will now need warm layers, hat and gloves, and light traction (i.e. Kahtoola Microspikes or Hillsound Trail Crampons. Use this link for a list of items needed for most three-season day hikes:

http://files.meetup.com/492954/Three_Season_Dayhike_gear_list.pdf 

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet in the Wildcat Mountain Ski Area parking lot which is located on the east side of Route 16 north of the AMC's Pinkham Notch Visitor's Center. According to Google Maps this spot is about 162 miles from Boston and it will take about 3 hours to drive there.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

https://goo.gl/maps/rjyr8tcZvev


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

The pace will  be~ 8:30-9:30 min/mi depending on terrain. To keep pace with the group, you should be able to run a 5k at a road pace of 8-8:30 minute miles. (trail running tends to be slower). If you're faster than the group, you are welcome to start with us, and can head out on your own or do some laps. I will try to maintain a steady pace and won't race after anyone.  If you are slower than 8:30 pace, please check out Monica's run on Thursdays at 5pm. If all of this sounds good, and you are like me & don't mind the company of random strangers running along side you, come out and get you heart pumping.

results.description:
Come join us for a fun urban barefoot hike along Boston's historic Freedom Trail.  We'll follow the trail through the streets of Boston, the North End, and over to Charlestown.  We will return along the trail back to our starting point (or take the shortcut if we're tired).  Interesting urban textures include old worn brick, cobblestone, ancient granite slab sidewalks, and two passes over the Charlestown Bridge (400 feet of steel grating).  The hike will be 2 to 3 miles long depending on how far the group would like to go.  We could stop for lunch again like we have in times past, if there is interest.

We'll meet on Beacon St, right in front of the Statehouse, gathering around the brass Freedom Trail marker on the sidewalk.  Everyone should bring water.  All are welcome (new barefooters and those not sure of their distance ability should bring backup shoes).  Street parking is free on Sunday but be sure to carefully read the signs (resident parking only, etc).  There is an underground parking garage below the Common (not sure how much to park these days).  Or, you can take the T to Park Street station.

Sorry, it's been a while since our last hike.  I've been trying to catch up on everything after losing five weeks to Lyme disease this Summer.

Sometimes participants bring print-outs of articles, research, or books to share on the topic, and sometimes people just come with a story or opinion to share.

We loosely moderate the topical discussion to give everyone a chance to participate. Then the conversation often flows onto other related subjects, sometimes in smaller conversation groups around the table.

If you have any ideas for meeting topics, please let any of the co-organizers know. We can also add announcements or "mini-topics" on the agenda if there's anything you'd like to share with the group.

For this brunch, we encourage you all to share your thoughts and opinions about Asian Americans and Higher Education.

results.description:
Our services have three parts: Healing Service, a Lecture on a spiritual topic, and Mediumship Spirit Communication. Each part lasts approximately 30 minutes.

The Healing Service gives you the opportunity to receive healing energy that is channeled through one of our Healers. We believe that healing can be channeled through thought to those who need it. This is a very calming experience, whether or not you choose to sit in a healing chair.  We encourage you to send healing to your loved ones, our communities, and Mother Earth.

The Lecture covers a variety of topics ranging from the History of Spiritualism to Inspired Insights. It also includes examples of how Spiritualism is a part of our lives on a daily basis.

Mediumship, or Spirit Communication, is the part of the service where a medium proves that "...the existence and personal identity of the individual continue after the change called death." The medium might be a member of our church or visiting from another the Spiritualist church in the community. We also have mediums from abroad stop in often. While there is only enough time during a service for a few people to receive messages from their deceased loved ones on the Higher side Side of Life, everyone present benefits by witnessing proof of the continuation of life.

At the conclusion of the service everyone is invited to our social hour downstairs for coffee and conversation.﻿

results.description:
These sessions at The Chinatown Community Center/Josia School will focus on a 6 week rotating schedule of classes designed to introduce the basics of Parkour in concentrate classes. The schedule will follow in order: 

• Safety, Landings and Balance

Class 1 will be focusing on how to land, move and stay safe practicing Parkour outdoor and in the real world. 

• Vaulting

Class 2 will focus on the foundation of Parkour - getting over low-level obstacles fast and efficiently through the use of vaulting.

• Precisions

Class 3 will focus on accuracy of jumping and foot/eye coordination honing basic standing and running jumps.

• Wall Techniques 

Class 4 will focus on conquering obstacles too large or tall to vault, in tandem with using walls as a means to keep a more efficient run.

• Tumbling/Acro

Class 5 focus is on tumbling and acrobatic skills, in pursuit of fully understanding movement in a 3D space and total proprioception.

• Flow + Speed

Class 6 links together all the previous lessons into one cohesive movement, and a timed obstacle course setting. ------

What if I've never done anything like Parkour before? 


This class, Parkour 101, is a introductory level class. We will be focusing more on learning how to move our body, understand our limits and get a solid understanding of how to train safe rather than jumping straight into super-high level flips and jumps. 

What if I'm a gymnast/marine/stuntman/etc? I don't want to be bored.

Our program prides itself on scaling classes to each and every student. With something like Parkour there are many levels and progressions to each movement. It's very common to in the same class have one student working on perfecting their roll, and on the other side of the room have another student practicing very high-level acrobatics. They both come from the same foundation, but are scaled to each practitioners skill level. 

What do I need to bring/prepare?

The great thing about Parkour is its accessibility. You really only need a good pair of shoes. We recommend a shoe that is made for urban running (no aggressive treads, a smoother sole lightweight). Think hiking boots, crocs, skate shoes are all no-nos. 

Other than that, dress appropriately for activity. Shorts, sweats, t-shirts are all good here. Jeans are normally not the best choice. 

We highly recommend bringing water, snacks and a form of transportation (bike, longboard, potentially train fare)

We will be charging a $5 per class fee to start here, and for the 1 hour 15 minute class we think this isn't too ridiculous. We accept cash or card day of. 

Anything else?

These jams will be run outdoors, and with existing architecture. While we won't be getting into anything crazy, injuries are to be expected. Scrapes happen. We will have first aid available, but make sure you are thinking clearly and in your limits before training! 

I am available to answer all questions, but I hope to see a whole bunch of you out in a few weeks!! 

Be sure to check us out on:

https://www.facebook.com/ParkourAndTricking

https://instagram.com/projectfreerun


http://www.projectfreerun.com/

results.description:
Same as last time, basically, so I'll copy and paste the info from before. Special note for people new to the outdoors: Personally I'll be looking to climb harder stuff this time, (i.e. in the main quarry), which means less time given to showing people how to set up anchors, etc. If you don't know how, do come down - it's a great place to learn this stuff and I or someone else will show you the basics. But just be aware I won't be doing it all day and as always you're responsible for your own safety.

Quincy Quarry is, as the name suggests, a quarry just outside Quincy. It has a shedload of top-roping routes ranging from a set of friendly-looking 5.6s in little railroad, to some pretty burly looking routes in the 5.11 range on the overhanging Q-wall. There is even a single, solitary, route than can be led.
Other popular activities in the quarry include graffiti, drinking, smoking weed, and disposing of bodies.

You can very conceivably get there by public transport from Boston: take the red line to Quincy center and then the 215 bus. If anyone has a car, however, the journey will be much simpler. Car pooling would be much appreciated, I'm sure.

I'd suggest we meet under Q-wall in the main quarry at about 11:30am - if you're coming from the car park it's the first one you come to, on the right as you enter.

Good topos are available on mountain project along with an aerial map of the quarry so you can orient yourselves:
http://www.mountainproject.com/v/quincy-quarries/105908121


==Gear: [ please read carefully ]==

Most routes have expansion bolts above them for setting up a top-rope. A decent rack for Quincy will involve about 8-10m of rigging rope or thick tape, a handful of locking carabiners (min 4 per anchor), and a 50m rope or longer. The rock is pretty stable, but a helmet would be a smart move.
Obviously the number of people who can go at any time is limited by the number of ropes etc, so please make it known in the comments if you have a rope to offer, or rigging gear, or will be relying on other people. I'm sure we're happy to share, but it would be wise not to turn up and expect to climb all day just using other people's equipment, especially if ropes are limited. Alternatively if you decide you're not going to turn up make this clear too - ropes are heavy and we don't want to drag them down for a no-show.

Guidebooks: there's a decent set of routes in 'Rock Climbing: New England', and (I'm told) a more comprehensive list in 'Boston Rocks'. Mountain project is also a good resource for the quarries - if you've not got a book, do download the app.
results.name: Climbing at Quincy Quarries

results.description:
Come join us at our regular Scrabble Meetup, and play over lunch or a pastry and some coffee!

We meet twice a month, every month, on the first and third Sunday. Please bring a board if you have one. We have a few spares, so you are welcome to come even if you forget your board.

Newcomers are always welcome. We keep 2 and 3 letter "cheat sheets" for new folks to keep the playing field more even.

We mostly play Scrabble one-on-one, and pairing is random. If you would like to be matched up to someone of a similar skill, just let the organizer know.

Au Bon Pain is right next to the Davis Square T stop, and there is typically ample free street parking on Sundays.  A few times a year, there is a race in Davis Square that shuts down some streets, so keep an eye out for that. If possible I will send out a message to the group the day before.

$1/Meetup goes to help pay for the annual Meetup.com dues and miscellaneous photocopying, but if you are a regular $10/year will be easier for you and me to keep track of!

results.description:
Here's the game plan:

1:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

1:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

1:20 - Play!!!!!!

3:00 - Conclude the meetup with snacks and socializing


Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white t-shirt and a colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a dark or white "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, pinnies, sunscreen, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

results.description:
The Vietnamese class for adults repeats on Sundays and takes place on the second floor of the VietAID Center near the Fields Corner T stop. Parking is also available.

Trimester 1: Class 3
Book 1: Lesson 2
Introductions

The school year is divided into 3 trimesters of about 10 weeks each (not including holiday weekends). Students can sign up for 1, 2, or hopefully all 3. Fee for each trimester is $60 and you pay as you go for the trimester(s) that you take. The fee helps pay for space rental, books, printings, snacks, and other miscellaneous items that will be purchased for the class. Pay during your first class, you don't have to pay before. The teacher is southern Vietnamese but he will teach in the northern dialect. The southern pronounce certain letters (d, g, v) the same, which makes it more difficult to learn to read.

There is no homework, no tests. There is only lecture, workshop, practice, and recitation
results.name: Vietnamese Language Class for Adults 3

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,

Let's meet a little early before the MFA Palestine Festival film event and hang out at the Taste Cafe and Wine Bar until showtime. This cafe is located on Level 1, directly across from the Remis Auditorium, next to the Bookstore and Shop.

I have set the start time for this meeting for 1 pm. Then at 2 pm, the plan is to walk across the corridor and get in line, gather as a group and then enter the auditorium as a group at 2:15 pm.  Film starts at 2:30 pm.  

I will try to occupy the large, tall tables directly across from the auditorium.  It is not a very large cafe, it should be easy for you to find me. I will try to discreetly hold a Meetup sign. 


To help you get acquainted with the location,  here is the link to the MFA first floor plan: http://mfas3.s3.amazonaws.com/Map_June2015_level1.pdf


<a href="http://www.mfa.org/sites/default/files/MFA_Map_Sept2013_Level1_web.pdf"></a>

• Please only reserve "YES" if you are attending.


• If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.

I look forward to wining with you at the MFA.


Joana

results.description:
Small Doggy Playdates is conveniently held at The Meadows Pet Resort and Spa in Holliston, 140 Summer Street. We meet mostly every 3rd Sunday of the month, 1:00 pm - 2:30 pm.


The Meadows is a multi-million dollar pet resort. The resort provides us with a large, clean indoor room with windows, chairs, water bowls, and plenty of room for our small dogs to play and socialize. Your dog can run around and play with others, off leash, in a safe environment.  

• All small and toy breeds are welcome. We look forward to having owners of FRIENDLY, EASY-GOING small dogs (under 20 lbs), with GOOD DOGGY MANNERS come play and make new friends. Please be sure your small dog(s) is healthy, clean, spayed or neutered, flea-free, and up-to-date with shots. If your pup(s) shows aggression or excessively barks towards others, you may be asked to leave.

• Due to the increase in participation at our PlayDates in Holliston, parking has become limited. The Holliston Meadows staff has asked us to please park directly across the street at Fatima Shrine where there is ample FREE parking for all. 

• To be sure there is enough seating, feel free to bring your own folding chair. 

• Due to some food allergy-prone dogs, please refrain from feeding your dog treats or snacks during the PlayDate. Their Moms and Dads will greatly appreciate this.

results.description:
Hi Everyone,

My name is Paula.  I am a new member to the Fun Stuff group, but I have been a host for 40+ and Loving Boston for a couple of years.  I  moved to Natick this past spring and would like to meet people in the Metro West area.  I will eventually post a happy hour and possibly a dinner, but in the meantime, I would like to invite you to my open house. 

I am a direct sales consultant with Scentsy (https://paulamarkson.scentsy.us) We offer a line of ceramic candle warmers and fragrant wax bars. Our warmers use low watt light bulbs to melt the wax (so no flames), which means there are no harmful chemicals or smoky residue released into your home. Scentsy bars burn 60 – 80 hours -- they are safe, with no soot, and very cost effective. If you like candles (or you have friends and family who do) or are at least curious, please contact me for the address.

I live in Natick Center, less than a 10 minute walk from the commuter rail (Boston/Worcester line). There is also plenty of street parking if driving.

Thanks for your consideration.  I look forward to meeting members here or at future events.
Paula

Please join us in October when we welcome our speaker Nate Matias, a fellow at the Berkman Center at Harvard and PhD student at the MIT Media Lab Center for Civic Media. Nate's current projects include large scale research on community building online, and he will be talking on the theme of Gratitude.

We will also be collecting non-perishable food items to be donated to the Greater Boston Food Bank. Please bring as many items as you can that match the following criteria:

- non-perishable (not frozen/refrigerated), sealed, unexpired food
- unopened toiletries (shampoo, soap, shaving cream, etc.)
- preferably non-glass containers
- sorry, no baby food or pet food

After a couple prime time games, the Steelers are back at 1 PM on Sunday, in a match-up that WILL NOT BE televised locally.  So far, Arizona has been scoring the highest PPG in the league this year, and they're coached by Bruce Arians, former Pittsburgh Steelers offensive coordinator and close friend of Big Ben.  With that background, Ben has come out and said he's holding out hope to play in this game after practicing with the team Weds and Thurs this week.

Yinz in Boston Notes:

Just a reminder that Cityside is now providing Yuengling buckets for Steeler fans: 5 Yuengling bottles on ice for $18.  It's a great value, and this way you don't have to keep ordering beers.  As always, 20% off all food items for Steeler fans and $3 Coors Lights.  

2015 Yinz in Boston koozies are $2 each.  Meetup.com isn't cheap and there's always other ad hoc costs associated with group activities, so if you like what we're up to, please support the fundraiser!

Lastly, bring your towels!  Steelers Nation Unite is requesting videos of us waiving our towels after big plays.  They'd like to play these on the Heinz Field jumbotron after big plays at home games (and they'll mention us in the caption), so come stocked!

results.description:
How do Humanists talk about death and dying? How can atheists and agnostics find meaning and beauty in mortality? All of us are touched by death, all of us will die, and all of us have the opportunity to shape the meaning of our time until then. The best way to do so is to learn to love this imperfect and finite life and the people in it, until our last conscious moments. But in order to embrace life, we have to come to terms with death. 

From Plato to Ernest Becker to JK Rowling to Atul Gawande, Ta-Nehisi Coates, and Woody Allen, what are the key lessons we can learn from great humanistic thinkers, on being mortal?

This program will feature an open, tentative, but passionate community discussion of questions such as: how can we talk with people who are dying, or with children learning about death? How do we cope with and understand the emotions that thoughts of death bring? How do we communicate about and plan for dying, including end of life care and the fate of our bodies after death? What is a humanist funeral? How is mortality a social justice issue? 

Greg chose to take on this subject after being invited last December to be one of two speakers at Mt. Auburn Cemetery's annual Candle Lighting Service for families of those who are buried there-- the largest event of each year at the historic Cambridge cemetery. You can read a transcript of his remarks at that event, here: 

http://www.patheos.com/blogs/gregepstein/2014/12/on-grief-winter-and-kindling-lights/

Join Greg for his monthly talk, with music, discussion groups, refreshments and more.
results.name: Greg Epstein: Death and Dying From a Humanist Perspective

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers, 


Let's watch Palestinian film,  The Wanted 18, at the MFA, part of the The 9th Annual Boston Palestine Film Festival.  

It is a part-animated documentary about non-violent resistance and fugitive cows.  For sure this event will sell out soon, consider yourselves warned. I strongly recommend that you purchase your tickets in advance. You may purchase online at http://www.mfa.org/programs/film/the-wanted-18.  The cost is $9 for members and $11 for non-members.


Tickets go on sale Thursday, September 17 at 10 am, so mark your calendars. 


The film starts at 2:30 pm, however the meeting time for the group is set for 2:00 pm  pm at the entrance of the Remis Auditorium.  

The plan is to meet at 2 pm at the entrance of the auditorium and then  enter the auditorium to sit as a group at 2:15 pm. I will do my best to find you and make easier for you to find me by holding a small Meetup Up sign.  I strongly recommend that you come early and join the pre-Meetup gathering for this event at the Taste Cafe. 

The auditorium is located inside the museum on Level 1.  Directly across from the auditorium, there is the Taste Cafe and Wine Bar.  I will schedule a separate event at this cafe for those who would like to meet early, starting at 1 pm, to have a snack or lunch before the film.

Just a reminder, this is an actual meet-up event, not an advertisement. For events to be successful, I need to know who to expect and how many.  


This is a public event and you are certainly free to attend this event outside the Meetup group.  I just ask  that only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending this event and intend to meet members of the group.  

If you reserve "YES", we will be expecting you.  If you reserve "YES" and then have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.  A consistent history of not showing up for events may cause you to be removed from the group.  

As for parking, and directions, I strongly recommend that you take public transportation, the Green E line stops right in front of the museum. Also there are several buses that also stop in front of the museum. Visit these links for more information on getting to the museum and parking: http://www.mfa.org/visit/getting-here, www.mbta.com .

I look forward to seeing you at the MFA.

Joana

***Additional Film Information***


The Wanted 18  by Paul Cowan and Amer Shomali (2014, 75 min.). 


It’s 1987, and the first Intifada is rising. In the Israeli-occupied West Bank, Palestinian residents want local alternatives to Israeli goods, including milk, which they have been buying from an Israeli company. Activists in filmmaker Amer Shomali’s village of Beit Sahour, a suburb of Bethlehem, decide to buy 18 cows from an Israeli kibbutz, transport them to the West Bank, and produce their own milk as a cooperative. The cows become legendary, and the “intifada milk” (sometimes distributed under cover of darkness) becomes a part of daily life. But this act of defiance does not go unnoticed. The Israeli Army raids the dairy, photographs the cows, and declares the farm a threat to Israel’s national security. Employing an impressive mixture of media—claymation, comic strips, reenactment, archived video footage, sketches, photographs, interviews and voiceover narration—this ingenious documentary captures the spirit of the first Palestinian uprising through the personal experiences of those who lived it-and provides an enchanting, inspirational tribute to the ingenuity and power of grassroots activism. In English, Arabic, and Hebrew with English subtitles. 

To view trailer, https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ekhTuZpMw54  


<a>http://www.bostonpalestinefilmfest.org/about/</a>;

<a>http://www.mfa.org/programs/film/the-wanted-18</a>;


<a>http://news.harvard.edu/gazette/harvard-events/events-calendar/#/?i=5</a>;

results.description:
We all know how to find a closed form for: 


but when faced with what seems like it should be an easier question:

I, speaking personally, would have no idea where to start. And I don't feel particularly enlightened when I look up the answer, which turns out to be n(n+1)(2n + 1)/6.

There is a better way! Discrete calculus is calculus on integers instead of the reals. It's an alternate universe where we start by defining differentiation:

and go from there. (That's an operator, which takes in functions and spits out functions. Don't worry if it doesn't make perfect sense right now, this is just the teaser!) The counterpart of integration in discrete calculus is summation.

This gives us a systematic way to solve sums like the above. But also: Funky! Wacky! Every concept from calculus has one or several cousins in discrete calculus. For example, there's a discrete version of e and two discrete versions of log. There's a discrete power rule and a discrete product rule (and you can discretely integrate by parts). Discrete differential equations are recurrence relations (for example, the Fibonacci recurrence relation f(n) = f(n - 1) + f(n - 2)).

This will be my first talk, and I'm hoping to make it as interactive as possible. If you have questions please ask them! There is always a minimum of two other people that your question will help out as well, three if you count me.

You can make some pretty far-reaching analogies with this stuff, and also some pretty concrete ones, so it should be accessible to people coming from a variety of backgrounds. If you ever listed out the squares:

1   4   9   16   25   36   49   64

and then noticed that if you subtracted each number from the one following it, you got the odd numbers...

1   4   9   16   25   36   49   64


  3    5   7    9    11     13    15

then you were doing discrete calculus! And we'll do some more exciting stuff along those lines, related to these pretty pictures, which I'll leave you with.

******************************************************

A NOTE ON THE LOCATION: For first-timers, getting into the building can be a bit tricky. See this page for a map and explanation.
results.name: Discrete Calculus

results.description:
Anna Dressed in Blood by Kendare Blake

We will be having the bookclub meeting at Coppersmith in South Boston.  There will be a voluntary $1 donation to Gabby to help defray the cost of the meetup.



Cas Lowood has inherited an unusual vocation: He kills the dead.

So did his father before him, until he was gruesomely murdered by a ghost he sought to kill. Now, armed with his father's mysterious and deadly athame, Cas travels the country with his kitchen-witch mother and their spirit-sniffing cat. They follow legends and local lore, destroy the murderous dead, and keep pesky things like the future and friends at bay.

Searching for a ghost the locals call Anna Dressed in Blood, Cas expects the usual: track, hunt, kill. What he finds instead is a girl entangled in curses and rage, a ghost like he's never faced before. She still wears the dress she wore on the day of her brutal murder in 1958: once white, now stained red and dripping with blood. Since her death, Anna has killed any and every person who has dared to step into the deserted Victorian she used to call home.

Yet she spares Cas's life.
