results.description:
18xx games are about railroads: building track and running trains for profit. 18xx games are also about a stock market, and the skullduggery between various robber barons as they try to build, thwart, take over, or bankrupt companies. But, they can take quite a while to play. We play with poker chips and emphasize a "ready to play" culture (we usually track operating order, so you know when your companies will act). Games have generally taken from 2 hours (via bankruptcy) to 6 hours (to the end) with the average around five hours, even with new players. The more you plan in advance, the faster the game (of course, many times the other robber barons thwart your plans!)

You will need to be ready to start right at the starting time, or very close to it, because the game is so long. We also are splitting into two games quite frequently now so being early is better so we can decide which 18xx games to play and then have to set them up, unless we ALL can come to a pre-arrangement in the comments.


New players are welcome although we strongly suggest familiarizing yourself with the basic rules and concepts first. A brand new player will need 20 to 40 minutes of rules explanation before they play, so if you're new and Tamm says the room is available a little earlier than our 2pm start time (it isn't always), we recommend setting up an early teaching session with an experienced player. The game really isn't overly complex, rules-wise, it's just long with lots of decisions. It is a little fiddly sometimes, though.


Due to some late arrivals in September we will emphasize: If you're over 15 minutes late and have not made arrangements with one of the tables, you are probably only going to be a mere spectator, unless there is a game doing a rules explanation, you know that 18xx variant well, and can make it before it starts. If you're much later you probably won't be able to join a game at all. It usually takes us all afternoon and well into the evening to play one game of 18xx. Even our more "experienced" tables usually drop four or five hours into a single game (or more; 18EU ran about six to seven hours last time). It is rare that there is a second game.


What you need to know about 334 Mass Ave:

-Press 999 on the intercom and security will let you into the building
-You must sign in at the security desk with a picture ID
-Take the elevator down to level "A." Exit the elevator to your left and the community room will be ahead on your right, next to the laundry room.
results.name: October 18xx Trainapalooza

results.description:
The Arboretum’s maple collection is a hotspot for beautiful autumn color.

Let's get out to enjoy the most colorful time of the year in Boston by joining Nancy Rose the Arnoldia editor on a stroll through the maples. You will learn about the Arboretum's diverse and valuable maple collection as well as be amazed by the brilliant display of fall foliage in shades from gold to crimson.

In addition to your Meetup RSVP, you MUST register for this FREE  guided tour here, https://my.arboretum.harvard.edu/SelectTime.aspx

Wear comfortable walking shoes and dress for the weather.

Meet at the Hunnewell Building which you can see on the map at this link

Call (617)[masked] for information and to confirm tour status in case of inclement weather.

Comment if you want to head over to Centre Street for some conversation and/or a bite to eat.

Directions to the Arnold Arboretum Main Entrance and Hunnewell Building located at 125 Arborway, Boston, MA 02130


Subway

Take the MBTA Orange Line to its southern end – Forest Hills. Turn left as you pass through the turnstiles. Exit through the door marked “Arnold Arboretum.” Proceed about 60 feet, then turn left and continue parallel to the Arborway (which is elevated above the bus stop). Continue walking along the Arborway, up the hill and to the Arboretum’s Forest Hills gate on your left. To reach the Arboretum’s main entrance and the Hunnewell Building, continue along the Arborway to the main gate (about 10 minutes).

Bus

Take the #39 bus to the South Street and Custer Avenue stop in Jamaica Plain (just after the monument stop). Walk back a few feet to the intersection and turn left on Custer Street. At the end of Custer Street (three blocks) you’ll be facing the Arboretum. Turn right and proceed to the pedestrian crossing. After the crossing, turn right. The Arboretum’s main gate will be 10 yards ahead, on the left.

Car

Parking is available outside the main gate, along the Arborway, and around the Arboretum’s perimeter.

More parking information.
results.how_to_find_us: Hunnewell Building at the Main Entrance Gate located at 125 Arborway, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130

Sign-up link for the webinar is here: https://www.innerengineering.com/online/webinars?signinsrc=Meetup-NewEngland

***REGISTRATION closes 45 minutes prior to the webcast.***  Please make sure you sign-up on our website at least 45 mins prior to the webcast to receive your live log-in link via email.


(Technical Support: <a>[masked]</a>)


The Inner Engineering online program includes guided meditations, powerful breathing techniques, and deeply engaging discourses about the nature of the mind and practical wisdom to manage life’s situations.

Inner Engineering is a combination of methods derived from the ancient science of yoga that addresses every aspect of human well-being — from your body, mind and emotions to the essential life energy within.

This 1 hour introduction to Inner Engineering explains the fundamental approach of the program in a live setting that offers you the opportunity to ask a trained Isha teacher questions about the program and practices available.

“Inner Engineering is neither a religion, nor a philosophy or dogma; It is a technology for wellbeing. One does not have to believe or disbelieve, you just have to learn to use it. Technology will produce results irrespective of who you are.” – Sadhguru
results.name: An Introduction to Inner Engineering--FREE Class (Online Webinar)

Donations for the workshops are accepted-$5.00


The Gaelic Club begins at 3:30 until 7:00.   During this time, musicians usually play Celtic music on the fiddle, piano, and guitar.  Other instruments are welcomed as well.  Dancers may get up and do a step dance or a square set.  In addition, you may hear a few Gaelic tunes or Scottish songs.

The cost is $7.00.  Bring a dish to share.

results.name: Sunday Meetup

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

WHAT: ASL Weekly Social
WHEN: EVERY SUNDAY 
TIME: 4:00-6:00PM
WHO: ANYONE is welcome to come by and have a conversation in ASL
WHY: To socialize, have fun, and enjoy chatting in ASL
WHERE: Tavern in the Square in Porter Square

NOTE: Every once a while, the location may change. PLEASE look on the website each week for confirmation. THANKS!


To get to the Meetup, take the RED LINE stop OUTBOUND TO ALEWIFE, and stop at PORTER SQ. Look down the street. There's Tavern in the Square! If you're driving, you can park on the street for free on Sundays!

Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

Don't be afraid or shy if you're not "perfect" at ASL, because being "perfect" is not the point of this group. No one expects that everyone will be at the same level, and none of us mind slowing down or repeating what we have signed so that everyone understands.

We all laugh WITH one another as we fumble along, mess things up, and start over again. This isn't an ASL class, since none of us are certified ASL teachers, so there's really no pressure or expectation--other than that we all use ASL to communicate. We all learn from one another!

IF you've taken an ASL/Sign Language class before (or have had exposure to someone who uses the language) and know the basics (alphabet, numbers 1-20, and even a small vocabulary of signs ), then join us to get your fingers, hands, face and body moving, ASL-style!

IF you haven't taken an ASL class, or don't know the basics, don't be discouraged ... you can come along anyway and learn by watching, and gradually, participating. We have lots of resources that we can suggest for learning ASL from a qualified teacher or authentic source, such as books, online classes, and local classes at various locations near Boston.

If you can, "officially" RSVP, even if the RSVP is "No," so that we know who is definitely going to come.

It will be great to see folks!

Erika and Jack
results.how_to_find_us: We will be there signing our beautiful language to inspire all of you!
results.name: ASL WEEKLY SOCIAL

results.description:
Win, lose or draw, we know how to party at Causeway! Mad props to the great crew of fans last week who stood tall during that gut punch loss to the Browns. 

We suit up again this Sunday for a 4:25 PM kickoff against the 49ers.  Remember: Ravens Central is on the SECOND FLOOR!

Our friends from Baltimore-based Heavy Seas Beer will be bringing the party to us this weekend with souvenir glasses and other giveaways.  Get there early to get in on the free stuff!


Getting to Causeway: 

Driving is doable. Update: the lot behind the building is sometimes $10 and sometimes $25 with no explanation for the sporadic rate hikes. We've tried unsuccessfully to get info out of them. It's still worth checking before trying other options.  On-street parking can be found near the bar with a little searching. Check nearby Nashua St. too. 

Taking the T - We are just a block from North Station where Orange and Green lines arrive. For the Red line, transfer at Park St. and go 3 stops to North Station or get off at MGH and walk 5-10 minutes to us. 

From the suburbs - Try the commuter rail. Lines from the west and north go directly to us (North Station). South Station arrivals are about a mile south of us, or a quick cab/uber ride. First time uber riders use code P6E94 for a discount!

Using I-93. Try getting off at the new Assembly Row T station in Somerville. Lots of parking, just off highway, and only 6-7 minute T ride to us. Not a bad option regardless of what direction you're coming from.

Go Pack,

Ray Butler

results.description:
Let's join five other walking groups and 20+ walkers for this walk.  Walk is on, Rain or Shine.

Few things are more enjoyable than a nice walk and a chat at the end of a busy weekend.

Since May 2012, we've met with a few other meetup groups Let's join for a stroll in a beautiful setting.

We walk clockwise, so if you get there late, just start walking counter-clockwise and you'll run into us.

Parking on Huron Avenue is easy, since the "Permit Parking" rules don't apply on Sunday - just park in any spot on Huron Ave, there will be plenty of them.

If you're coming by bus, take the 71 or 73 bus from Harvard Square and get off at Aberdeen Ave. Walk all the way up Aberdeen until you come to Huron Avenue, we'll be there.

Afterwards, we'll go out for dinner. We usually go for some unusual Chinese food, and the total cost is about $10 per person.

If you have trouble finding us, call me at[masked]
results.name: Large,Multigroup Weekly Walk around Fresh Pond,dinner @ Shangri-La :10/18@5:00pm

group.name: Boston Late Risers Hiking/Walking/Biking Social Meetup

results.description:
For the 180th consecutive Sunday, we will be walking.   Let's join 20 or so others from other walking groups for this walk.

The walk is on, rain or shine.

Since May 2012, there has been a regular walk around Fresh Pond at about an hour before sunset. Frequently, 20-25 walkers turn out for this walk, and you can too. There are a whole bunch of regulars, along with some new people.


Frequently, if we eat too much food, we'll go for another walk.

Come see why this walk is so popular. It's at a great time, the people are friendly, the parking is free -- no permit parking in Cambridge on Sunday, so you can park on Huron or Aberdeen Ave.

You can get there by T easily from Harvard Square, take the 71 OR 73 bus to Aberdeen Ave, then walk to the other end of Aberdeen Ave, and you'll see us there.

If you're late, and we've already started, start walking counter-clockwise. We'll be walking clockwise, so we'll surely bump into each other. We're the large group of vigorously chatting walkers.

Hope to see you there.

We'll all go out for dinner afterwards, somewhere in the neighborhood.
results.name: Large,Multigroup Weekly Walk around Fresh Pond,dinner @ Shangri-La :10/18@5:00pm

For this intensive, we will be at Pandemonium in Central Square! Pandemonium is located at 4 Pleasant Street, Cambridge, MA 02139, and we will be at a table in the basement; call[masked] if you have difficulty finding us. Come join us and help improve this fine game!

results.description:
Join other single professionals for an early evening happy hour, topped off with about* 7-10 rounds of "mini-dates." You'll meet each member of the opposite sex for 5-7 minutes each (depending on the size of the event), turn in your dating card and then we'll send you the contact info of your mutual matches 48 hours later. On average, 80% of those who attend end up with at least one or two mutual matches.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

PAYMENT POLICY:
$24 (MUST register with code ATWYS- codes can not be applied after registration)

REGISTER AND PAY HERE: 

https://2015bostonatwysspeeddating.eventbrite.com

(SEE MORE FAQ's BELOW)

ABSOLUTELY NO REFUNDS FOR LAST MINUTE/DAY OF CANCELLATIONS. NO EXCEPTIONS.

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~


FAST FACTS - PLEASE READ:

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

*We can not accept payment at the door for these events. All registrations must be done online via the Eventbrite link below before the event. No exceptions.

*RSVPing through meetup does not guarantee admission. You must pre-pay to secure your spot in the event.

*Business casual attire requested. No sneakers, t-shirts or active wear, no ripped jeans.

*We limit our events to 12 couples/24 people. (See reason below)

*You will have approximately 8-12 dates.*

*Matches are tabulated and emailed to attendees 48 hours after the event.

*Event lasts about 90 minutes give or take 10 minutes between check-in and all speeddating rounds. Speed rounds last 5 minutes each.

*You must register with a valid, correct email address.

*There are no refunds for cancellations, late arrivals or no-shows.

*You must arrive and check in within 20 minutes of the advertised start time.

OUR METHOD:

Online dating is great. But how many times have you chatted with someone just to have them fade or never make plans to meet? How many dates have you had that you thought went well and then ended up confused because you never heard from that person again?

The upside of online dating is that it provides us with so many options. The downside is that people start to believe that their options are endless, which leads them to move on quickly seeking that "perfect" match.

This is where speeddating comes in. To try and combat the "shopping cart" mentality of online dating, we limit the number of attendees to 10-12 per gender.  Fewer choices to distract us means that people are more likely to make a connection. Face to face conversations result in fewer flakes. That means fewer people get put on the back burner.


FAQ'S

The Organizer RSVPD with X amount of people. What does that mean?

That number represents the RSVPS (not registrations) that have come in through our other pages listed below. It is NOT the total number of people pre-paid. The typical number of people per event is 16-20.

What should I wear?

Business casual attire is perfect. No sneakers or athletic wear, please.

What if I want to give someone my contact info at the event?

Go for it! That's the whole point. Do whatever you are comfortable doing.

Can I see photos of other attendees?

Most people do not RSVP on meetup for privacy reasons. They only pre-pay and therefore do not share their photo.

Where are all the RSVPs?

About 50% of the registrations come through Eventbrite and our main events website. They are not Meetup members. Many people prefer not to post their Meetup profile or photo for privacy reasons. We often remove the event from the calendar once it has started so that people can't contact attendees without the attendee's expressed permission.

What's The Refund Policy?

Since we need to try and ensure a gender ratio as close to even as possible, our policy is that all registrations are final. We can not offer refunds or transfers to last minute cancellations. However, if you notify us at least 3 days in advance, we can give you a credit to another event.

Can I bring a friend for moral support?

You'd be surprised how many people arrive alone. We actually prefer that guests do not bring friends or "spectators." It makes the other attendees uncomfortable. Fun fact: The people who sign up and arrive alone tend to get more matches than those who attend with friends.

Will there be equal numbers of men or women?

That's the goal. We constantly monitor registrations and amp up promotion to try and ensure and equal gender ration. Sometimes there's 1 or 2 more men or women. Sometimes it's even numbers. This is heavily dependent on the age range and weather. We will NOT host an event if there isn't AT LEAST 7 of each gender registered, and we will NOT let there be an excessive (more than 3) amount of one gender versus the other.

PLEASE REMEMBER:
* We run 3-5 Meetup Groups, plus maintain our own outside Dating Advice & Events Website. We advertise on Facebook, Twitter, Blogs, etc. Most registrations come through our outside events website, not Meetup. Therefore the number of RSVPs reflected here are NOT the total number of men or women registered.

*This is not a guaranteed number of dates.

See other RSVPS posted on our other groups. Please note that many people opt NOT to RSVP through Meetup for privacy reasons.

Caller: Marcie Van Cleave
Music: Audrey Knuth and friends

https://www.facebook.com/events/1624502557830182/ Dance 7:30-10:30pm

Bring someone new to Contra to the intro session and you both get passes for free admission to a future dance! Share the love. Public Transportation (recommended): We are across the street from the Porter Square Red Line stop.

Parking: Free street parking (meters and residential are open to all on Sundays). Don't park in the Shaw's parking lot because they tow.

See you there!

results.description:
So, the title is meant literal: I challenge you to capture the Zodiacal Light, as I have never done so. Images need to be taken during this event period, old photos don't count. Are you a morning person? Good, the best time to do this is 12-24 October before dawn.

Zodiacal light is a faint, roughly triangular, diffuse white glow seen in the night sky that appears to extend up from the vicinity of the sun along the ecliptic (the apparent path that the sun takes across our sky). It is best seen just after sunset in spring, and just before sunrise in autumn, when the zodiac is at a steep angle to the horizon. Caused by sunlight scattered by space dust </a>in the zodiacal cloud, it is so faint that either moonlight or light pollution renders it invisible. That means: shooting over the ocean on the beach gets you best results, but you will need a clear night without much marine layer fog.


In the northern hemisphere, the light appears as a faint cone of light above the eastern horizon before sunrise (or the western horizon in spring). Its light intensity is greater than the Milky Way. Typically, the light is colorless, but in rare circumstances it can have blue, green, yellow, or red hues. If the conditions are right, it is easy to see the zodiacal light, but because it is so faint and occurs near the horizon, most viewers think they are seeing twilight or the light from a distant town (both of which we eliminate by shooting before civil twilight and over the ocean). It is best seen when the sun is between 18 and 12 degrees below the horizon, that means during nautical twilight.


The best time then is 5:30 to 6:30 a.m. during the period 12-24 October, after that it gets too bright (sunrise is around 7, in case you want to capture, that, too). Even though the light can be seen well in general in October and November, the moon will be out of the way only during that period of 12-24 Oct (and again 11-23 November). If you have PhotoPills (iToy) or PlanIt! (Android), these apps can show you exactly where the sun would come up, that is where you have to point your camera - typically due East (90°) to about 100°.


<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiacal_light">Here is more info about it on Wikipedia

and

some examples on Google

.

Shooting settings are the same as for star points or Milky Way: wide open aperture (f/2.8 or wider), maximum exposure time in seconds is determined as 400/focal length in mm (300/FL for cropped sensor cameras) and ISO between 1600 and 3200 (6400 is usually too noisy and diminishes the beauty of the faint light). Compose to have something interesting in your foreground, could be silhouettes, as long as it is not a plain straight beach. Try some dunes, or if you plan to go into the mountains, that works, too.


Useless trivia: Brian May, guitarist of the rock band Queen moonlighted (!) as a scientist and completed a PhD thesis on A Survey of Radial Velocities in the Zodiacal Dust Cloud.


Post pictures here as you get them.
results.how_to_find_us: This is not a group event, it is an individual challenge
results.name: Challenge: Capture the Zodiacal Light

venue.name: The Meetup Web Site -time to pay the Meetup fee

results.description:
This is a friendly monthly reminder to contribute $11 yearly to help us pay off the yearly Meetup Group fee and additional cost to run the group and keep the group going. This is more for member's information and is not meant to sound that I am angry. Also, note that  Biagio is NOT getting rich from the group fees.  This is a YEARLY fee and NOT a monthly fee.

I wanted to address any crazy rumors and incorrect assumptions that I am getting rich from Meetup. These assumptions are based on having ALL 9,000 members paying the $10 a member fee which would equal $90,000, but that is 100% incorrect. I am not making $90,000 a year for this group!

So please let me clarify less than 1% of the group’ members actually pay the $11 yearly Voluntarily Donation. Out of that $11 PayPal take their cut so I only get  $10 per member. I barley take in $200 a year and that is NOT enough cover the yearly Meetup fees and the other Meetup expense like printing out Meetup materials, supplies for the group, batteries, games, Meetup business cards, etc. Over the past 6 years I've acquired over $2000 of debt to run this group and cover Meetup expenses. So it is time to understand the truth and stop making assumption.

Biagio is pretty Poor and Not rich. Luckily, there hasn’t yet been a need for me to start to begging for money on the side of the street……….. yet!

I am now paying Meetup a $200  fee  every year to run the group. In 2015 we have only collected $150 from members for the Meetup Group Fee so far, and we have not paid off the 2014 debt which is over $500 now. If we cannot get members to pay off the 2014 and 2015 debt  then I’m just going to let the group shut down due to lack of  funding when the 2016 payment is due.

Don’t forget,  I pay for batteries, supplies,  printouts,  signs, games, stands  etc. etc. to run this group its over $700 a year,  which includes the $200 a year Meetup fee!

So please be informed and realize what it takes to run a group this large. Oh and add to that I spend 30+ hours every week of my own time running the group which I get paid $0 for.

Please help keep the group going. Don’t let not giving $11 a year, every year stop all the fun. Oh and you don’t have to pay the $11 online you can pay the $10 in person or e-mail me to pay by check.

If you want to pay online Meetup has shut down the Amazon payment feature so you can now pay using Paypal and pay $11 to my PayPal account using e-mail address which is [masked]

</a>

<a href="mailto:[masked]">===================================

With PayPal, you can send money to anyone with an email address.

Here’s how to send money:

Log in to your PayPal account.


Click Send money to a friend at the top of the page.

Type the email address or mobile number to whom you are sending money, and the amount being sent. In this case its [masked]

Click Next.  

Review and confirm the information on the screen and click Send.

=======================================

Thanks and let’s keep the fun gong!

Biagio

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

results.description:
October 19th we will host our second speaker event at the amazing Microsoft NERD Center.  Join us for a cash bar, pizza, networking and 2 great speakers.


To get into the NERD space, show a photo ID at the front door and ask for directions to the Commons room.

Christopher Burge of MIT will be discussing his work on computational biology of gene expression "Distal alternative last exons localize mRNAs to neural projections" and Jonathan Dry of AstraZeneca will be providing some insight on how to get you CV noticed "How to see you in your CV"

Thank you to our sponsors Bina Technologies and Insight Health Data Science for making this night possible.


Agenda:

• 5:30 - 6:10: Networking, pizza, and cash bar.

• 6:10-6:15: Opening remarks

• 6:15-6:45: Distal alternative last exons localize mRNAs to neural projections: Dr. Christopher Burge, Professor of Biology and Biological Engineering, and Director, Computational and Systems Biology PhD Program, MIT.

• 6:45-7:15: How to see you in your CV: Jonathan Dry, Principal Scientist II, AstraZeneca.


• 7:15-9:00: Networking and cash bar (note: the bar closes at 8:30). 

Bina Technologies builds next-generation technologies for scalable, accurate processing and management of genomic information. Bina’s Genomic Management Solution is a comprehensive analysis platform used by clinical and translational researchers to gain insight from their genomic data sets. Bina’s Genomic Management Solution dramatically decreases the complexity, time, and cost of genomic analysis, accelerating the science of personalized medicine. Bina Technologies was acquired by Roche in December 2014. Learn more about Bina’s product, technologies, and team at www.bina.com

Insight Health Data Science Fellows Program www.insighthealthdata.com is an intensive, seven week postdoctoral training fellowship that bridges the gap between academic research and a career in health data science. Based in Boston, the program enables scientists to learn the industry-specific skills needed to work in the growing field of big data at leading healthcare organizations.

Are you a PhD candidate, postdoctoral researcher, or medical doctor looking to transition into a career in industry? Do you want a career that truly leverages your quantitative experience in a fast-growing, in-demand field that is making a positive impact in the world? 

Top companies in many fields are hiring health data scientists to help them glean insights from the terabytes of data that they collect everyday. While the amount of data produced and stored is growing exponentially, there is a severe shortage of talent to analyze this data and extract valuable insights from it.

The Insight Health Data Science Fellows Program is a postdoctoral training fellowship that bridges the gap between academia and health data science. Insight is a seven week, intensive program that teaches researchers how to apply their existing analytical skills to big data. The program consists of a projectbased, industry-driven learning approach designed to train academics in many of the cutting edge data science tools and healthcare practices used in industry. Immediately following the program, Fellows interview at leading organizations in Boston and the surrounding area, where they are likely to receive multiple job offers.

Insight in a nutshell:

7 week, full-time, postdoctoral health data science training fellowship in Boston. Full tuition scholarship for all Fellows. Self-directed, project-based learning (no classes!) under the guidance of top industry health data scientists. A group of smart people who are excited about working on interesting problems while having a positive impact. Interview at top companies and organizations immediately following the program.
results.name: BCBB October Speaker Event

results.description:
Here is the book selected to discuss at the Oct meeting._Thanks Susan S.

The Circle by Dave Eggers The Circle

When Mae Holland is hired to work for the Circle, the world’s most powerful internet company, she feels she’s been given the opportunity of a lifetime. The Circle, run out of a sprawling California campus, links users’ personal emails, social media, banking, and purchasing with their universal operating system, resulting in one online identity and a new age of civility and When Mae Holland is hired to work for the Circle, the world’s most powerful internet company, she feels she’s been given the opportunity of a lifetime. The Circle, run out of a sprawling California campus, links users’ personal emails, social media, banking, and purchasing with their universal operating system, resulting in one online identity and a new age of civility and transparency. As Mae tours the open-plan office spaces, the towering glass dining facilities, the cozy dorms for those who spend nights at work, she is thrilled with the company’s modernity and activity. There are parties that last through the night, there are famous musicians playing on the lawn, there are athletic activities and clubs and brunches, and even an aquarium of rare fish retrieved from the Marianas Trench by the CEO. Mae can’t believe her luck, her great fortune to work for the most influential company in America--even as life beyond the campus grows distant, even as a strange encounter with a colleague leaves her shaken, even as her role at the Circle becomes increasingly public. What begins as the captivating story of one woman’s ambition and idealism soon becomes a heart-racing novel of suspense, raising questions about memory, history, privacy, democracy, and the limits of human knowledge.

WE ARE BACK IN DAVIS SQUARE FOR TONIGHT, PLEASE TAKE NOTE OF THIS.

6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

6:45 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

results.description:
Schedule


* 6:00 - 6:30: Mingling. Food and drink are provided.
* 6:30 - 6:45: Opening remarks and sponsor pitch.
* 6:45 - 6:50: Lightning Talk
* 6:50 - 7:30: Feature Talk 

Lightning Talk: "Flintrock: A faster, better spark-ec2" - Nicholas Chammas

spark-ec2 is a handy little tool for spinning up Spark clusters on EC2, but it has a few frustrating problems that are difficult to solve within its current architecture. In this lightning talk, Nick will give a very quick overview of a project he is working on which reimagines what spark-ec2 might look like if it were rewritten from scratch.

Feature Talk: "Counting with Apache Spark and Algebird" - Edward Sumitra, Curriculum Associates

Many Big-Data computations involve counting different types of data. The open-source Algebird library from Twitter enables easily structuring computations as "counting" problems that can be parallelized and executed on map-reduce frameworks like Spark. The talk will briefly cover the properties of abstract algebraic types like semigroups, monoids and rings and how to leverage their properties using Algebird and Spark in counting problems. The talk will demonstrate the use of these abstract algebraic types in implementations of standard Big Data probabilistic counting algorithms like Count-Min-Sketch (top-K items) and Hyper-Log-Log (unique items) in Algebird and Spark.

results.description:
Do you have a family member or friend who wants to get in shape but doesn't know how to start? Help get them walking or jogging.

We have 2 groups:

Our Walking Group will exercise and encourage one another towards walking a 5K. 

Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.

Using CoolRunning.com’s Couch To 5K program we introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 8-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles).

•  Anyone from the community can participate. 


• Led by experienced runners.

results.description:
This is a 4 week course. If you RSVP for this date you are RSVPing for the complete 4 week course (Monday evenings beginning October 19 through November 9). Please only RSVP if you are committed to attending to the whole series.


This course introduces students to the basic principles of 3D modeling, such as how to navigate in 3D space, what 3D models are made out of, and how to create simple forms and objects. The software used will be Sketchup, a free program that is excellent for beginners and professionals alike. Students will learn the ins and outs of the program, from basic techniques to advanced modeling concepts. This series is for people who have not already taken a 3D modeling class at HATCH.


Requirements:


• A free copy of Sketchup. 

• A CAD-capable laptop or desktop. The computer must have a discrete graphics chip or a very new (last three years) onboard graphics chip.


• A three button (minimum) mouse.


• You must be an experienced Windows or Mac user.


• You should be able to utilize keyboard shortcuts and understand how to use computer file systems.


*If you need a laptop please contact the organizer, we have six laptops available for use. We prefer that you use your own for this class.*

If you are bringing your own computer, please pre-load Sketchup Make. You can download it from www.sketchup.com.
results.how_to_find_us: We're located in the Arsenal Project (formerly Arsenal Mall). Park in the lot near Old Navy entrance, you'll see a big yellow-green sign over the doors. HATCH is between Pearle Vision and Game Stop.
results.name: Introduction to 3D Modeling (4 week class)

results.description:
Climbing MeetUp at MetroRock Gym in Everett. Toprope, sport leading, and bouldering available, including some tall walls up to 55 feet. Whether you're a new or experienced climber, join us for a fun and solid workout! We usually have people at all levels. Gym meetups are also a great way to make more friends for outdoor climbing. Plus Mondays are Ladies' Night: discounted admission. If you'd like to lead climb, don't forget to bring your rope :)

*** If you are new to MetroRock Gym and/or climbing, please see the FAQ below. ***

Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (the one furthest from the cubbies if available) from 7 - 7:10 PM.  (NOTE: In the rare case the Event Host doesn't arrive within this time window, assume major traffic jam or other catastrophy, ask others nearby to find the group, make introductions, and go climb).  If arriving later, just come find us on the walls.  Hopefully you can recognize us, the Event Host(s) (see RSVP list), from our profile pictures, and/or check the small Whiteboard near the bathrooms and water fountain, for a description of what we're wearing that day.

Full-access Day Pass:  $22.  Students, Military or Bouldering-Only Pass:  $18.  Mondays are Ladies Night:  Women's Pass $14 after 3 PM & also special class pricing.

For membership, gear rentals, and other programs and pricing available, or for directions, check the gym website:  http://www.metrorock.com/

Frequently Asked Questions for Newbies:

Q) How do I get to the gym?

A) See website for directions: http://www.metrorock.com/ If you're driving here for the first time, it can be tricky to find MetroRock Everett, especially in the dark! Use a GPS if possible. MetroRock is in a building opposite Boston Coach.   If you don't have a vehicle, the gym offers a shuttle service from nearby Wellington T Station; call the gym for schedule details.

Q) I've never climbed at MetroRock Gym before, what do I need to do?

A) You'll need to take and pass a belay test for rope climbing. There is a separate test for toproping and sport lead climbing. For toproping, if you are not confident you can tie a re-threaded figure-8 knot and double fisherman's backup knot and safely belay a climber using an ATC device, it is highly recommended you take the Level 1 Safety class. They will not allow you to climb on ropes without passing a belay test. Call MetroRock in advance to reserve your spot in the class, and ask them about any discounts or special prices they are offering. Also, you can rent basic climbing gear (harness, shoes, belay device, etc), if needed, at the gym.
results.how_to_find_us: Meet at the picnic table near bouldering area (the one furthest from cubbies if available; usually the round table).

results.description:
Welcome back from a busy summer! Hope everyone had some time to relax and enjoy all the sun. With MongoDB in town for September, our first regular meetup will be in October.

We're still looking for speakers so give a shout if you have an interesting topic!


Tentative Agenda:

6:30-7pm: Networking!
7pm: "The Modulestore: Storing edX Courses in MongoDB" by John Eskew

John Eskew is a software developer on the Core Platform Team at edX. Using MongoDB, they've created the concept of a "modulestore" which stores all the course modules using a particular schema. The initial modulestore stored each module as a document and supported two branches per course - a draft and published branch. The newest implementation supports multiple branches, keeps all past course revisions, and has a different schema designed with our typical query patterns in mind. The edX platform also stores course asset BLOBs in MongoDB via GridFS.
results.name: October Meetup - edX Use Case and ??

results.description:
Car Wars game information below... but first, the open gaming announcement:

Other Games:

We are limiting the Car Wars players to 8 due to table size and to keep the turns moving along fairly fast.  However, the game room will be open for other games and you are welcome to schedule a side event (same day, same location - work it out with Randy or myself and we will schedule the other event.

Car Wars

Sometimes we get nostalgic about old games and want to bring them back to the table one more time - in a way that pays homage to the many hours of youth spent playing them.

Beginners welcome, we will teach the rules.  If you want to review them ahead of time you can either browse my copy here or get one from SJG - Car Wars Compendium.  


We will use 3" x 1" sized card templates (bring a hot wheels/match box sized car if you like a particular one or you can use one of ours).  We will also play on the 7' x 4' table, using the now old Car Wars fourth edition rules (Car Wars compendium).  We will triple all measurements (1" on the rules becomes 3", 1/4" becomes 3/4" and so on).  Counters and turning keys have been printed in 3x size.  Feel free to bring your own or use ours.  CWSpark has very good printable files.

You can design your own car at the link below (Cars only, no bikes, trikes or anything else):  http://carwars.opentools.org/  Use Car Wars Compendium pricing (CWC).  I suggest you prepare cars at the 5k, 7.5k, 10k, 12.5k and 15k.  You can also use some of the ones we will have prepared.  Yes, I am aware that design tool produces a 3D model of the cars - cars don't come out as good as the commercial ones.

We will play between 2 to 4 games in the night, depending on how fast they go.  Winner of one round gets their choice of $500 extra vehicular build price or +1 to their Handling Class.  Handling Class is big in this game as it prevents cars from spinning over and crashing in the wildest way.

The games will be escalating in car composition.  First round will be a 5k build price, then 7.5k build price and increasing 2.5k each round thereafter.


Still deciding on game format (free-for-all - last car standing, teams, or somewhere in between).  (The somewhere in between I am thinking is that you secretly declare your target, and then score as follows: your car survives = 10 pts, for each car you disabled 3pts, for disabling your mark bonus 3pts. or something similar.)  Disabling meaning that the opponent car can no longer move or shoot.  Vitas also has some ideas for scenarios that we can introduce.

Sample Cars You Can Use:

• Princeton Games - have cars in several popular divisions.


• AADA Vehicle Guide (Steve Jackson Games) - The official books.  Nominal cost for the PDF.


• If you find any interesting sources, please enter them on the comments.  If you build any interesting cars, please put them on the comments.

Update from October 15:

The Turning Keys and the counters are ready.  And if you bring your own car (hot wheels or matchbox size) you can mount it on one of the acrylic bases that I just cut.  See pictures below.  Will post pictures of the 3D Arena in the next couple of days.

More details to follow.  Invite nostalgic friends to the event and to the meetup.

results.description:
Join us for an introduction to this unique Japanese martial art. Participants will all get a chance to practice some basic movements, explore a bit of the underpinning philosophy, and experience seated meditation. In short, we will have fun together learning about this martial way, one unknown to many in the United States. 

Shorinji Kempo is a relatively new martial art. It was founded just after WWII as part of a Zen Buddhist practice. Today, while the martial art has been separated from the religion, the practice of Shorinji Kempo remains true to it's Zen Buddhist roots, with philosophy and meditation still integral to the study in the dojo of hard (punches, kicks and blocks) and soft techniques (releases, joint locks and throws).
results.name: Boston Shorinji Kempo Open Dojo Event

results.description:
Science and Cooking returns! - A semester-long public lecture series that pairs Harvard University professors with popular chefs and food experts to showcase the science behind different cooking techniques. This lecture series is sponsored by the Harvard University John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences. 

Full schedule below and HERE. Free and open to the public. 

:: :: ::

Lecture 6) Monday, Oct. 19 - Heat Transfer to Capture Flavors - Josep Roca, (@CanRocaCeller), El Celler de Can Roca and Raül Sillero, El Celler de Can Roca

:: :: ::

These public lectures are based on the Harvard course “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” but do not replicate course content. Unless otherwise noted, all talks take place in the Harvard Science Center (1 Oxford St., Cambridge, Mass., Hall C) and begin at 7 p.m. Each presentation begins with a 15-minute lecture by a faculty member from the Harvard course, who will discuss one of the scientific topics from that week’s classSeating for all lectures is first come, first seated. If you have questions regarding this public lecture series, please contact [masked]. 

:: :: ::

Sample Lecture: Explorations of Chocolate Textures [Lecture 4 (2012)]

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tt9g2se1LcM&index=10&list=PL546CD09EA2399DAB


 Full schedule

Lecture 1) Monday, Sept. 7 - Thinking about Flavor - Dave Arnold (@CookingIssues), Booker & Dax, and host of “Cooking Issues” and Harold McGee (@Harold_McGee), writer, “Curious Cook”


Lecture 2) Monday, Sept. 14 - Pasta Magic - Mark Ladner, (@ChefMarkLadner), Del Posto

Lecture 3) Monday, Sept. 21 - The Science of Sugar - Joanne Chang ’91, (@jbchang), Flour Bakery, author of “Flour” and “Flour Too”

Lecture 4) Monday, Sept. 28 - Title TBA* - *Jim Lahey, (@jimlaheySSB), Sullivan Street Bakery

Lecture 5) Monday, Oct. 12 - Science and Emotions: Delicious or Disgusting? - Andoni Aduriz, (@mugaritz), Mugaritz and Ramon Perisé, Mugaritz

Lecture 6) Monday, Oct. 19 - Heat Transfer to Capture Flavors - Josep Roca, (@CanRocaCeller), El Celler de Can Roca and Raül Sillero, El Celler de Can Roca

Lecture 7) <Location TBA> Tuesday, Oct. 27 - Viscosity and Polymers - José Andrés, (@chefjoseandres), ThinkFoodGroup

Lecture 8) Monday, Nov. 2 - Title TBA - Bryan Voltaggio, (@BryanVoltaggio), Volt*Michael Voltaggio, (@MVoltaggio), Ink

Lecture 9) Monday, Nov. 16 - Fermentation on Wheels: Food Education and Community Impact - Tara Whitsitt, (@tarawhitsitt), Fermentation on Wheels

Lecture 10) Monday, Nov. 23 - Title TBA - Nathan Myhrvold, (@ModernCuisine), former Chief Technology Officer of Microsoft, co-founder of Intellectual Ventures, author of “Modernist Cuisine”

Lecture 11) Monday, Dec. 7 - Title TBA - Tom Colicchio, (@tomcolicchio), “Top Chef” judge and chef/owner, Craft Hospitality, and Mei Lin, (@meilin21), “Top Chef” season 12 winner, and Gail Simmons, (@gailsimmons), “Top Chef” judge, Culinary expert, and Food & Wine magazine Special Projects Director

:: :: ::

The Harvard College Course: The Harvard John A. Paulson School of Engineering and Applied Sciences (SEAS) and the Alícia Foundation developed a General Education science course, “Science and Cooking: From Haute Cuisine to the Science of Soft Matter,” which debuted in the fall of 2010. The course uses food and cooking to explicate fundamental principles in applied physics and engineering. (Watch a video about the course.) Limited to currently enrolled Harvard undergraduates, the class brings together eminent Harvard researchers and world-class chefs. 

:: :: ::

A version of “Science and Cooking” is offered for credit through the Harvard Extension School. An online course will be offered in the fall and spring semesters. Registered students will have access to the expertise and support of Harvard teaching staff.

:: :: ::

For more info visit <a>www.seas.harvard.edu.</a>

Contact: [masked].

results.description:
All children are born artists, but we get educated out of being creative. There is a hierarchy of subjects in schools which puts creativity at the bottom. Academia has transformed education in its own image.

We have to rethink what 'intelligence' is. It is dynamic, an interaction between disciplines that, if not recognized will turn us all into mindless robots.

In this TED talk: Do Schools Kill Creativity, Sir Ken Robinson makes an entertaining and profoundly moving case for creating an education system that nurtures (rather than undermines) creativity.

Before the 19th century, education reflected all of humankind's varied capacities. With the advent of industrialism, subjects that were useful for work were given preferred status, until the concept of 'intelligence' became so narrowly defined that it only covered a small spectrum of ability.

In this second TED talk: How to escape education's death valley, Sir Ken Robinson outlines 3 principles crucial for the human mind to flourish — and how current education culture works against them. In a funny, stirring talk he tells us how to get out of the educational "death valley" we now face, and how to nurture our youngest generations with a climate of possibility.

The 3 principles he enumerates are, that children have various talents, have inborn curiosity, and that human life is inherently creative.

We need a revolution in education! Please bring your ideas, experiences and opinions.
results.name: Do Schools Kill Creativity?

Isha Kriya Guided Meditation-

A lot of people find it really difficult to calm the mind and settle the body for meditation when they first try it. Too many people get frustrated and give up on meditation before they can experience its many benefits.

These 1-hour guided sessions offer a simple, but powerful kriya practice that aligns your mind, body, and inner-energies to easily and naturally become meditative. Once meditative, your experience of the life within you and the world around you becomes much deeper and richer. Daily activity becomes effortless and joyful. 

You can easily learn this 12-to-18 minute Isha Kriya process in one session and practice on your own, or return to class to ask questions and deepen the experience with the group. Benefits of regular practice include improving health, energy and vitality; enhancing mental focus, memory and clarity; reducing stress and establishing a deep sense of peace and inner balance.

Isha Kriya is a gentle, seated practice, which can be practiced in a chair. No previous meditation experience is necessary.

The Isha Kriya process was developed by realized yogi, Sadhguru Vasudev. Sadhguru is renowned for his powerful yoga and meditation programs, as well as thriving humanitarian initiatives. He has been hosted to speak and offer meditations at numerous global leadership forums, businesses and universities, including the United Nations, the World Economic Forum, the British House of Lords, TED, MIT, and the World Peace Congress.

results.description:
So, the title is meant literal: I challenge you to capture the Zodiacal Light, as I have never done so. Images need to be taken during this event period, old photos don't count. Are you a morning person? Good, the best time to do this is 12-24 October before dawn.

Zodiacal light is a faint, roughly triangular, diffuse white glow seen in the night sky that appears to extend up from the vicinity of the sun along the ecliptic (the apparent path that the sun takes across our sky). It is best seen just after sunset in spring, and just before sunrise in autumn, when the zodiac is at a steep angle to the horizon. Caused by sunlight scattered by space dust </a>in the zodiacal cloud, it is so faint that either moonlight or light pollution renders it invisible. That means: shooting over the ocean on the beach gets you best results, but you will need a clear night without much marine layer fog.


In the northern hemisphere, the light appears as a faint cone of light above the eastern horizon before sunrise (or the western horizon in spring). Its light intensity is greater than the Milky Way. Typically, the light is colorless, but in rare circumstances it can have blue, green, yellow, or red hues. If the conditions are right, it is easy to see the zodiacal light, but because it is so faint and occurs near the horizon, most viewers think they are seeing twilight or the light from a distant town (both of which we eliminate by shooting before civil twilight and over the ocean). It is best seen when the sun is between 18 and 12 degrees below the horizon, that means during nautical twilight.


The best time then is 5:30 to 6:30 a.m. during the period 12-24 October, after that it gets too bright (sunrise is around 7, in case you want to capture, that, too). Even though the light can be seen well in general in October and November, the moon will be out of the way only during that period of 12-24 Oct (and again 11-23 November). If you have PhotoPills (iToy) or PlanIt! (Android), these apps can show you exactly where the sun would come up, that is where you have to point your camera - typically due East (90°) to about 100°.


<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiacal_light">Here is more info about it on Wikipedia

and

some examples on Google

.

Shooting settings are the same as for star points or Milky Way: wide open aperture (f/2.8 or wider), maximum exposure time in seconds is determined as 400/focal length in mm (300/FL for cropped sensor cameras) and ISO between 1600 and 3200 (6400 is usually too noisy and diminishes the beauty of the faint light). Compose to have something interesting in your foreground, could be silhouettes, as long as it is not a plain straight beach. Try some dunes, or if you plan to go into the mountains, that works, too.


Useless trivia: Brian May, guitarist of the rock band Queen moonlighted (!) as a scientist and completed a PhD thesis on A Survey of Radial Velocities in the Zodiacal Dust Cloud.


Post pictures here as you get them.

It also strengthens your lower body, helps to develop a stronger core, improves energy flow and flexibility in your body, especially hip joints and knees. It also provides mental alertness and emotional balance.

This QiGong form is very close to Taichi, but still much easier.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.

REGISTER NOW: http://bit.ly/1MGxgGf

The Design Sprint is a flexible framework for starting new product design and development work.

The Design Sprint is the first, and for some projects the most significant, phase of a design thinking process. It gets the entire product design and development team on the same page, reduces the risk of downstream mistakes, and generates vision-lead goals for the team to measure their success. 

In this webcast, you'll learn both why and how Design Sprints work and how you can use Design Sprints to enhance your own design process.

Get an eye-opening approach to the product design process that results in better,faster outcomes

• Learn the design sprint process from start to finish, including essential tools, tips, and best practices

• Learn about successful examples of design sprints from across the industry 

Presented by: Richard Banfield, C. Todd Lombardo, Trace Wax

Duration: Approximately 60 minutes.

Cost: Free

About Richard Banfield</a>

Richard Banfield is CEO and Co-Founder of Boston-Based User Experience Agency Fresh Tilled Soil, Richard wears the strategic hat around the office. He's worked his way up the web marketing food chain, starting with online ad sales at MultiChoice, Africa's largest TV and Internet media business. Richard was in the thick of it during the heady dot-com years, founding Acceleration, an international e-marketing business headquartered in London. He has never met a whiteboard he didn't like.

Twitter: <a href="https://twitter.com/freshtilledsoil">@freshtilledsoil 
Website: www.freshtilledsoil.com

About C. Todd Lombardo

In a world of hyper-specialization, C. Todd stands in the intersections and sees the connections that revolve around us. As an Innovation Architect at Constant Contact's InnoLoft, he facilitates product and service design sprints for a wide range of external startups and internal product teams. C. Todd is also a member of the adjunct faculty at Madrid's prestigious IE Business School where he teaches courses on Creativity, Innovation, Design-Thinking and Communication.

Twitter: @iamctodd 
Website: https://smbinnoloft.com

About Trace Wax

After a career in user experience design and research at companies like Microsoft and Nuance, Trace then became a developer at Pivotal Labs, and is now a Managing Director at thoughtbot. He has facilitated numerous product design sprints, and is an author and maintainer of thoughtbot's design sprint methodology repository. He's brought Lean and Agile methodology to many large companies and small startups, helping teams to focus, prioritize, and become happy and productive.

Twitter: @tracedwax 
Website: https://thoughtbot.com/

</a>

The modern world holds many secrets, but the most astounding secret of all is that witches still live amongst us; vicious supernatural creatures intent on unleashing the Black Death upon the world. Armies of witch hunters battled the unnatural enemy across the globe for centuries, including KAULDER, a valiant warrior who managed to slay the all-powerful QUEEN WITCH, decimating her followers in the process. In the moments right before her death, the QUEEN curses KAULDER with her own immortality, forever separating him from his beloved wife and daughter in the afterlife. Today KAULDER is the only one of his kind remaining, and has spent centuries hunting down rogue witches, all the while yearning for his long-lost loved ones. However, unbeknownst to KAULDER, the QUEEN WITCH is resurrected and seeks revenge on her killer causing an epic battle that will determine the survival of the human race.

October Marketing Technology Group Meetup! #BMTG4

Let's keep the momentum going! Join us on Tuesday, October 20th from 6:00 to 8:30pm network, learn and discuss marketing approaches and the technology to support them.

Please sign up for this event on our Meetup page since you won’t be allowed access unless you are on the list! Also, please bring a photo ID.

Speakers

• Sean Kelly, Engineer, Tapjoy, Bill Bogasky, Account Manager, Basho: Riak at TapJoy
Mobile Advertising is a big business, and it's only getting better. At Tapjoy, over half a billion ads rendered is just a regular day for us. We'll cover why we chose Riak to handle that scale, how it meets our data storage needs, and how new developments in the product are enabling us to to continue to grow our platform. Riak KV is a distributed NoSQL database that is highly available, scalable and easy to operate. It automatically distributes data across the cluster to ensure fast performance and fault-tolerance.

• Tushneem Dharmagadda, CEO Mobinett Interactive: Using Employee Apps to Create a Better Customer Brand Experience
Learn why internal marketing is just as important as external. Build your brand from the inside out, leveraging mobile technology and the best engagement tactics for employees. Tushneem will show you how to easily create an internal facing employee mobile app that pushes out relevant content, surveys, gamification, rewards, and much more, through an easy-to-use dashboard.

hubEngage™ is an employee communication and engagement platform that lets you push relevant content, surveys, gamification, rewards, and much more, to users via location-based technologies, segmentation, user behavior and feedback algorithms. Using hubEngage's intuitive dashboard, you can instantly design, build and trigger tactics to mobile and desktop apps, analyze performance, and re-target users with increasing relevancy.

• Eric Webster, VP Technology, Cramer: Emerging Technologies You Need to Know About
Strap on your seatbelt for this fast-paced trend spotting session that will take you around the world for a sneak peek at the biggest mega trends you’ve probably never seen before. See what high-tech ideas are coming on strong, how people are experimenting with them and what it will mean for experiential marketers in 2016. Fill your notebook with fresh inspiration and get a glimpse of the future of technology-driven experiences.

•  Mike Maggio, Enterprise Account Exec, bigtincan: Mobile content enablement for sales organizations
Ensuring that sales teams are equipped with the most effective content and selling tools is critical to realizing the highest yield out of a sales opportunity pipeline.  If your organization has or is considering deploying tablets to the sales organization to enable them to be more effective when engaging with customers and more productive while they are mobile, you’ll want to attend this session to discover how to automatically deliver the most recent and relevant content to field sales at the right time, directly to their mobile device, provide the productivity tools to work with any content type on a mobile device regardless of network connectivity, automate processes on mobile devices with interactive forms & HTLM5 apps, gain insight on content utilization, effectiveness & impact on revenue and unlock field sales expertise to share across the team to improve overall group performance.


Agenda

• 6:00: Pizza, refreshments, networking

• 6:40:  Welcome and Announcements

• 6:50 to 8:15: Presentations

• Wrap-up


Location:

Microsoft New England R&D Center, Horace Mann Room, 1 Memorial Drive, Cambridge, MA 02142


Directions to Microsoft New England R&D Center

For driving directions as well as to the NERD, please visit: http://microsoftnewengland.com/About


Parking:

Parking is available at 1 Memorial Drive. Details can be found here. http://microsoftnewengland.com/About


THANK YOU to our generous sponsors!

Davis IT and Engineering Davis IT and Engineering is a specialized staffing firm with over 25 years of experience in providing clients and candidates with expert level talent and cutting edge career opportunities. We bring an innovative and collaborative approach to fulfilling staffing needs including contract, contract to hire and direct hire placements. We're proud to have earned Inavero's Best of Staffing Award for providing remarkable service quality to our customers and candidates.

Microsoft New England (MSNE) is a major center for technical innovation and research. Located in the heart of Cambridge, Massachusetts, the MSNE campus includes two buildings—One Memorial Drive and the recently renovated One Cambridge Center. At the core of MSNE is the Microsoft New England Research & Development Center (NERD). NERD is a world-renowned research and software development center, and is home to teams working on critical products and services like Microsoft Office 365 and Microsoft SQL. NERD also serves as a center of gravity for the local tech community, having hosted more than 1,000 events and welcomed more than 100,000 visitors since opening in 2008.

See you there!

- Rick Kollmeyer
