results.description:
Autodesk will present their new View and Data API and show demos of WebGL/HTML5 with the Oculus and Google Cardboard. 3D Systems will present the Touch haptic device to allow you to reach out touch virtual worlds. As usual we'll also have a variety of other VR demonstrations for you to try from our local developers including brand new demos from VirZOOM & Skreens!


Come see Autodesk research into VR technology via web delivery. Using the new View and Data API, Autodesk Developer Network (ADN) team will show some demos of using this WebGL/HTML5  technology with Oculus Rift (DK2) and Google Cardboard. We will also discuss a few other cool things being researched around Autodesk technology with VR.

Everyone knows how to use their hands but not everyone knows how to use CAD software. Touch is a haptic 3D stylus that puts digital content in your hand, allowing you to actually feel models on the screen. Designed for intuitive 3D sculpting, Touch eliminates the intimidation of traditional 3D modeling. Touch comes with Cubify Sculpt which brings organic modeling tools right to your fingertips. With precise positioning input and instant force feedback that mimics the sense of physical sculpting, Touch gives you complete control over your creations, making it faster and easier to realize your designs. Touch lets you fully manipulate your design by providing access to all three dimensions, making it easy for students, designers, and artists alike to create 3D-printable files with virtual clay. Touch connects the digital and physical worlds like never before, giving you immediate access to your complex designs and a comprehensive understanding of 3D digital space. With the available software development kit (SDK) you can harness the power of the Touch to create spatially aware apps with infinite possibilities.



Demos

Skreens - driving an Oculus Rift directly from their Nexus without a PC!

VirZOOM - VR That Moves You! Brand new cycling hardware and new levels!

Archean World Builder (formerly known as VRMT) - demoing for the first time on the HTC Vive!

Giveaways!

Everyone loves free stuff! Our sponsor Autodesk will be giving out dodo cases, T-shirts and stickers! We've also just received a limited number of gift bags with VR stickers, a cleaning cloth and a VR cover compatible with the Samsung Gear VR and the Oculus DK2 from VR Giant so get there early! Jonathan Linowes will be giving away a copy of his new book "Unity Virtual Reality Projects"


PLEASE NOTE: Our venue requires our guests to sign in with a photo ID at the security desk. When you RSVP you'll get a pop up question; please enter your full name as it appears on your ID. Thanks for your cooperation.

Schedule

6 - Doors open, demos begin 

7 - 7:30 - Autodesk presentation


7:30 - 8 - 3D Systems Presentation

8 - 8:15 - Demo intros & announcements

8:15 - 9:45 Demofest!!

9:45 - Come with us to the afterparty at Firebrand Saints (it's right downstairs!!) 

Parking

If you're coming to the afterparty, Firebrand Saints offers free validated parking for entry after 5pm. Enter through the garage and then keep going into the parking lot so you don't have to go through security again after the garage closes. Please note that the validation is temporary; once they swipe your ticket you should exit the lot immediately.

WE ARE BACK IN DAVIS SQUARE FOR TONIGHT, PLEASE TAKE NOTE OF THIS.

6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

6:45 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

Free event! Come learn about 7 innovative and exciting technology products and network with the Boston/Cambridge startup community! Each presenter gets 5 minutes for product demonstration and 5 minutes for Questions & Answers. Please follow @BostonNewTech and use the #BNT58 hashtag in social media posts: details here.

Sponsors:

Foley Hoag LLP - No industry moves faster or makes a bigger impact on the way we live than the technology industry. Technology innovators in software, hardware, gaming, entertainment and telecom turn to Foley Hoag LLP to help secure and maintain their leadership positions in this competitive industry. Our attorneys provide a comprehensive array of legal services for companies in all stages of development, from conception through profitability and beyond. For more information, please click here to visit our website for technology entrepreneurs. www.FoleyHoag.com [masked]

</a>Get a beautiful new office + $1,000! Our next meetup will take place at WeWork Boston, which has beautiful, collaborative workspaces for entrepreneurs and small businesses. WeWork is offering a $1,000 credit to anyone in the BNT community who signs up at WeWork during September or October. Request a tour by clicking "Become a Member" at <a href="http://bit.ly/1Od0sp8">WeWork.com and submitting your info. Then just mention this offer to whoever shows you around!

The Web world has changed. Now that all browsers and most mobile devices support WebGL, 3D on the web is a reality. We, at Autodesk, love 3D and our new web-service, Autodesk View & Data API, can help enhance your web and mobile apps with rich 3D content. No downloads or plug-ins required, supports over 60 file formats to bring you stunning, detailed, high-fidelity visualizations of models - right within your browser experience. Our REST and JavaScript APIs make it easy for you to quickly develop web apps. Get more info at the Autodesk Developer portal.

Idea to App! Get 30% Off Mobile App Development Services in Boston, MA Through Fall! Do you have an idea for a mobile app or responsive website (web app) and need a mobile app developer, or mobile app development services partner, to bring your vision to life? Mobinett Interactive has vast expertise in strategy, design and software development, and we’re offering a 30% discount on our services for Boston-based startups, if you sign up in September! Visit www.Mobinett.com, Email [masked] or call <a>[masked]</a>.


Products / Presenters:


1. GradTrain / @GradTrainInfo - Curated marketplace for moving abroad, focused on international education first. (Jacob Bacon) Tech: PHP, Angular, Android, C#, Java, SQL. www.GradTrain.com

2. SPOT / @theSPOTapp - Park Easier! The Airbnb of Parking. (Braden Golub / @BSG617) Tech: iOS. www.ParkEasier.com

3. agapt - Activity networking platform for both personal and business use. (Bala Vatti) Tech: MEAN (MongoDB, Express.js, Angular.js and Node.js) JavaScript stack. www.agapt.com:3000


4. ParkWise / @ParkWiseApp - Street parking made easy! (Alexander Shvartz) Tech: iOS, Android. www.ParkWise.us


5. SidelineSwap / @SidelineSwap - Makes it easy and fun to buy, sell and trade sporting goods. (Brendan Candon  / @SidelineChief) Tech: Ruby on Rails. www.SidelineSwap.com


6. Paracosm / @Paracosm3D - Software turns real world spaces into a 3D models to improve augmented reality experiences and robotic navigation. (Amir Rubin / @AmirRubin) Tech: PrimeSense, Intel RealSense, Google Project Tango. www.paracosm.io


Agenda: 


6:00 to 7:00 - Networking over dinner and beverages

7:00 to 7:10 - Announcements

7:10 to 8:20 - Presentations, Questions & Answers

8:20 to 9:00 - More Networking. Please exit the floor by 9 pm.

Directions & Parking:


Public Transportation:

WeWork is just over 2 blocks south of the MBTA Red line South Station, at 745 Atlantic Avenue, Boston, MA (corner of Beach St).

Driving Directions:

Use this Google Map to WeWork. There are parking meters along Atlantic Ave and other area streets, but best garage parking option is at 86 Beach St (between Lincoln St-Surface Artery S) - Use this Google Map to the CENTRAL Chinatown Garage. Only $12 for the evening after 5pm.

Upon Arrival:

Come to our check-in desk in the lobby. Type the first few letters of your last name on the screen or keyboard and once you see your name appear, tap on it to print your name tag. Then, take an elevator to the 8th floor.

results.description:
Please plan to join us and our Partner, Cintell as we host the New England Enterprise Software and Cloud Development Meetup group for their first ever Meetup!

Presented by: Vic Germani - Client Technical Specialist

Special Guest Speaker: Shyam Vaidhyanathan - CTO, Data Scientist, Cintell 

Our topic is hybrid cloud integration.  As organizations begin to leverage more and more cloud capabilities and platforms, the notion of a hybrid cloud patterns becomes extremely relevant. Whether it be combining the privacy and control of a private cloud with an open cloud platform, or leveraging multiple public clouds, determining an integration strategy is critically important. 
  Bluemix provides a number of services that help you address this requirement. In this session we will exam how to leverage the Secure Gateway service to integrate to an external cloud environment such as AWS or Microsoft Azure. Additionally, we make use of the Bluemix Cloud Integration capabilities to manipulate data in flight between multiple services. 

We also welcome our Partner, Cintell who has their application running on AWS and they utilize IBM Watson Services on Bluemix to bring very specific , high value data science related functionality to their customers.  After a brief discussion and overview, we will have the opportunity to see a demo of Cintell's product. 

After this session you will have a solid understanding of how IBM Bluemix supports a hybrid cloud pattern.

This session will be demo focused! See you there! 

Still haven't registered for your free Bluemix account? Sign up here to get started: www.ibm.biz/cloudboston
results.name: Hybrid Cloud Integration

group.name: IBM Watson Cognitive Tech Meetup (Boston, MA)

results.description:
$20 to attend. Please be on time and sign up only if you're positive you can be present.


In this workshop we'll read your work and give you constructive suggestions to strengthen it. From larger structural and character considerations to minor formatting and story bumps, we'll help you make your script tighter, evocative, and more compelling. 


Please bring at least four copies of ONE of the following:

1. Ten pages of an original feature screenplay (or a ten or less-page short film) that you wrote yourself.
2. A treatment that you wrote yourself (one to two-page synopsis of the plot) for a proposed original screenplay. Please keep treatments to two pages maximum.


If you haven't written a script or treatment, then come with your questions and a willingness to provide constructive feedback for others.


Regardless of what you bring, be sure to PRINT OUT COPIES so that we can read it together. If you don't print them out, we'll have no way to workshop your work! At least four would be appreciated.

If you haven't written a screenplay or treatment but are curious about the process, then we definitely have a place for you. For beginners, we highly recommend grabbing a copy of The Complete Screenwriter's Manual (http://www.amazon.com/Complete-Screenwriters-Manual-Comprehensive-Reference/dp/0321397932) and screenwriting software (free: CeltX.com, more features: FinalDraft.com)

For more personalized script attention, I offer one-on-one screenplay coverage services. Details and testimonials: http://www.screenplay.guru. 10% off for Cambridge Screenwriting members.

We can't wait to see you!
results.name: Group Screenplay Workshop - $20

results.description:
Bring your laptop, current project(s), and prepare to make some progress! Folks have walked away grinning from our previous project nights after solving problems that had been frustrating them for a while. We'll do introductions around 6:30pm to get a sense of the skill set in the room, then settle in to work.

These sessions are super-informal and low-key. We always have attendees of all experience levels--don't feel like you have to be "good" or know "something" before you can come hang out with us. If you feel like the term pre-beginner applies to you, project nights are a great time to meet other code-curious women and start figuring out what you need to learn to start working toward your goals. We guarantee that you'll meet someone who will nerd out about what you are interested in and make you excited to start tinkering.

On hand to help out will be:

Paige Eaton is a librarian turned Drupal developer. She loves sports, games, and long walks on the beach, but not too long. It's really tiring to walk on sand. Paige is helpful for questions about UX, HTML, CSS, some PHP, and is a good listener/sounding board for ideas & projects.


Jessica Pang is an interactive designer at ExtensionEngine, a web/mobile app development company. She has spent the past 3 years there working on projects from the ground up. Jessica has experience in wire framing, branding, user experience design, and user interface design.

Reasons why you should come work with us:

Accountability: it's the perfect way to get away from it all (other work, family/housemates, the laundry) and work.

Nerd friends: you'll meet other women who are coding and creating awesome stuff.

Practice: it's an opportunity to practice some of the skills you've picked up if you've taken some of our classes.

Brain exchange: you can ask your neighbor for help on a bug or teach a n00b how to do something you've mastered.

No agenda: Have non-technical work to do? Need a sounding board? Looking for feedback? Just want to get your inbox under control? You're welcome too!

Perks:

+ Fast, reliable internet

+ Fancy, schmancy (i.e., comfy) Aeron chairs

+ Way more fun than working in a coffee shop =)

Location

14th floor, Room Charles

Cambridge Innovation Center

1 Broadway

Cambridge, MA 02142

T Stop: Kendall / MIT

Street parking is available on Broadway St., Third St., and Main St.

Access

Please bring photo ID. Upon entering 1 Broadway you'll check in with security. Tell them you're visiting the 14th floor.

Doors open at 6:15pm; if you arrive before 6:15pm, please wait in the 1st floor lobby, as no one will be available to let you in upstairs.

Once you depart the elevator, you'll find glass doors that are locked. Look for the tablet door sign and find your name in the list to ring the doorbell.

We're meeting in the room labeled Charles.
results.name: Project Night

results.description:
Join us at Boston Common Coffee Co on Washington to discuss The Second Sex, by Simone de Beauvoir.

Boston NOW's Feminist Book Club is our reading group for anybody who loves to read and identifies as a feminist. We'll be reading a variety of books that may fall into one of the following categories:

1.Written by a feminist and/or a woman
2.Plot looks at how gender, race, class, sexuality, ability/disability, ethnicity, nationality, etc. shape us and our views of the world
3.Spark conversation about social justice and gender equality
4.Have strong female characters.

But most importantly, it's a space for people to come together and discuss literature with other feminists! The club is open to both NOW members and non-members. All meetings will be on the second Wednesday of every month. If you haven't read the book, please don't be discouraged - come anyway!
results.name: Book Club Meeting - First person to RSVP gets to choose the book!

results.description:
This month we are focusing on how DevOps transformations impact individuals in traditional software cycles. 

This stuff is hard, so let's talk about it. Change is extremely difficult. Especially with people. 

Here's the agenda:

7:00 - Presentation - Igor Moochnick on DevOps Denialism


7:20 - Cross-functional panel sharing the challenges they've encountered moving into DevOps.
Dev: Jonathan Bass 
Ops: Peter Nealon
QA: Edward Rousseau


We will have a Q&A session afterwards.


8:20 - Open spaces
We'll split into smaller groups to discuss topics brought up during the panel. This is a great opportunity to share personal challenges you face everyday and to get some perspective from others.
results.name: Moving into DevOps from more traditional roles

results.description:
The book: Strands of Bronze and Gold by Jane Nickerson is a Southern Gothic retelling of the Bluebeard fairytale perfect for enjoying some October chills!


When naive seventeen-year-old Sophia Petheram’s father dies, she receives an unexpected letter that seems her salvation. Her godfather the mysterious Monsieur Bernard de Cressac has sent an invitation to “sweeten the atmosphere of an old man’s dwelling” and come live with him. With no money and fewer options, Sophie accepts, leaving her humble childhood home for the astonishingly lavish Wyndriven Abbey in the heart of Mississippi.

At Wyndriven Abbey she finds herself both attracted to and shocked by the charm and easy manners of her overgenerous guardian. But as she begins to piece together the mystery of his past, it’s as if thread by thread a silken net is tightening around her. And as she gathers stories and catches whispers of his former wives—all with hair alight with strands of bronze and gold as her own—in the forgotten corners of the abbey, Sophia knows she’s trapped in the passion and danger of de Cressac’s intoxicating world.

The venue: Mediterranean. Humus, soups/salads, baklava, teas and Turkish coffee. Yum.
results.name: Strands of Bronze and Gold at Andala Coffee House in Central Sq

results.description:
"Energy Deregulation: the $500 Billion Frontier (of what?)"
SOLAR ARRAY FARMS and WIND TURBINE FARMS are entering the space which deregulation opened.  

How does this mean 'massive cash transfer' for investors and smart marketers?

Alex Rhalimi, BU law student and entrepeneur, will present what energy deregulation is, how it works and relates to us consumers, and what that means for ecologically-informed visions of human life on the planet. Buffett and Gates each has said that energy deregulation is the biggest transfer of wealth in the history of business and it's ongoing (from The Motley Fool). 

Learn about carbon reduction and sustainability impacts.

Wednesday evening discussions with community forming. Discussions and Q&A will follow each presentation.

For some interesting comparisons, bring your utility (light, electricity) bills.

Alex Rhalimi's weekly Wednesday evening opportunity meeting is at the Hilton Garden Inn at Boston Logan Airport.

There are TWO (2) Hilton Hotels at Boston Logan Airport, so this one is at the Hilton Garden Inn, 100 Boardman Street.

results.description:
Anyone who loves ASL is welcome to come and be part of the fun! We want to warmly extend an invitation to Deaf people or others fluent/skilled in the language (CODAs for example) to join our group.

This is an easy-going, casual, ASL get-together to meet people who enjoy American Sign Language, who want to brush up on their signing skills, and want to learn more ASL by using it as often as possible.

We strive to have a good time and communicate without using voices. If we need to, we draw or write what we don't know how to sign, and if lots of folks show up, we split up into small groups and mix and mingle, so we can actually see one another clearly, face-to-face and get a good conversation going.

results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us. 

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

BEANTOWN GAMERS RSVP POLICY:

1. You must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.

3. If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 48 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

4. If you would like to come but there are no spots, send Tucker a message.

5. We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 48 hours, or frequently cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

6. If you use a "+1" spot, all of the above applies to you and your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza. We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot). When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.

results.description:
It's Back to the Future Day, and "back to school" day—map school, that is! We'll talk about the anatomy of web maps and how they work, along with some resources for getting started with building web maps. We'll go through the same material as our first meetup back in June of 2014, along with a few updates. If you're new to web mapping, this is for you! If you're a veteran, come anyway to share your wisdom! And enjoy pizza and the company of fellow mappers!

As always, beginners very welcome. Please bring a laptop. Hoverboards optional.


When you enter the building, check in with security - let them know you're attending Maptime on the 4th floor.


--------


Maptime is, rather literally, time for mapmaking. Our mission is to open the doors of cartographic possibility to anyone interested by creating a time and space for collaborative learning, exploration, and map creation using mapping tools and technologies.


This open learning environment for all levels and degrees of knowledge offers intentional support for the beginner. Maptime is simultaneously flexible and structured, creating space for workshops, ongoing projects with a shared goal, and independent/collaborative work time.


Inspiration for Maptime comes from both hack nights and knitting circles. Both are models of spaces for people to create and learn together. Our goal is to provide this space with an open heart and without pretension. You can bring your own projects to work on, or just hang out and socialize or ask questions. Some people are experts, and some people are just getting started, but all of us are learning, so why not do it together?


Maptime is hands-on, so don't forget to bring your laptop!
results.how_to_find_us: When you enter the building, check in with security - let them know you're attending Maptime on the 4th floor.
results.name: Back to School / Back to the Future: Web Maps 101

results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we embark on another Austrian classic; "Human Action: A Treatise on Economics," by Ludwig von Mises.  Our group will cover the Introduction, and Chapter 1: Acting Man, under Part One, followed by a discussion of the questions.

Please note that the readings are not required to attend our meeting, but are recommended.  As always, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill has plenty of parking and is accessible via the Orange Line "Assembly" stop. 

READINGS:


Human Action: A Treatise on Economics
This Week: Introduction & Chapter 1: Acting Man

QUESTIONS:

1) What is human action, and what is the distinguishing feature of this action?

2) What is the incentive for a man to act?

3) According to Mises, is it acceptable to view action as man striving for happiness?


4) Purposeful behavior motivates man to act in which way?Purposeful behavior has the power to remove or at least to alleviate the felt uneasiness.

5) What distinguishes man’s behavior from animal behavior?


6) What does praxeology take for granted?


7) Why must the term “rational action” be rejected as redundant?


8) The study of human action relies on which method?


9) Why is it wrong to condemn an action as irrational?


10) In what way does causality influence human action?


11) How does Mises define the term “instinct?”


12) What happens if man reaches contentment?

Hope to see you there!
results.name: BOSTON AUSTRIAN ECONOMICS GROUP PRESENTS HUMAN ACTION

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11

results.description:
“BELIEF” is an exploration of the power of our diverse belief systems, faith practices and cultural traditions to connect us to ourselves, sustain us through the most challenging times and bind us closer together in community with one another.

Join us for this groundbreaking and bold endeavor by Oprah Winfrey and her incredible team at OWN as we spearhead a whole new culture of getting along! Each evening will offer conversations around questions helping to build more unity and understanding in our lives. 

Explore how our beliefs help us change. A young woman in central India, has committed to forgo all of life’s conveniences and permanently sever ties with her family in order to be initiated as a Jain nun; a man and his daughter arrive in the Nevada desert for Burning Man, an annual festival that provides an experiment in community art, self-expression and culminates in the ritual burning of a large wooden effigy; a member of the Yavapai-Apache Nation, prepares to participate in the Sunrise Ceremony, a spiritual ritual into womanhood; and scientist Marcelo Gleiser has journeyed to the heart of the Atacama Desert in Chile to look deep into space for clues as to how the universe was born and how it is changing over time. He finds the more he searches the universe, the more he must embrace the mystery of the unknown.
results.name: BELIEF : A CHANGE IS GONNA COME

As if it weren’t already bad enough on its own, stress makes us more susceptible to illness. When the mind and emotions are disturbed or overtaxed, the body is less able to fight off infection and manage the repair and rejuvenation of its cells. Living with chronic stress is more of a threat to good health than riding the T in flu season!

In this class we’ll focus on two major categories of herbs for stress: the relaxant, calming nervines and the endurance-building, restorative adaptogens. These natural remedies can very effectively manage and reduce stress, whatever its source. Boosting natural immunity, building stamina, and developing more balanced reactions to stressful events can all be accomplished with the aid of herbal allies. Even panic and anxiety can be effectively controlled with herbs – and without side effects!

Don’t let stress control your life! Come learn safe, holistic strategies for dealing with stress and anxiety!

All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

Membership: $89/month

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~

results.description:
Presented by Grow Native Massachusetts and taught by Dr. Jessica Lubell, Associate Professor of Horticulture, University of Connecticut

Native plants are becoming increasingly popular for creating sustainable and ecologically vibrant landscapes. Yet, designers and landscapers sometimes worry that these species might not survive the tough growing conditions associated with commercial and institutional landscapes, foundation plantings, or other challenging sites. However, many native species will perform well— especially if you understand which plants to use where, and how to get them established. They also make excellent ecologically friendly replacements for the ubiquitous, but now banned, invasive shrubs like winged euonymus and barberry. This workshop will teach us about native shrubs that are adaptable to tough conditions— such as the readily available Rhus and Juniperus, as well as lesser-known taxa like Aronia, Diervilla, Prunus, Myrica, Corylus, and Spiraea. Dr. Lubell has conducted wide-ranging research on the subject, including controlled studies on the adaptability of native shrubs, and improved methods of nursery propagation to increase the availability of native taxa. This will be an enlightening program for all who landscape with natives.


Dr. Jessica Lubell teaches at the University of Connecticut and has more than 15 years of experience working with the horticulture industry. She was a 2015 recipient of the New England Nursery Association Young Nursery Professional Award for the state of Connecticut. Jessica also enjoys using social media to promote the beauty and utility of native plant landscaping. You can follow her on facebook.com/NativePlantGal.

Cost: $28 for Members of Grow Native Mass / $38 for non-members
Sponsor Registration: $75 — includes registration and membership, and a special thank you at the workshop.

CEUs Available: NOFA AOLCP and APLD (2 credits each)

More info: http://grownativemass.org/programs/workshops
results.name: Workshop - Landscaping with Native Shrubs: They are Tougher Than You Think

results.description:
Tonight, three talks sponsored by edX and Quantopian.

Jonathan Kamens: Coal Mine

Coal Mine is Quantopian's open-source tool for monitoring scheduled tasks.  Tasks trigger "canaries" when they execute, and Coal Mine sends alerts via email for late canaries.  Jonathan will explain how it works, and also some of its novel implementation techniques that can apply to any project.

Rafael Schloming: parsimonious

Many text-processing tasks are easier with a powerful parser at hand. Parsimonious is a PEG parser.  Rafael will show of some of the powerful things it can do.  What is a PEG parser? I don't know either! Come find out. :)

Brad Smith: lxml

LXML is the go-to Python library for processing XML and HTML. If you deal with XML in Python, you need it in your toolkit.  Brad will give us an overview of using it and XPath expressions to do document mining and mangling.  


Food will be provided, sponsored by edX.  Doors open at 6:30, talks at 7:00.


Drinks afterwards sponsored by Quantopian.

results.description:
I know when I'm in casual conversation, I have the tendency to "spin" what I'm saying such that the content of the conversation reflects myself in the best possible light.  It's similar in a way to setting up a Facebook profile.  I want to always put my "best self" out there.  Similar to this, but perhaps a little beyond this is Exaggeration.  Sometimes it can be tricky to identify our own exaggerations, but easy to do so when hearing them come from someone else.  Why do we do this? what's wrong with it? and is there anything we can do about it?  

This New York Times article gets at the Psychology of it a little bit: http://www.nytimes.com/2008/05/06/health/06mind.html?_r=0.


I'd kind of enjoy (notice the honest un-inspiring, un-exaggerated truth) discussing this topic. 


I hope you can make it!

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing 

• Accountability 

• Ideas and inspiration 

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do 

Or, you can be a fly on the wall.  No pressure at all.  Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

We try to keep the meetings about an hour long, or shorter.  Here's the way it works:

• 7:00pm Join the meeting here:  https://hangouts.google.com/call/dq4qhhdefftaq3fmqwij2ipe2ea.  It tends to work best with Chrome (rather than Internet Explorer or FireFox).

• Intros, and goal checking: 

• New Members:  Who are you?  What are you working on?  And what is it you hope to get out of attending these meetings?

• Existing Members:  What was one win from this past week?  Is there anything you need help with? (I'll record in Trello).  Last, if you set a goal last week, did you accomplish that goal? (I'll record in Trello).

• Check-Up on last week's Hot Seat:  Did Ed implement our advice?  And with what result? 

• Hot Seat (Rick Dieterlie):  Rick is a serial entrepreneur who has experience with everything from coffee houses to successful Amazon and Ebay stores.  He'll be giving us insight into how he does what he does, and looking for feedback from the group.

• Accountability:  For those who use this group to keep themselves accountable, speak now and we’ll ask you next week if you met your goals.  

• (Meeting Ends around 8pm) 

• Chat and Offer Assistance: The Hangout will remain open until everyone leaves.  You can stay as long as you want to meet new members and give Rick any feedback you may have on his business.

This month we're excited to hear from Paul Chiusano about his work with csound:

Abstract:

Csound is a powerful audio programming language that's been around since the 80s. This talk will be an intro to the csound-expression library, a nicely typed Haskell library for interacting with Csound. In the talk we'll have fun creating and processing audio live, right in GHCI, and we'll explore some of the basics of audio synthesis together.


We will be meeting at 90 Broadway from 7-9pm.


Logistics:

Pizzas, salad and soda.

results.description: "I appeal to you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you agree, and that there be no divisions among you, but that you be united in the same mind and the same judgment."  Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 (and 2!) Corinthians, Paul's back-to-back letters to the saints in Corinth, provide great insight into unity, maturity, church growth, humility, love, the resurrection, church discipline, salvation, faith, and a number of essential topics for those seeking God.  Come join us in our study of 1 Corinthians!

results.description:
As if it weren’t already bad enough on its own, stress makes us more susceptible to illness. When the mind and emotions are disturbed or overtaxed, the body is less able to fight off infection and manage the repair and rejuvenation of its cells. Living with chronic stress is more of a threat to good health than riding the T in flu season!

In this class we’ll focus on two major categories of herbs for stress: the relaxant, calming nervines and the endurance-building, restorative adaptogens. These natural remedies can very effectively manage and reduce stress, whatever its source. Boosting natural immunity, building stamina, and developing more balanced reactions to stressful events can all be accomplished with the aid of herbal allies. Even panic and anxiety can be effectively controlled with herbs – and without side effects!

Don’t let stress control your life! Come learn safe, holistic strategies for dealing with stress and anxiety!

Wednesday, October 21st, 2015
7:00pm – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The fee for this class is $20.

RSVP by emailing us at [masked], or calling[masked]-5274.

results.description:
Hey all! Boston needs to step up and show their community pride! 

Let's get together, here's why...

We have so many great community pros and companies in Boston and Cambridge. We'll all be more successful if we build stronger bonds between us, share challenges and offer support for one another, and grow our presence outside of Boston. 

What do NYC and SF have on our community know-how? Nada.

So, let's get together for casual drinks at a local watering hole and brainstorm some community/world domination ideas. Or, you know, just catch up on each other's lives and work.

Please RSVP, if you're coming. It'll help us spot each other the day of the meetup.

I'd love help with these items to get this event ready:

• Great locations for meetups


• Who we should be asking to join the fun


• The best ways to reach out to other community pros

I'd love help with these things for future events:

• Potential sponsors


• Future event or meetup ideas


• Any community resources you'd like to see 

Please reach out! The more the merrier.
results.name: Community Drinks

results.description:
Most Wednesdays we gather for an open gaming night at the Panera in Porter Square. This event is open to anyone, and usually doesn't have any sort of pre-arranged agenda -- anything you can bring is fair game, provided you can get it done in three hours!

* Your gallant host almost always brings something to play, and takes requests if you get said request to him by Tuesday night at the latest. Behold the collection: http://www.bgg.cc/collection/user/CmdrOverbite?gallery=large&rankobjecttype=subtype&rankobjectid=1&columns=title%7Cstatus%7Cversion%7Crating%7Cbggrating%7Cplays%7Ccomment%7Ccommands&geekranks=%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09Board+Game+Rank%0A%09%09%09%09%09%09%09%09&own=1&objecttype=thing&ff=1&subtype=boardgame

* Due to logistical concerns and a desire to keep peace with the management (who have been notably chill thus far about a bunch of freeloading nerds taking up their table space), I have set a limit of twelve attendees on these events going forward. I doubt this will be much of an issue, given our typical attendance numbers.

* Because our events tend to be small, and the games we typically play tend to be long, if at all possible, please let us know if you plan to be more than a couple of minutes late so that we don't launch into something without you. Likewise, if you're planning on arriving more than a half-hour late, you should be aware that it may not be possible to include you in a game. You're welcome to come by and hang out but the chances are better than even that we'll be hip-deep in gaming goodness by the time you arrive.

* Please be respectful of our hosts; stay mindful of closing time and throw 'em some business if you're hungry.

* Have fun and roll high!
results.how_to_find_us: We usually meet on the lower level -- look for the games!
results.name: Wednesday Gaming In Porter Square

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]

8:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

8:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

Dan Boulger (The Late Late Show, The BBC, Comedy Central) will record his new LIVE ALBUM at this month's edition of Strange Behavior, a stand-up comedy show hosted by Ryan Donahue at the historic Davis Square Theatre.

Dan Boulger Bio: Dan Boulger began his comedy career in late 2004, only one week into his freshman year of college. Quickly becoming a favorite in the New England area, Boulger started performing nationally after winning the Boston Comedy Festival in 2006 at the age of 20. He has since received recognition from audiences and industry alike, having performed on Comedy Central, The BBC, and the HBO Aspen Comedy Festival. He has most recently made multiple appearances on The Late Late Show with Craig Ferguson and Comics Unleashed with Byron Allen. He's appeared on several high profile college tours such as Comedy Central Live and College Humor Live, and he has been the supporting act for many famous comedians including Bill Burr, Louis CK, and Zach Galifianakis.

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

I remember the fanfare of the publication of Erich Von Daniken's Chariots of the Gods back in the early 70s (and late 60s I think) and I was immediately captivated by it. From the pyramids of Egypt to those of the Aztecs, or the Nazca Lines in southern Peru I have never felt that they've been adequately explained by conventional archaeology. And the mysteries just seem to keep piling up. And a few years after Von Daniken's first book, Zecharia Sitchin published The 12th Planet (1976), the first of his Earth Chronicles series in which he interprets the ancient Sumerian writings as providing a narrative of the ancient aliens known as the Anunnaki who traveled to Earth from a planet called Nibiru. During their stay on Earth, human beings were created as hybrids of the aliens and native hominids. Virtually all ancient creation myths from the Bible to the Vedas to the Greek myths can, arguably, be traced to the Sumerian writings. From this perspective, the question of whether ancient aliens have critically influenced human evolution and development is forged!

My guest, Martin Roy Hill has written a novella, Eden, that loosely draws on Sitchin's theme, but it is interesting that he does not especially endorse the work of ancient alien theorists. As he wrote to me in a  correspondence, “ I'm ...not necessarily a believer in the ancient astronaut theory, though I'm open minded about it. The AA theorists bring up a lot of good questions, though I also think they stretch the point sometimes.” So this is going to be a show that will use a fictional work as a starting point for discussion, evidence, conjecture and philosophical rumination from an author who is not entirely sold on the concept. But this, I would like to submit, is the mark of a good writer whose fiction stimulates thought even if he remains skeptical. Indeed, this was also the attitude of Arthur C. Clarke, perhaps the most esteemed science-fiction writer of modern times.

Martin Roy Hill spent more than 20 years as a staff reporter and editor for newspapers and magazines, before becoming a Navy analyst specializing in battlefield medical operations. His freelance credits include Reader's Digest, LIFE, Newsweek, Omni, American History, Coast Guard Magazine, Retired Officer Magazine, the Los Angeles Times Sunday Opinion Section, and many more. Much of his freelance work involves historical topics, especially military history. He was a lead contributor to the 1995 WWII anthology, "From Pearl Harbor to Nagasaki: America at War," published by the Retired Officer Association (now called the Military Officer Association). He also contributed to the American Civil War anthology "Gettysburg: Three Days that Saved the United States," published by I-5 Publishing. Martin's short stories have appeared in such publications as Alfred Hitchcock Mystery Magazine, ALT HIST: The Journal of Historical Fiction and Alternative History, San Diego Magazine, San Diego Writer's Monthly, and the Plan B Mystery Anthology and webzine. 

A veteran of the Coast Guard and Navy reserves, Martin now serves as executive officer of a state military police battalion in the California State Military Reserve, a component of the California National Guard. He has also more than 13 years experience in maritime and wilderness search and rescue and disaster response, and taught wilderness survival and first aid.

Visit Martin's website at http://www.martinroyhill.com/

******************

Your RSVP indicates that you plan on listening to the show. After listening to the broadcast or the subsequently posted podcast you will  be able to post comments on this page. (No, Cyberville MA is not a real place! But I look forward to "seeing" you on the radio, October 21, 2015, 10pm Eastern/7pm Pacific.)

Philosophic Perspectives with Arthur D. Schwartz. Visit the show page at: http://artistfirst.com/arthurdschwartz.htm

Past shows are also accessible on Arthur's YouTube channel: https://www.youtube.com/user/ArthurDSchwartz
results.name: The Ancient Alien Argument with author Martin Roy Hill

results.description:
So, the title is meant literal: I challenge you to capture the Zodiacal Light, as I have never done so. Images need to be taken during this event period, old photos don't count. Are you a morning person? Good, the best time to do this is 12-24 October before dawn.

Zodiacal light is a faint, roughly triangular, diffuse white glow seen in the night sky that appears to extend up from the vicinity of the sun along the ecliptic (the apparent path that the sun takes across our sky). It is best seen just after sunset in spring, and just before sunrise in autumn, when the zodiac is at a steep angle to the horizon. Caused by sunlight scattered by space dust </a>in the zodiacal cloud, it is so faint that either moonlight or light pollution renders it invisible. That means: shooting over the ocean on the beach gets you best results, but you will need a clear night without much marine layer fog.


In the northern hemisphere, the light appears as a faint cone of light above the eastern horizon before sunrise (or the western horizon in spring). Its light intensity is greater than the Milky Way. Typically, the light is colorless, but in rare circumstances it can have blue, green, yellow, or red hues. If the conditions are right, it is easy to see the zodiacal light, but because it is so faint and occurs near the horizon, most viewers think they are seeing twilight or the light from a distant town (both of which we eliminate by shooting before civil twilight and over the ocean). It is best seen when the sun is between 18 and 12 degrees below the horizon, that means during nautical twilight.


The best time then is 5:30 to 6:30 a.m. during the period 12-24 October, after that it gets too bright (sunrise is around 7, in case you want to capture, that, too). Even though the light can be seen well in general in October and November, the moon will be out of the way only during that period of 12-24 Oct (and again 11-23 November). If you have PhotoPills (iToy) or PlanIt! (Android), these apps can show you exactly where the sun would come up, that is where you have to point your camera - typically due East (90°) to about 100°.


<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiacal_light">Here is more info about it on Wikipedia

and

some examples on Google

.

Shooting settings are the same as for star points or Milky Way: wide open aperture (f/2.8 or wider), maximum exposure time in seconds is determined as 400/focal length in mm (300/FL for cropped sensor cameras) and ISO between 1600 and 3200 (6400 is usually too noisy and diminishes the beauty of the faint light). Compose to have something interesting in your foreground, could be silhouettes, as long as it is not a plain straight beach. Try some dunes, or if you plan to go into the mountains, that works, too.


Useless trivia: Brian May, guitarist of the rock band Queen moonlighted (!) as a scientist and completed a PhD thesis on A Survey of Radial Velocities in the Zodiacal Dust Cloud.


Post pictures here as you get them.
results.how_to_find_us: This is not a group event, it is an individual challenge
results.name: Challenge: Capture the Zodiacal Light

results.description:
You are cordially invited to an Open House meeting of the Eastern Massachusetts Business Association on Thursday, October 22, 2015 from 7:00 am to 8:30 am.

We meet each Thursday morning, upstairs at the Hillview Country Club, at 149 North Street in North Reading, MA . The Eastern Massachusetts Business Association is a networking group consisting of business people from Northern Massachusetts and the Greater Merrimack Valley with a primary focus on helping members develop and grow their business. We hold weekly meetings with our members, plus special Visitor Day Open House meetings 3 times per year.
This next visitor day will feature a chance to meet our members, hear a great guest speaker, have a free breakfast, and learn more about the Eastern Massachusetts Business Association. (EMBA).

Come meet a dynamic group of local businesses, expand your contacts and learn some new information to grow your business.

A SPECIAL GUEST SPEAKER will be joining us at this special Visitor Day meeting on October 22nd!  The guest speaker will be Sam Jackson, Director of Operations at Greentown labs. Greentown Labs is located in Somerville, MA.  It offers 33,000 sq. ft. of prototyping lab and co-located office space, a shared machine shop and electronics shop, immersion in a growing community of energy and clean technology entrepreneurs, and on-site events and programs designed to enable start-ups to rapidly grow their networks and their companies.  Currently Greentown Labs has 40+ companies located in their facility.

The Eastern Massachusetts Business Association is a dynamic group of professionals representing a vast range of industries. We have a waiting list for several of the trades/professions, and we know many excellent people have been unable to join our group because their profession was already represented in this chapter.  GREAT NEWS!  A NEW CHAPTER will be starting soon, which will meet weekly in Woburn.  Come to our open house in North Reading on October 22nd for more information about this exciting opportunity!

results.description:
PLEASE NOTE THE DATE CHANGE TO OCTOBER 22ND.  EVERYTHING ELSE IS THE SAME.

Competitive advantage comes from capitalizing on uniqueness. Every organization has the potential to exploit its exact uniqueness in a way that no one else can match. Doing this means leveraging the organization's single biggest resource: it's data. Applying analytics technologies, tools, and techniques can transform data into strategic insights that deliver intelligence in the moment.

Join IBM and NES, a premier IBM Business Partner, for an executive briefing to hear from Safety Insurance, Wegmans, Cheesecake Factory, Seattle Children's Hospital, Homemakers and others are harnessing their data with an enterprise class analytics platform that includes self-service business intelligence, predictive analytics and self-tuning data warehouse appliances. Companies embracing big data and analytics have 33% more revenue growth, 12X more profit growth, and are 2X as likely to outperform their peers.  Four excellent reasons to attend:

• Find out how your organization can address the full spectrum of analytics challenges. Organizations that adopt a full range of analytics cpabilities can discover what is happening, determine why it is happening, predict what is likely to happen and prescribe the best actions to take.

• See how your analytics platform stacks up. New information can help you understand how others are successfully addressing their business analytics challenges with a robust Analytics & Data platform.

• See IBM's enterprise-class Analytics platform including Cognos and SPSS tightly integrated on PureData for Analytics powered by Netezza alongside Aginity's Amp product which can deliver Analytics and Data Hub for Omni-channel marketing in action. This event will include overviews and 'what's new' presentations and demonstrations on Cognos, SPSS and PureData for Analytics, Aginity Amp.

• Get new tools and knowledge. Best practices, topical whitepapers and even access to new big data and analytics tools for you to try are part of this session.

Join us to learn how our solutions are helping organizations of all sizes gain visibility and insight to accelerate their business goals and drive better business outcomes. 


Register here to confirm your seat:  Accelerate Boston


Breakfast and lunch will be provided.  Questions can be addressed to: Jennifer Ely Carter,[masked] - [masked]

See you there!
results.name: Accelerate your Business with Smarter Analytics

The Golden Chickpea in Brookline Village is hosting a breakfast on Thursdays for Moms and babies/toddlers. The little ones can play while we chat- there are plenty of toys. Hope to see some of you there!

http://www.thegoldenchickpeacenter.com

At The Golden Chickpea Center, we provide a warm and friendly atmosphere with emotional and social support in Brookline Village. Our main objective is to strengthen the initial emotional bond between families and their children in the community, particularly those who have no other family in the area.

In a cosmopolitan city such as Boston where young families come from many parts of the country and the world, due to education and professional opportunities, being far away from family is a common occurrence. Our center is a great alternative to fill this need.

We aim to be the premiere urban destination for cosmopolitan families with young children to socialize, have fun, and experience the richness of different cultures among us.

 Our Center is a welcoming place for families of all compositions and backgrounds where children and parents can learn, play and grow together creating shared experiences that last a lifetime... 


If you are one of those  families, join us,  you will feel at home!
results.name: Breakfast at The Golden Chickpea Center

Are you interested in measuring your key fitness metrics (VO2Max, Recovery & Lactate Threshold) so you can learn about your physiological potential and train smart ?

http://revvo.co/

DETAILS

Revvo is a Boston startup building a smart training cycle that is unique in estimating VO2Max & training zones without using an oxygen mask. 

Knowing your training target helps you get more out of every training session. So you'll spend less time yet see a quick improvement !

The test is FREE and everyone gets their VO2Max & Recovery scores, which is incredible value versus lab tests which cost $100-$400! 

The optional report (which includes Lactate Threshold & Personal Training Zones) can be purchased for an extra fee.

Our mission is to help everyone test their fitness regularly so they understand where they stand, train smart and measure the effects of their training program.

The 2015 CWE Women Business Leaders Conference is THE premier event for New England women in business! This event draws budding entrepreneurs and established business owners interested in learning how to start or grow their businesses, as well as corporate supplier diversity and purchasing professionals interested in advancing and promoting their diversity programs. This year’s 2-day event will feature even more than previous:

Educational Sessions for all

Keynote Speakers - three (3) amazing women from New England who launched and led highly-successful, well-known businesses

Business Expo Fair - featuring exhibitors showcasing their products and services - (you can exhibit too!)

WBENC - Exclusive Activities - includes Matchmaking and the kick-off of the WBENC Corporate Mentor Program for WBENC-certified women-owned businesses & WBENC corporate members

CWE Women-Owned Business Challenge - the final presentations of our 10 pitch contest finalists, representing early-stage and mature businesses

Awards Luncheon - honoring friends & clients of CWE for their commitment to supporting women in business

Opportunities to network and make new connections - including a unique speed-mentoring session and an evening cocktail reception on Thursday, October 22

For more information and to register click here: www.cweonline.org/wblc

results.description:
Meditation practice develops concentration, which allows us to calm and steady the mind and give us clear access to our natural wisdom. This practice is 30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion.

The focus is to be present in the moment, allowing thoughts and emotions to surface. We become an internal observer of these, fostering healthy non-attachment and cultivating a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Thursday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

Gathering customer intelligence to guide product design and uncover value

Uncovering what investors or development partner organizations are looking for

Knowing your competition to better know yourself

Join us for healthy refreshments, including sandwiches, energy bars, and nonalcoholic drinks.

Price: $30 until October 21st at 8:00 pm; $40 after then. Free for full time college students through Stay in MA.

October 22, 2015

Place: Microsoft Corporate Center

Agenda: Networking - 5:30 pm to 6:30 pm 
Program: 6:30 pm to 8:00 pm 
Networking: 8:00 pm to 8:45 pm

Register Now!


Jason is a strategist, marketer and researcher with over 10 years of proven success in marketing strategy, portfolio planning and customer needs assessments. His client work spans from traditional organizations to start-ups, including a breadth of medical device work in cardiology, endoscopy, uro-gynocology and oncology, as well as work in diagnostics, biotech and medical technology.

His deep experience in market research drives a rigorous, yet practical approach to problem solving. This data-oriented approach to decision-making provides a strong foundation to advanced market plan and product development. He is currently developing a new model of customer needs assessment targeted at supporting improved product development and portfolio management.

Jason is a mentor in the Healthbox Accelerator Program, an adjunct faculty member at Bentley University and an active member of the Mentors Guild.  He holds an MBA from the Fuqua School of Business at Duke University and a Bachelor’s degree in business from Emmanuel College.

At the Innovation Center, Jeff helps to manage strategic investments across the Pharmaceutical, Medical Device and Consumer businesses made on behalf of the Innovation Center.  He joined Johnson & Johnson in 2006 and has held various finance roles across the Consumer and Med Device businesses supporting operations, commercial activities and Licensing & Acquisitions.  

Prior to joining J&J, he worked in a financial planning & analysis role at Tyco International.  Additionally, he worked as a research associate for Taylor Rafferty Associates in New York City where he supported investor relations activities.  

Jeff completed both his undergraduate and MBA degree at Syracuse University.


An allied healthcare professional with over 15 years of pharmaceutical, biotech, and medical device industry experience, Alexis has helped global 1000 companies identify and solve tactical and strategic challenges through scenario planning, war-gaming, and other primary research monitoring techniques.  Previous to her role in Business Development, Alexis was a Research Director for Fuld + Company, managing engagements within the cardiovascular, CNS, oncology and metabolic disease markets with an emphasis on sales force benchmarking, go to market strategies, market access and regulatory approaches. Previously, she served as a Principal of Allenex Group, a strategic consulting firm, in Naples, FL, where she managed and executed new business development for small and mid-sized pharmaceutical and biotech clients. Additionally she was an award winning member of the specialty sales division at AstraZeneca Pharmaceuticals.

Alexis’ clinical work has been published in the American Congress of Rehabilitation Medicine and she has been a contributor to Rehab Management, an interdisciplinary journal of rehabilitation.

Alexis is a member of the Empire Who’s Who of Executives and Professionals, National Association for Female Executives and The Society of Competitive Intelligence Professionals (SCIP).  She holds an MBA from Simmons College and a combined Bachelor and Master’s Degree in Physical Therapy from Russell Sage College.

Moderator: Ilsa Webeck, Principal, Luminis Partners, LLC

Ilsa, a creative thinker and process driven planner, brings nearly 20 years in healthcare business strategy to the table.  Through her experiences working on many product types, business models and planning processes both in start-ups and multi-nationals, she knows how to see the forest AND the trees.  This experience has contributed to the success of emerging ventures and market leaders by uncovering value for new technologies.  

She has lead process and product development through her work in orthopedics, cardiology, neurology, endoscopy, dialysis, hospital supplies, bioprocessing, tissue banking and hormone therapy spaces.  Ilsa has particular experience helping companies build fact-based product and strategic plans that create value and advance organizational thinking.  She enjoys working with clients to look for simple solutions to the not-so-simple problems.

Ilsa holds an MBA from the Tuck School of Business and Bachelor’s degree in biology from Dartmouth College.

Register Now!
results.name: Marketing Healthcare Innovations: Know Your Customer, Know Opportunity

In other words, bring a laptop, charger, and something you want to build or learn.

6:00 Hang out, chat, snack.

6:15 Go around and introduce yourself and what you're working on. Ask or offer help on your project, or ask for project ideas. Work/chat/eat!

9:00 Go home and get your beauty rest.

WWCode events are intended for ALL women (trans/cis), trans men, and genderqueer folks who are interested in attending. We are emphatically queer and trans friendly and committed to matters of social justice as an organization. Select events may be open to the general public, which will be clearly noted in event descriptions. If you have any questions (or identify differently and want to attend), please message the Directors of this Network.

Monthly Code & Coffee events are back! Come join us on the third Thursday of every month for coffee, code, and camaraderie.

General Description of our Code and Coffee Events:

Code & Coffee is a monthly opportunity for you to practice your skills, meet new friends, and get help if you need it. Bring your laptop, your recent projects, and your programming problems!

All are welcome regardless of gender or skill level, whether or not you've attended past Girl Develop It events. If you're a beginner, we'll be right there to help you work through your questions as needed.

Code & Coffee events are relaxed and informal, and are intended as a way for our community to work and play together while providing each other with ongoing support and feedback.

This event is free, though of course we encourage you to support our location host, Uno Due Go, with a purchase of coffee or a snack.

Feel free to come early, stay late, and/or drop in whenever you can. We can't wait to see you!

The USDA and Microsoft are collaborating on an Innovation Challenge to help farmers be more efficient and effective.  The USDA has a tremendous amount of food supply, economic demand, and remote sensing data as part of its Agricultural Statistical Service (NASS) and Economic Research Service (ERS), the challenge is to explore how to make this data accessible and provide insights for potential users.
