This event will bring together French entrepreneurs from the NETVA program and entrepreneurs from MassChallenge for an elevator pitch face off, an opportunity for both groups to improve their skills in front of their peers and develop a growing network across the Atlantic. Each person in the audience will be able to vote for their favorite participant. 

Come join us for what promises to be an incredible opportunity to engage with French and International entrepreneurs in a fun and dynamic environment! 

The two grand winner of the competition will win a prize of $300 in cash, offered by our generous sponsor: Marie Landel & Associates. 

In addition to the Pitch Battle, we are pleased to announce the participation of scouts from Analog Devices, Sanofi-Genzyme BioVentures and Thales Xplor, a special opportunity to meet one-on-one with top experts and discuss key factors in growing your business!

Register at: http://bit.ly/1Ooq4yf

More information at: http://bit.ly/1OnYmBV 

French Catering will be graciously offered by NETVA's sponsor: Marie Landel & Associates. As a sponsor of international cooperation and the NETVA program since its inception, Marie Landel & Associates is an invaluable resource in the Boston area. 

This event will be held at MassChallenge’s headquarters in the vibrant Boston's Innovation District. Their dedicated team continues to support entrepreneurship and innovation all over the world, and their headquarters in Boston has reinvigorated and empowered the global entrepreneurship ecosystem. 

-----------------
Analog Devices - Emerging Business & Technology
The Emerging Business & Technology division at Analog Devices is intended to accelerate external engagement with the technology start-up community and to accelerate the expansion of ADI’s capabilities beyond silicon into algorithms, software, systems and the cloud. Sanofi-

Genzyme BioVentures
Sanofi-Genzyme BioVentures (SGBV) is the corporate venture capital arm of Sanofi. Previously known as Genzyme Ventures, SGBV has a recently expanded mandate to invest across the more expansive business footprint of Sanofi. SGBV is an important component of Sanofi’s broader global strategy to invigorate external innovation and research. SGBV only invests in early stage companies with promising new products that may be future Sanofi pipeline candidates. 

Thales xPlor
Seeking ways to generate corporate growth beyond traditional R&D and M&A, Thales founded xPlor, which now serves as the company’s innovation hub in the United States. xPlor comprises an elite team of business leaders, technical experts and entrepreneurs whose mission is to identify emerging and disruptive technologies within the US start-up and academic communities.

results.description:
Ok maybe genocide isn't controversial but it is a difficult topic to cover and sad so many avoid it when it should be addressed. This meetup we are going to focus on 2 documentaries: The Act of Killing a documentary directed Joshua Oppenheimer and The Missing Picture a stop motion documentary directed by Rithy Panh. 

In The Act of Killing (documentary not the film!), Oppenheimer has the perpetrators of the Indonesian killings of 1965–66 act out how they killed people. The perpetrators are currently leaders in Indonesia and during the documentary did not realize what Oppenheimer was doing. It's an incredible documentary particularly at the end. 

In The Missing Picture documentary filmmaker Rithy Panh re-creates atrocities of Cambodia's Khmer Rouge between 1975 and 1979 through stop motion and real footage. It's incredibly moving. Both these documentaries are not easy to watch but so good I hope no one gets scared off by the topic! They are such good documentaries I promise you will be happy you took the time to watch them.

Do you have other documentaries or films that you would recommend to others? Comment below!

Accessing the films: Both The Act of Killing and The Missing Picture can be streamed on Netflix or rented on Amazon Prime for $2.99.
results.name: Controversial Film Topic: Genocide

results.description:
2015 marks the 800th anniversary of the signing of the Magna Carta, the founding document of Western liberty that is internationally revered and has inspired the constitutions of hundreds of countries. Its language can be found in the Declaration of Independence and the Bill of Rights and according to Dan Jones, “the year 1215 has become in a sense ‘year zero’ in the story of the struggle for freedom from tyranny.” In Magna Carta, Jones takes us back in time to this turbulent year, when the document in question was just a peace treaty between the third Plantagenet King, John, who was known for his cruelty and instability, and a small group of self-interested and violent barons. Jones brilliantly shows why this document has had such a lasting and international impact that continues to resonate today.

Dan Jones is the New York Times bestselling author of The Plantagenets: The Warrior Kings and Queens Who Made England, now a four-part BBC television miniseries, and The Wars of the Roses, due out in October from Penguin, which charts the story of the fall of the Plantagenet dynasty and the improbable rise of the Tudors. Jones lives in London.

$30.00  Registration for this event will begin on October 8 at 9:00 a.m.

To register, click here and follow the registration button on the right. If you would prefer your information to pre-populate, log in to your My Athenæum Profile. To log in to your My Athenæum Profile click on the profile icon found in the upper right corner of each page on our website.   If you do not yet have a profile, select “New User? Create an account” on the Profile Login page. Members create their own accounts; a username and password are not assigned when you join the Athenæum.

Join us every Thursday at 6 PM at the Cambridge Women's Center for a peer-facilitated trauma discussion group. We are a small but growing community of women who come together to lend support to survivors of all kinds of trauma, past and present. Groups are free, open, and held on a drop-in basis, and all material shared is anonymous and confidential. We hope to see you there! Questions? Please contact [masked]

The theme for this week's meeting will be family.  Relationships with family members are often complicated, and for many survivors of trauma, there can be challenges connecting and communicating. For others, family members may have caused the trauma itself. Come join a supportive network of peers to being talking through some of these challenges, share your experience, and receive support.

results.description:
From Disarray to Direction. Separation, Divorce, and Life Afterwards: Tips to Organize and Prepare Yourself for What Lies Ahead.

On Thursday, October 22, 2015 at 6:30 p.m., four professionals are hosting a free, confidential information session at 133 Washington Street in Norwell, MA.

Complimentary drinks and light refreshments will be served.

Presenters will each speak for 10 to 15 minutes. The second hour will be a chance to socialize and speak with the professionals individually.

Attendance to the event and discussions with professionals are kept confidential. There is no charge for attendance.

Presenters:

Attorney Stephen M. Dodd
The Law Office of Stephen M. Dodd
Stephen will discuss the basic process of a divorce from a legal perspective. He will share the chronology of the divorce process, from start to finish. 

Deanna Coyle, CFA, MBA, CLTC
Deanna will discuss how important it is to look at your financial situation now in order to prepare for the days ahead. She will relay the top items you should be considering at this time. 

Joyce Dolberg Rowe, LMHC, Clinical Director
The Door is Open Counseling Center, LLC
Joyce will discuss ways to prepare yourself for the emotional terrain of separation and divorce and life ahead. She will discuss resources available and mental health tips for navigating the times ahead. 

Sheila May, CPA
Founder of a CPA practice specializing in forensic accounting & litigation support
Sheila will provide information about hidden income. She will share ways income is commonly hidden and what documents you may need to look for it. 

We look forward to seeing you and answering your questions.
results.how_to_find_us: Stephen M. Dodd's law office is in a grey building across from Webb's Pro Fitness. There is plenty of parking behind the office building. The office is on the 2nd floor. Please call or text Sheila May at 781-218-7511 for information or directions.
results.name: Separation, Divorce and Life Afterwards: Tips to Organize and Prepare Yourself

results.description:
Let's read some real science!

We will review the paper which describes the gene and protein expression of the Prochlorococcus bacteria triggered by daily dark-light cycle.

It is the smallest known photosynthetic bacteria which is responsible for producing a substantial part of oxygen in the atmosphere. And it is not really clear how the dark-light cycle governs its gene expression. It does not have enough genes for the normal circadian rhythm. 

http://journals.plos.org/plosone/article?id=10.1371/journal.pone.0043432


The agenda for the journal club:

• Short overview of the papers to understand the scope of the paper. So it is clear what is important and what is not.

• Go over the paper figure by figure. So everyone understand what exactly was done and how it was done.

• Free form discussion.


Previous reading of the paper is not required but much advised. It will help to do not get lost.

A real scientist from the lab that produced that paper is going to join us.
results.name: Journal Club: Transcriptome and Proteome of a Light-Dark Bacterial Cell Cycle

results.description:
This will be the second session of our new Current Events meetup series. We aim to have reoccurring discussions moving forward so we can stay abreast of local, national, and global anti-racism issues both as individuals and together as a community. 

We have seen a huge surge in media coverage within the racial justice movement over the past year. It can get overwhelming trying to keep up with all the stories, events, anniversaries, policies, and debates that touch on racial justice in some way. Let's pool our collective knowledge and discuss what's going on - locally, nationally, and globally - within the realm of anti-racism. This will be a great opportunity to share our sources, our stories, and our knowledge to keep everyone informed of the way things are changing, and unfortunately, the many ways in which things are staying the same.

The topics will change from month to month depending upon what's happening in the world, but many stories may carry over. Have a current event you'd like to discuss at the meeting that isn't listed below? Have a helpful article you'd like to share? Want to look at a story from an unexplored angle? Great! Feel free to post in the comments section below or email one of the facilitators with your ideas. We hope you'll come to this session willing to share a current event you've learned about over the past month or so. If not, feel free to come and listen, learn, and participate in some really important discussions. Looking forward to seeing you all there and kicking off this new series! 

Possible October Current Events:

- Body Cameras coming to BPD

- Syrian Refugee Crisis

- Donald Trump - he's openly racist and has half the country's support

- Iran Deal (parties, Israel's reaction/campaign, global nuclear proliferation)

- US airstrike on an MSF hospital in Kabul
results.name: Current Events October

results.description:
This is the first of several scheduled classes, so sign up only if you can attend a 5 classes listed here.

We will meet 5 times at $5 per person per lesson.  Let's plan to get to Panera (please note which Panera this is) between 6 and 6:30 to eat;  then we can tackle the lessons with a satisfied tummy.   The lesson will begin at 7:00 for 5 consecutive Wednesdays (October 1 - October 29).   In the first weeks,  I'll teach basic stitches and we can talk about realistic first projects.  The final weeks will focus on getting you working on your own project.

I will collect the full amount ($25) at the first lesson so I don't have to bother with collecting  each week and  I prefer cash so I don't have to go to the bank.

You will need a crochet hook in size I, J or K and a skein of inexpensive "worsted weight" acrylic yarn in a solid, light color for the first class.  We had a little difficulty with some yarns,  so I recommend "craftsmart":  it's about $3 at Michael's comes in lots of colors and behaves.  If you google Michael's, Joann or AC Moore stores,  you can probably find a coupon on their sites which will offer a discount off the full price and each store honors coupons from the others.     

There will be homework. 

I will assign a small amount of homework intended to be completed over 3-4 days during the week intended to reinforce what you have learned that week.

Please be considerate

There is a long list of women who are interested in learning to crochet.  If you RSVP,  please be sure you can attend.  Same day cancellations and no shows will not be tolerated.   You'll be marked as a no show and I won't be willing to include you in a future class.

If you have any questions,  please send me a pm.  I won't necessarily be monitoring this site.
results.how_to_find_us: Look for a skein of yarn on the table.
results.name: Learn to Crochet with Anne

results.description:
Itadaki downstairs bar (Boston, Newbury St. between Gloucester and Fairfield) 7 pm to 10 pm

Join me at this izakaya style venue for a pleasant evening of drinks, food and chats. Whether you're learning Japanese or English, buy a drink, join the table, and practice your new language in a friendly and relaxed environment. If you're a beginner or just interested in culture, you'll fit in fine! Don't miss out on this opportunity to learn and practice over a few drinks. Can't make it on time? Need to leave early? Not a problem. Just stop by if you can!

If you are >21 and plan to drink, please bring a MA state issued ID or passport. Other state IDs may not be accepted. Please order at the bar and take care of your own tab.

Transportation: I highly recommend using public transportation. Not only is driving while intoxicated dangerous, but there may not be any parking available in the area. A lot of the parking on Newbury St  is Residential Only in the evenings, and many of the signs indicating this are very well hidden. If you insist on parking in the area, be aware that meter maids love handing out parking tickets around here. Best methods for public transportation are the green line subway or bus #1 to the Hynes stop.

I have made an arrangements with the Itadaki staff for a simpler ordering method. Last time was very chaotic and stressful for the bartender, so lets do our best to not confuse the bartender. :)

Ordering at Itadaki

1) Order your first drink at the bar. If it's alcoholic, your ID will be checked at this time. You will also be  given a guest number to use the rest of the night.

2) If you're at a table, the bartender will try to make several rounds throughout the night to take additional orders. Keep using your guest number and please feel free to order more food and drinks.

3) Keep in mind we're a pretty large group so don't be offended or annoyed with the bartender if he doesn't get to you right away. If you have an urgent order, go request it at the bar.

4) Please take care of your tab and don't forget to tip*. The management and staff are doing a lot to make this all possible.

*Note: If the group is large, an 18% tip may already be included.

See you there!
~Lindsay
results.how_to_find_us: Go to the downstairs bar and look for the sign!

About the talk:


Scaling Django Apps using AWS Elastic Beanstalk - This talk will cover the following topics:

•  What is AWS Elastic Beanstalk (EB)?

•  What are the advantages of using EB over managing EC2 instances / Load-balancing / Auto-scaling myself?

• What are some common issues I might run into when deploying my Django app to EB?

About the speaker:

results.description:
We will photograph the 9/11 Memorial, a very somber place, but beautiful and I believe that we can capture it very uniquely at night. The memorial is open until 9 pm, which gives us about 2 hours to explore. I have not had any issues with a tripod inside, but be aware that the guards are very adamant about "proper" behavior, let's make sure not to aggravate anybody, be respectful, quiet and stay out of the way of people. I chose a Thursday night to avoid the weekend crowds.


After the Memorial, we will drive up the subway to Empire State building, which observation platform is open until 2 am. However, they do not allow any tripods, but you can check them at the security checkpoint, if you do not have any option to store it. I recommend that you bring some sort of small monopod (nothing that extends to the ground, but is perhaps a foot long), maybe one of those gorilla pods. If you have a choice of cameras, bring the smaller one, it is easier to steady. The observation platform is surrounded by a metal lattice, which serves to steady the camera and its spacing is wide enough to comfortably shoot through. Make sure not to drop your camera, though. :-) The lattice has varying heights from about 1 ft off the ground to 4 ft.


Bring wide angle lenses for the memorial and long lenses or zooms for the Empire State Building. A fisheye will work well in both locations. Lots of cool stuff to zoom into from the Empire State. A small backpack is recommended, the less we carry, the less we will stick out of the crowd. Try a 360° view at the memorial or a panorama from the Empire State!


Be aware that you will need to go through a thorough security check with metal detector and the Empire State Building charges $32 for the 86th floor platform and $52 for both 86th and 102nd floor (I've never been up there). You can purchase tickets and get a feeling for what to see at this link. Advanced ticket purchase will save you between 10 and 30 minutes wait time.
results.name: New York City 1: 9/11 Memorial and Empire State Building

venue.name: The Commonwealth Center for Holistic Herbalism

results.description:
Flower essences work to help realign emotional and psychological imbalances, allowing us to regain peace and harmony in our minds and bodies. Working within a holistic perspective, we see that many physical illnesses are manifestations of emotional and psychological imbalances. In this monthly group, we will explore the ways that flower essences behave in the body, and the many imbalances for which we can look to the flowers for help. Whether we seek to increase emotional comfort, decrease physical discomfort, encourage creativity and spiritual growth, or to aid us in transitions in our lives, flower essences can help us in making these shifts.

If you are interested in working with flower essence medicines and never have before, or if you already work with flower essences and want to deepen your understanding of these remedies, this is the evening for you! We will meet to experience some different flower essences, discuss our experience of the essence, share thoughts on working with flower essences, and do some flower essence formulation practice.

Thursday, October 22nd, 2015
7:00 – 9:00 pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

This group meeting is free of charge, although a $10 donation for materials is recommended. Please RSVP for this event by emailing [masked], or calling (857) 615 7763.

results.description:
If you’ve been thinking about what’s next, then this is the program for you. You’ll have the opportunity to meet 3 dedicated, interesting women who will talk about opportunities for work (both volunteer and stipend) with non-profits in the Greater Boston area. Please join us at Hotel 140 for a wonderfully informative evening.

If you are interested in ride-sharing to this event, please contact Elizabeth Meek at <a>[masked]</a>.  

Donna Morelle is the Director of Encore Fellowships at ESC of New England (ESC) providing a new source of talent to the nonprofit community. She brings over 25 years’ experience in executive leadership and program development to this role, partnering nonprofit organizations with mid-career professionals looking to serve the nonprofit community. The Encore Fellowship Program matches skilled, seasoned professionals with social purpose organizations in high impact, paid transitional assignments. For more info about the Encore Fellowship Program, click here.

Jan Latorre-Stiller has been director of SOAR 55 for nearly 23 years.  SOAR 55 is part of a national network of volunteer programs that mobilizes adults age  55 and over to contribute their skills and experience in significant service activities that helps strengthen and expand the capacity of nonprofit and public organizations in Newton and several metro west communities.  Jan’s long tenure with the organization is evidence of her commitment to providing adults in later life transition with challenging and meaningful ways to continue to remain an integral and valued part of our communities. For more information about SOAR 55, click here.  

Judy Willett, Executive Director of ReServe Boston, is an innovative, solution oriented professional with expertise in leadership, management and entrepreneurial, non-profit business development. Her main mission is to improve the lives of people 50 and over and enhance their communities. ReServe helps professionals age 55+ who want to stay engaged in the workforce while dedicating their skills to important causes. ReServe helps them secure high-impact, part-time work in the nonprofit sector that offers flexibility and a modest stipend. For more information about ReServe Boston, click here.  

TTN Members $15.  MeetUp Members & Other Guests $20.

To register for this event click on 

https://www.thetransitionnetwork.org/pages/events/chapter/chapters-boston/?cmd=register&event=1627.  

For More information about The Transition Network (TTN), click here.
results.name: Encore Career Panel

results.description:
The More Beautiful World so often seems far away and even impossible to the rational mind. Yet our hearts know the way.  Let's engage our most embodied, playful and creative selves to find the Beauty, clear the pathways, and move forward individually and together.   Let's affirm those things that give us hope, inspiration and strength. 

We will warm up our bodies, minds and spirits with movement, voices and energy work. We'll practice centering and connecting with Source;  then step into the More Beautiful World through various forms of Play. 

Our activities will include such things as:  sounding, moving, shaping, listening, speaking, showing, witnessing, leading, and following;  hand dancing, face dancing, babbling, talking in a fake foreign language, toning and rhythm jams, story circles.... There's no way to do any of it "wrong!"   

I've been participating in the InterPlay version of play for some years now, experiencing its "sneaky deep" powers to cultivate personal freedom, creativity, connection and transformation within oneself and with others. It's such a delight to share this with others. 

To learn more about InterPlay: http://www.interplay.org
results.name: At Play in the More Beautiful World

results.description:
"A universal theology is impossible, but a universal experience is not only possible but necessary. It is this experience toward which the course is directed." (ACIM Manual for Teachers)

Designed to correct perception and lead to a universal experience of knowledge, A Course In Miracles has been translated into 23 languages, is referenced and utilized by many of today's most reknowned spiritual teachers, and has inspired countless books and curriculums based on its teachings. But it can be a difficult book to grasp. It is lengthy, the writing is abstract, and its use of Christian terminology alienates many.

And yet it has become one of the most influential spiritual books of today. Join us as we dive into it, and are led to understand its principles against the backdrop of our own questions, personal experiences, and realizations. Beginner as well as advanced Course students are welcome. We'll start with a short meditation, and then use a reading from the Course as an entry point into our time together. Cost $5 per person.

Bringing a copy of the book is helpful, but not necessary. Recommended (but again not necessary) is the combined volume that includes the three supplements (Clarification of Terms; Psychotherapy: Purpose, Process, and Practice; The Song of Prayer), available online from The Foundation For Inner Peace at acim.org.
results.how_to_find_us: From Concord St.: we're 4/10th's of a mile down Russell St. on the right, the driveway after Fraser Farm.

results.description:
Ongoing class in 18th century Scottish Broadsword and Smallsword.

The Broadsword is the archetypal weapon of the Highlander swordsman - a broad-bladed cutting and thrusting weapon. It has a basket hilt to protect the hand and wielded single-handed.

The Smallsword is the courtly weapon of the Scottish warrior class. An elegant thrusting weapon it teaches the fighter to use the thrust and make small parries. The smallsword is the immediate predecessor to modern epee.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.

All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.
results.name: Scottish Smallsword & Broadsword

QUINTON RANDALL IS BACK from Baltimore, MD to give Boston more of that #BaltimoreBlues
Slade's Bar & Grill

{{ FREE EVENT }}

He is a passionate blues player from Baltimore, MD - Quinton Randall's distinctive growling vocals and wailing guitar work have become a favorite of any audience lucky enough to hear it. He's got an old soul and an intimate connection to his guitar that shines out of his every tune. “I want them to feel a sense of hope, clarity and freedom” says Quinton Randall, also known as “Q". His talent, along with his instrument of choice was birthed in 2005. His audience could recognize his potential even then at the age of 16. His earthy tones resonate with his mixed audiences. His mission is to give his audience what music gave to him, which is an outlet. He has experienced, first hand, what blues can do for the soul and wants to continue to spread that feeling everywhere.

Quinton Randall will be accompanied by:
Ramadan Yasiin on bass
Noah Stone on violin
Patrick Forte on trombone

results.description:
In this FREE mini-workshop, you'll learn specific tools that you can use right away to master intimate connections that are meaningful and loving.  

Spend your evening paving the way to intimate connection with a group of like-minded friends (old and new!)


If this feels scary to you and you've been holding yourself back, this workshop is for you! 

Discover what's in your way of having the most satisfying  relationships including effective communication, and great sex. 

This workshop will focus on our innate ability to open to a greater love inside ourselves - that can be shared with others: a skill that when learned and practiced, enhances all of our relationships.  Feeling deeply connected to yourself and your heart provides a deep sense of peace. 

You’ll learn specific tools that will:

• Enhance your ability to identify core wants, needs and desires 

• Cultivate communication for healthy relating

• Become more intimate with yourself and others - with ease! 

• Stay in a place of love when it’s most difficult

In this free mini-workshop, you’ll have the opportunity to connect with others through a variety of exercises designed to open your heart and support you in sharing authentically with one another.

Come and get a taste of what you’ve been craving in a totally safe, warm, loving and non-sexual environment.  Learn more about what the Human Awareness Institute has to offer.

Finding love and being in love every day is something I personally never dreamed was possible (only for 'others' and not for me!)  Well, I'm happy to say I was wrong and am really excited to share what I've learned with you.

Each event begins promptly at the scheduled time. Please arrive at 7:30 pm so you can settle in, register and meet a few folks before we begin promptly.   

There will be no admittance after the scheduled start time so as not to break the continuity of the workshop.  



We look forward to seeing you there!  Even if you've been to a mini-workshop before, please join us again!  There's no limit to how many you can attend!
results.name: Paving the Way to Intimate Connections with Rich Walkden

results.description:
In this FREE Human Awareness Institute (HAI) mini-workshop, you'll learn specific tools that you can use right away to master intimate connections that are meaningful and loving.  

Spend your evening paving the way to intimate connection with a group of like-minded friends (old and new!)

If this feels scary to you and you've been holding yourself back, this workshop is for you! 

Discover what's in your way of having the most satisfying  relationships including effective communication, and great sex. 

This workshop will focus on our innate ability to open to a greater love inside ourselves - that can be shared with others: a skill that when learned and practiced, enhances all of our relationships.  Feeling deeply connected to yourself and your heart provides a deep sense of peace. 

You’ll learn specific tools that will:

• Enhance your ability to identify core wants, needs and desires 

• Cultivate communication for healthy relating

• Become more intimate with yourself and others - with ease! 

• Stay in a place of love when it’s most difficult

In this free mini-workshop, you’ll have the opportunity to connect with others through a variety of exercises designed to open your heart and support you in sharing authentically with one another.

Come and get a taste of what you’ve been craving in a totally safe, warm, loving and non-sexual environment. Learn more about what the Human Awareness Institute has to offer.

Finding love and being in love every day is something I personally never dreamed was possible (only for 'others' and not for me!)  Well, I'm happy to say I was wrong and am really excited to share what I've learned with you.

Each event begins promptly at the scheduled time. Please arrive at 7:30 pm so you can settle in, register and meet a few folks before we begin promptly.  

There will be no admittance after the scheduled start time so as not to break the continuity of the workshop.   

We look forward to seeing you there!  Even if you've been to a mini-workshop before, please join us again!  There's no limit to how many you can attend!
results.name: Paving the Way to Intimate Connections with Rich Walkden (HAI)

results.description: Bees Deluxe is a full-tilt, acid blues/funk/rock collective comprised of Boston-based musicians. Their unique repertoire includes over three sets of originals and 60s, 70s, and 80s covers from Billie Holiday, Miles Davis, Joe Zawinul, Charles Mingus, B.B. King, Kenny Burrell, Freddie King, Herbie Hancock, Albert King, Etta James, Muddy Waters, The Meters, Little Feat, Ray Charles, Jimi Hendrix, Roy Buchanan, Curtis Mayfield, The Butterfield Blues Band, Derek Trucks, Donny Hathaway, Amy Winehouse, Steely Dan, Etta James, ZZ Top, Robben Ford, Bonnie Raitt, Bobby 'Blue' Bland, SoulLive, Derek and the Dominoes, Robert Cray, Edgar Winter, Amy Winehouse, among many others. Taking the road less traveled, they discover and share off-the-beaten songs and instrumentals and fuse them into their own original works. They dare to be risk-takers on stage, digging deep into the vaults of blues/jazz antiquity. The result is an effortless take no-prisoners-approach that wittingly captures the audience's hearts.

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

results.description:
So, the title is meant literal: I challenge you to capture the Zodiacal Light, as I have never done so. Images need to be taken during this event period, old photos don't count. Are you a morning person? Good, the best time to do this is 12-24 October before dawn.

Zodiacal light is a faint, roughly triangular, diffuse white glow seen in the night sky that appears to extend up from the vicinity of the sun along the ecliptic (the apparent path that the sun takes across our sky). It is best seen just after sunset in spring, and just before sunrise in autumn, when the zodiac is at a steep angle to the horizon. Caused by sunlight scattered by space dust </a>in the zodiacal cloud, it is so faint that either moonlight or light pollution renders it invisible. That means: shooting over the ocean on the beach gets you best results, but you will need a clear night without much marine layer fog.


In the northern hemisphere, the light appears as a faint cone of light above the eastern horizon before sunrise (or the western horizon in spring). Its light intensity is greater than the Milky Way. Typically, the light is colorless, but in rare circumstances it can have blue, green, yellow, or red hues. If the conditions are right, it is easy to see the zodiacal light, but because it is so faint and occurs near the horizon, most viewers think they are seeing twilight or the light from a distant town (both of which we eliminate by shooting before civil twilight and over the ocean). It is best seen when the sun is between 18 and 12 degrees below the horizon, that means during nautical twilight.


The best time then is 5:30 to 6:30 a.m. during the period 12-24 October, after that it gets too bright (sunrise is around 7, in case you want to capture, that, too). Even though the light can be seen well in general in October and November, the moon will be out of the way only during that period of 12-24 Oct (and again 11-23 November). If you have PhotoPills (iToy) or PlanIt! (Android), these apps can show you exactly where the sun would come up, that is where you have to point your camera - typically due East (90°) to about 100°.


<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Zodiacal_light">Here is more info about it on Wikipedia

and

some examples on Google

.

Shooting settings are the same as for star points or Milky Way: wide open aperture (f/2.8 or wider), maximum exposure time in seconds is determined as 400/focal length in mm (300/FL for cropped sensor cameras) and ISO between 1600 and 3200 (6400 is usually too noisy and diminishes the beauty of the faint light). Compose to have something interesting in your foreground, could be silhouettes, as long as it is not a plain straight beach. Try some dunes, or if you plan to go into the mountains, that works, too.


Useless trivia: Brian May, guitarist of the rock band Queen moonlighted (!) as a scientist and completed a PhD thesis on A Survey of Radial Velocities in the Zodiacal Dust Cloud.


Post pictures here as you get them.
results.how_to_find_us: This is not a group event, it is an individual challenge
results.name: Challenge: Capture the Zodiacal Light

results.description:
This conference is free and open to the public, but seating is limited and registration is required. Event link HERE. Registration HERE. 

:: :: ::

The Second Annual HLS-UCLA Food Law and Policy Conference: Drugs, Animals, and Food: Law & Policy of Antibiotics in the Food System

:: :: ::

October 23rd, 8:30am–5pm

Pound Hall, Room 102

Harvard Law School, 1536 Massachusetts Ave.

:: :: ::

The debate over antibiotic use in animal agriculture combines elements of science, ethics, politics, and law. Between fifty and eighty percent of all antibiotics sold in the United States are fed to farm animals raised for human consumption––both to promote animal growth and reduce disease in food-producing livestock living in high-density conditions. This agricultural antibiotic use significantly contributes to the evolution of drug-resistant bacteria that affect our ability to treat and prevent human disease, and serious animal welfare concerns exist regarding the concentrated environments this antibiotic use enables. Considerable social and financial costs weigh on both sides of the issue, and the legal system is invoked with each new dispute. This symposium will explore the many facets of the debate with presentations by leading legal advocates, health sciences experts, and public policy scholars. 

:: :: ::

Confirmed speakers 

• Emily Broad-Leib, Director of the Food Law and Policy Clinic; Deputy Director of the Center for Health Law and Policy Innovation, Harvard Law School

• Anna Cecilie de Klauman, Minister Counselor, Food, Agriculture and Fisheries, Danish Royal Embassy

• Kelsey Eberly, Litigation Fellow, Animal Legal Defense Fund

• Jacob Gersen, Founder and Director, Harvard Food Law Lab, Harvard Law School

• Lisa Heinzerling, Justice William J. Brennan, Jr., Professor of Law, Georgetown University Law Center

• Kim Kessler, Policy and Special Programs Director, UCLA School of Law Resnick Program for Food Law and Policy

• Bob Martin, Program Director, Food System Policy Program, Johns Hopkins Center for a Livable Future

• Janice Nadler, Professor of Law and Associate Dean for Faculty Affairs, Northwestern University Law School

• Erik Olson, Senior Strategic Director for the Food & Agriculture and Health Programs, Natural Resources Defense Council

• Kevin Outterson, Professor of Law and Professor of Health Law, Bioethics & Human Rights, Boston University School of Law

• Lance B. Price, Professor, George Washington University Milken Institute School of Public Health

• Michael Roberts, Executive Director, UCLA School of Law Resnick Program for Food Law and Policy

• Kristen Stilt, Director, Animal Law and Policy Program and Islamic Legal Studies Program, Harvard Law School

• Stephanie Tai, Associate Professor of Law, University of Wisconsin Law School

:: :: ::

This event is cosponsored by the Harvard Food Law Lab and the UCLA School of Law Resnick Program for Food Law and Policy, with support from the Harvard Food Law and Policy Clinic, the Harvard Animal Law & Policy Program, and the Petrie-Flom Center for Health Law Policy, Biotechnology, and Bioethics at Harvard Law School.
results.name: Food Law Conference (HLS)

results.description:
Embark on a profound journey of personal transformation. Re-align to your personal goals and to your values.  Practice tools that can effectively support a more fulfilling life.  Learn to manifest the "success" that holds the most meaning to you in your life.


Insight I takes you on an engaging, inspiring, and exciting adventure of self-discovery. Clarify what you want in your life.  Identify what holds you back.  Choose beliefs and behaviors that will propel you forward.


Learn simple, powerful tools of awareness. Reconnect to your authentic self — to "your heart".  Tune into your inner wisdom.  Fall back in love with yourself  -- and with the people in your life.

From this place of wisdom, you'll align to your life purpose, unleashing energizing feelings of freedom and enthusiasm.  As you deepen your understanding of your true self, you'll clarify your true life goals (and re-evaluate unsatisfying goals, which may have been imposed on you.)

Highly experiential, Insight I is a powerful first step in self-awakening and self-awareness.  It brings you into a more conscious alignment with your true individual purpose, releasing feelings of great joy and fulfillment, and the experience of life's abundance.

When  

The seminar takes place over one of the most profound three days of your life:

Friday, Oct 23:  8:30 Registration, Seminar: 9:30A-10P
Saturday, Oct 24: 9:30A-10P
Sunday, Oct 25: 9:30A-8P

Candle Lighting Ceremony
Sunday: 8P-9P

Notes on Timing:

Please arrive between 8:30-9:00 on Friday morning to confirm registration information  

Ending times are approximate 


There is a lovely candle lighting ceremony on Sunday at 8P to which your friends and family are invited.

Price: The price is $495.  

Money Back Guarantee: You will receive a full refund if you request it within a week of *completing* the seminar.  


Graduate Price: Price to re-take the seminar is $295 .



To Register for this Insight I

RSVP here at Meet-Up to connect with the community, and then click here to officially register at the bottom of Insight's cVent web site.

Facilitator: Mary Ann Somerville


Mary Ann Somerville is an international educator, consultant and executive coach. Since 1980 she has assisted over 50,000 people to create greater fulfillment and balance in their personal and professional lives while achieving outstanding results. Her work has taken her to Europe, Australia, Russia, South America, Asia, Canada and United States.

She is a lead facilitator and design consultant for Insight Seminars.  For the last seven years she has worked as a consultant with Triad Consulting conducting Managing Difficult Conversations courses for a variety of corporate clients including Honda, HP, Xilinx, BP, Conoco, and CIBC.

Ms. Somerville is an innovator in the field of experiential learning and communication.  She designs customized programs and coaching formats for teams and organizations to develop the skills and strategies needed to work effectively and efficiently in a rapidly changing, culturally diverse, “global” workplace.

Ms. Somerville has been the director of training for Insight Seminars and the international enrollment director for Insight Seminars. She has developed and delivered programs for Americorps volunteers, for the 4-H National Council, for the Drucker Foundation, and for other non-profit organizations.

She co-created and facilitates the "Gift of the Heart Seminar", which, funded through private donations and sponsored by Insight Seminars, are offered to patients, families and caregivers who are dealing with the challenges of life-threatening illnesses.  Ms. Somerville also co-founded one of the first parent cooperative schools in the United States.

Ms. Somerville holds a B.A. in psychology and an M.A. in spiritual science. She lives in Santa Barbara where she is currently working on her first book.

Facilitator: Michael Connor


Michael Connor has been designing and presenting personal and professional development keynotes and trainings worldwide since 1993. A highly talented trainer and facilitator, he has presented programs on four continents, including eastern Europe, western Europe, Russia, Israel, and Brazil. Mike Connor leads corporate strategy seminars for Fortune 500 companies.  A business professional with a wealth of practical expertise, he is the former President and CEO of the Insight Educational Institute and a former health care executive. 


His personal growth background includes leading Insight Boston, facilitating Insight seminars, creating and facilitating his own workshops, leading men's work, and numerous interactions with parent-child workshops. He has written a book, "Insights of a Father", reflecting on personal growth through fatherhood.

Mike holds a masters degree in health care management and   a masters degree in practical theology.  While consulting to the Ministry of Health in Bulgaria (and simultaneously starting Insight Bulgaria), he met his wife, Maria, a physician.  He is a dedicated father to two beautiful teenagers and lives with his family locally.
results.name: Insight I:  The Awakening Heart Seminar

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Friday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

Running late?  No prob. You can always meet up with us at the picnic tables next to the visitor center after we finish the walk. 

***By popular demand this is set as weekly event.  If the weather is bad we can change it to a different day or skip the week.

results.description:
--->NOTE: This is a FREE DIGITAL EVENT at your location on your device where-ever you are! 

REGISTER NOW: http://bit.ly/1ZJ8SZK

The learning world has been buzzing for years about informal learning, social learning, collaborative learning, personal learning environments (PLE), and many other mutations.

The challenge is how do we connect the dots that we "honor the way learners learn" - by following their own interests, in small bites, anytime-anywhere to a shared knowledge so everyone learns form each other. "We're Smarter Together" is how we combine self-learning to collective small group or wide company learning.

Furthermore, how do we connect the "Smarter Together" learning to build a path of skills and expertise development that leaders and peers that shows how employees and learners can showcase, announce and celebrate their studies and discoveries and capabilities?

The webinar will focus on the ALL-NEW Training Magazine Network's new features & abilities:

1. How to use small insights learning leading to expertise development 
2. Where to find the world's single place to find abundant knowledge about learning and keep permanent records of them 
3. How to track, show, demonstrate and share with leaders your "Path to Expertise" - be recognized for your continuing skills development 
4. How to be smarter by being of the "We're Smarter Together" community 
5. How to do extend the "We're Smarter Together" community to your business and organizations

Speaker

Ray Jimenez, Ph.D.

Architect of TrainingMagNetwork.com, Chief Learning Officer of Vignettes Learning 


Ray is the Chief Learning Officer of Vignettes Learning, a consulting, content development and platform company focusing on how to make content smaller, more engaging and accessible. He is the author of 3-Minute eLearning, Scenario-Based eLearning and Do-it-Yourself eLearning. He developed and delivers the popular workshops on “Story-Based eLearning Design for Technical and Compliance Programs” and “Story-Based Webinars.” He serves companies like Nestle, NASA, US Air Force, British Petroleum, Philipps66, Neiman Marcus, Caltech, Edison International, Pacific Gas & Electric, Progressive Insurance, to name a few. He teaches at the University of California, Irvine, and in workshops and conferences for Training Magazine, ASTD and eLearning Guild.

results.description:
This image taken in very late afternoon/blue light.

Fall in Cape Cod is a multi-faceted photo opportunity with truly spectacular scenics and wildlife. The tourists have left and traffic isn't a nightmare. This very special workshop is all for all levels of photographers from beginners to advanced.

The Cape provides some of the most incredible landscapes and seascapes along with October light that is spectacular. We will explore and photograph the Cape's classic sea shore, sand dunes, light houses and possible wildlife. We will determine schedules and locations based on weather forecasts, tides and sunrise/sunset times. We will explore the opportunity to do some night photography as well.

This workshop will begin with a meet and greet. An orientation briefing and a short classroom session devoted to teaching exposure theory, composition and field techniques. Each day we will explore various landscapes, whether intimate ones or those on a grand scale, photographing sand patterns, marsh grasses and fishing scenes. We will determine locations based on weather forecasts and the progress of fall colors.

In the field, you will be provided with instruction based upon your needs. We will cover:

• Light

• Light quality and quantity

• Light temperature

• Light direction (side and back-lighting)

• Exposure

• Metering for the best possible exposure

• Filters and Polarizers

We will explore how to obtain tack sharp images considering the following:

• Auto Focus Modes

• Manual Focus Modes

• Panning techniques

You will also learn how to work you subject considering such factors as:

• Perspective

• Composition

• Panoramas

• Close-up and macro capture

Our days will be based on a very flexible schedule allowing us to respond to the opportunities based on weather and light conditions so you can have the best photo experiences each day. We will start each day early so as to capture images in the the best possible light. We will grab a coffee and quick breakfast en-route, on the go. We photograph throughout the morning, breaking for at mid-morning for an image review, lunch and instruction sessions.

In the late afternoon, we will head out for more photography, concluding after sunset. Dinner will be at a location of your choosing. We will then meet to do image downloads and for a feedback session. Open discussion session will be included as well as a prep session for the next day. Whenever possible, we will attempt some night photography and light painting sessions.

Day 1: October 23rd, 2015:

Check-in to the hotel at 3:00 p.m. We will meet at the Easton Windmill Meeting room at 4:00 p.m. for a quick meet and greet as well as an orientation and a short instructional session in preparation for the next day's activities. We will then go out for a Sunset and blue hour shoot in the Chatham area.

Day 2: October 24th, 2015:

We will venture out before sunrise into the dunes to get some early morning light and our first exercise. We will grab breakfast, on the go, and continue photographing in the vicinity to complete the first exercise. We will return to our hotel for a review session and after lunch we will have an instructional session. Late in the day, we will photograph additional scenes on the cape. We will capture a sunset and break for dinner. After dinner, we will download our images and do an image critique. Instruction on how to enhance your images will be provided.

Day 3: October 25th, 2015:

A sunrise shoot is scheduled at beaches and at a lighthouse. We will have breakfast and spend the day concentrating on HDR photography at an abandoned farm village. After lunch, we will have an instructional session and image download as well as a critique. Sunset photography will be in a working fishing village/harbor. Dinner and an image review will conclude our day.

Day 4: October 26th, 2015

Once again, we will do a sunrise photo shoot and have breakfast on the fly. We will then travel to Province Town photographing on the PT dunes. We'll then do a local street and architectural shoot. We'll have lunch in P Town. After lunch, we will spend some more time in the harbor and, if possible, we'll go to the Race Point Light. Based on the weather, we will do sunset in P Town or travel to Truro to photograph the infamous rows of beach cottages. Post dinner, we will do an image review.

Day 5: October 27th, 2015

We will leave early in the morning before sunrise and have breakfast on the road. We'll get back to the hotel in time to check out. Once again, the morning will be spent photographing various scenics. We will break for lunch after which our workshop will officially conclude. However, participants are welcome to stay through sunset.

Registration is through AIP. Lodging is based on double occupancy. Your hotel room and workshop instruction is included in the price of the workshop. Travel to and from the Cape, insurance, meals and incidentals are not included.

We will try to arrange for car pooling from the New York/New Jersey area to the Cape.

Accommodations and Travel:

We will be staying in the Four Points Sheraton in Eastham, MA. The Hotel is located at 3800 Route 6 in Eastham. Massachusetts.

The hotel has an indoor pool, color TV with cable and free WiFI.

Our tour leader and instructor, Shiv Verma:

Shiv Verma, APSA, MNEC is a published author, photographer, educator and
technologist. He has been photographing for over 50 years and has evolved his photography to express his intense devotion to wildlife and nature. Over the years has earned numerous awards and recognition both nationally and
internationally. Shiv devotes a great deal of his time formally reviewing
photography related products, to education in digital photography and is a
speaker and competition judge. He conducts photo tours and workshops
worldwide and typically has one tour a month.?

Shiv’s book Time-Lapse Imagery was published in February 2014. He has been writing for one of the worlds largest photography education sites “Digital Photography School” with about 1.5 million subscribers.  He is also a co-host on TWiP (This Week in Photography) a weekly photography podcast that is the 7th largest in the world.?

He belongs to multiple photographic clubs and associations and serves as Vice President of the Digital Circuit NECCC (New England Camera Club Council) and General Chairman of the PSA International (Photographic Society of America).

Shiv is a past President of the Stony Brook Camera Club; and the Gateway
Camera Club, a member of the Greater Lynn Photographic Association,
Massachusetts Camera Naturalists, all in Massachusetts?

_______________________________________________________________

The price of $695.00 per person includes your hotel room for 4 nights and the workshop. It doesn't include any meals or anything not expressly included.

The price of a single supplement is $275.00
results.name: Cape Cod - A Fall Workshop: Led by Shiv Verma

We'll have drums to share, and support for newcomers, and energy for everyone.

Recent accolades!

“Great fun! Good rhythms. Very accommodating leader and group for this beginner. Will be back!”

Adrienne S 10/14

It was an amazing experience .. It was nice to feel free from the world and it's problems .. It's was so relaxing, can't wait to drum again ..thanks!

Justin 6/14

Was an awesome experience, I love hand drumming but really the main reason I came was to relieve stress due to family health situations and the circle definitely met my needs. Alan did a great job leading the circle with the drumming and the short history lessons about drumming and Africa. I will be coming back.

Paul 10/13

This Drum Circle is a great stress reliever after a long week of work and I wish it were every Friday night!! Boston Drum Cirlce attracts a wonderful , eclectic group of people that share the common bond of hand drumming. It is always wonderful to have the multi talented Fanta leading the Circle. Her singing, dancing, and drumming are all 5 star. Thank you for a great night of Drumming!

Carla 8/13

We can't wait to meet you! See you soon....

Alan and Fanta

results.description:
This will be a three-stop meetup, first stop being the Verrazano Narrows bridge, a very picturesque structure and we will explore it from both east side (meeting point) and west side, where we will also find Ft Wadsworth. The fort is likely closed at night, but perhaps we can find a good vantage point to include it.


From there, we will go north and stop to explore some huge piling fields left over from rather large wooden docks near St George and finally end up at the ferry terminal, which has a very modern structure and also a good view on Manhattan from a different angle than we usually get it.


The sun sets at 6 pm, moon will be 70% full, low tide will be at 11 pm. Car pooling will be practical.


Bring a variety of lenses, super wide will work well under the bridge, but you will need a decent zoom / long lens to capture Manhattan from St George.


Some inspiration below, taken from Flickr and Google maps.


Bridge from the east side and there will be a couple of vantage points that includes the perpendicular roads:


From the west side, including Ft Wadsworth:


The pilings:



Observation platform at the ferry terminal, modern structure on right, Manhattan on left. There is a public parking lot we can park in or walk to that gets us very close to that structure.
results.name: New York City 2: Verrazano Narrows Bridge & St George

DELICIOUS DINNER

(and Take-Out)

Prepared by

DAVID SNIECKUS

- MACROBIOTIC CHEF AND COUNSELOR -

At 7 p.m.

at David’s, Margaret’s and Abigail's home in Newton, MA

October 23, 2015 Menu

Carrot and Ginger Miso Soup

Pressure-Cooked Brown Rice 


Barbeque Tofu 

Baked Squash

Vegetable Medley

Colorful Harvest Salad

Pears with Tofu Cream Sauce

Kukicha Tea

(see detailed logistics below.)

**************************

Followed by a presentation from 8 to 10 pm on

 Brahma Vihara - Karuna (Compassion)

with Whispering Deer

Compassion is the capacity of the awakened heart to remain open in the presence of pain and suffering - our own and that of all beings. It is the movement (quivering) of the heart that wants to alleviate suffering. Can we let ourselves feel our own as well as another’s pain without getting pulled into sorrow, self-righteousness, anger, or become gripped in the hold of despair or grief? Compassion is the opening of consciousness to human life and the ability to stay close in the face of suffering without fear without aversion. Come and join us in learning how to live in a free and open-hearted way.

Donation welcome.

About Whispering Deer

Meditation is my primary spiritual practice. Each year, I spend 8 weeks in silence, working with various meditation techniques, accessing deep states of consciousness and expanded awareness. This work has led me to experience the transformative power of the awakened heart, resulting in the development of the Brahma Vihara workshops. The benefits I have received are innumerable and immeasurable. Nothing would please me more than to share what I have learned with others.

For more information, go to: https://sites.google.com/site/whisperingdeermeditation/

Upcoming Brahma Vihara workshops with Whispering Deer:

November 13, 2015: Brahma Vihara - Mudita (Appreciative Joy)

November 20, 2015: Brahma Vihara - Upeka (Equanimity)

**************************

Most ingredients are organic and of the highest standards.

Come be in community and enjoy a healthy meal!

Call (617)[masked] or e-mail [masked]
for reservations and directions.

Please rsvp no later than noon on Friday.

Sliding scale of $20 - $35/meal.

(Note: Preferred payment is by cash or check.)
(Let David know if interested in helping him cook in exchange for a free meal. Prerequisite: One of David's cooking classes, unless experienced.)

(Please contact us if you'd like to lead a discussion opener based upon a topic of your choice.)

Feel free to pass on to other friends and kindred spirits!

THIS MEETUP IS NOT CANCELLED!!!

IT'S STILL ON!!!


Time for our Annual Fabulous Fur Ball!

This is our major fundraiser for the year, to be held on Friday, October 23, 2015 at the Italian Community Center (ICC), 302 Rantoul Street, Beverly, from 7-11 PM. The very popular band Ray Novack and Horizon will provide live music. There will be dancing, good food, and lots of great raffle items. All animal lovers are asked to come and support FOBA’s rescue and adoption efforts. Besides saving animals in and around Beverly, FOBA’s mission is also to establish a no-kill shelter in Beverly.
Tickets are $25/person, cash bar.  Music, food , raffle items, dancing, and more.

Contact Bonnie Hannable [masked],[masked] or Heidi
Roberts at [masked],[masked] for tickets and further information. Please support this most worthy cause!

http://www.friendsofbeverlyanimals.org/about/

Friends of Beverly Animals (or FOBA) is an all-volunteer Section 501(c)(3) charitable organization dedicated to the care of homeless animals in and around Beverly, Massachusetts.  FOBA’s mission is to better the lives of homeless animals through: Assisting with the feeding of homeless animals
Assisting with the cost of medical care for homeless animals
Creating a network of foster and permanent homes for homeless animals
Long-term planning for the establishment of an animal shelter in and around
Beverly. FOBA also plans to develop educational activities designed to raise community awareness of the plight of homeless animals, to increase public sensitivity to homeless animals and to reduce the frequency of animal abandonment.

results.description:
Each and every Friday, we're proud to open the doors of our music school in Central Square for a FREE seminar, demo or meet-up. Hell, we'll even throw a classical music concert or two. What's in store this week? Let's find out: 

Mixxx is a popular live music creation tool for DJs, similar to Traktor or Serato Scratch Live, but it's totally free and open source. The Mixxx developers just released a beta version representing two years of work adding advanced features like 4-deck master sync, built-in effects, and musical key matching. Come and watch one of the lead developers reveal what's new and what you may not have known Mixxx could do. 

Owen Williams consistently fails at not writing code all the time. During the week he works on software that helps people find plane tickets and on the weekends you'll find him in a coffee shop working on side projects. He has been a developer with Mixxx since 2009 and is one of the lead developers on the project. Occasionally he DJs house parties while sweating a river, worried that Mixxx might crash at any moment even though that only happened once. He would like to learn how to repair pinball machines next.
results.name: Behind the Free DJ Software of Mixxx [10/23] #FREE

results.description:
As photographers we constantly strive for better images, but time and time again we fall short. Yes, we improve over time but it often seems like it is taking forever. A new camera, a new lens, or new post processing software can all give us a burst of inspiration, but that rarely lasts very long and we are once again dissatisfied with our results.   While this is all part of the natural order of things, there is plenty we can do to improve our results and make our images much stronger.

This workshop series of six classes will take you on an adventure, pushing you to try out new techniques and learn new skills that will have you thinking and shooting with greater intent.

Comprising a well balanced mix of instruction, information and practical hands-on shooting spread over a number of weeks this series of classes will ensure that you spend the winter developing your ability to create strong images that directly communicate your intent to the viewer.

Learn how to lead your viewer's eye around the image.

Learn  techniques to help you more effectively envision your shot before you press the shutter.

 Understand what to include and what to exclude  to create a strong impression of depth in your image. 

Learn techniques to make  the 3D world in front of you appear more realistic in your 2D image.

Understand how color, light, tone and focus can be combined to convey mood.  

Classes will be[masked]pm on Fridays   (October 23, Nov 24 , Jan 8)

                          10am -5pm Sundays ( Nov 8, Dec 6,  Jan 24

The Friday evenings will be in the Pembroke Studio and the Sunday full day classes will be in the studio and occasionally outdoors (weather permitting).

The group size is limited to just 8 and the cost for the complete series is: $550
results.name: Making Stronger Photographs - A six class winter workshop Series

results.description:
Boston Book Festival <~ (note hyperlink)


Event link HERE. Full Schedule HERE. Ticketed events HERE.  

Distinguished speakers for BFF-2015 begin with Margaret Atwood's kickoff keynote on Friday, October 23. 

On Saturday, October 24, the lineup includes Libba Bray, Atul Gawande, Colum McCann, Amanda Palmer, Louis Sachar, and James Wood. Tickets for Margaret Atwood and Amanda Palmer's events are on sale now; all other keynote events (and everything else at BBF 2015!) are free of charge. Want front row seats to all the keynotes? Become a member at the Playwright level or above. 

:: :: ::

Distinguished speakers

• Libba Bray is the New York Times–bestselling author of young adult novels such as The Gemma Doyle trilogy and Beauty Queens. Her novel Going Bovine won the Michael L. Printz Award in 2010. Bray’s latest work is Lair of Dreams, the second installation in the Diviners series. - SATURDAY, OCTOBER 24 - COPLEY SQUARE

• Atul Gawande is a public health researcher and a general and endocrine surgeon at Brigham and Women’s Hospital. He is also a professor in both the Department of Health Policy and Management at the Harvard School of Public Health and the Department of Surgery at Harvard Medical School, as well as a staff writer for the New Yorker. Gawande’s most recent book is Being Mortal, which examines the limitations of medicine in end-of-life care. - SATURDAY, OCTOBER 24 - COPLEY SQUARE

•  Colum McCann won the 2009 National Book Award for his novel Let the Great World Spin. McCann’s stories have appeared in the New Yorker, Esquire, Paris Review, Granta, Atlantic Monthly, and elsewhere. His most recent work, Thirteen Ways of Looking, marks his first collection of short fiction in more than a decade. -SATURDAY, OCTOBER 24 - COPLEY SQUARE

• Amanda Palmer is a performance artist, singer, songwriter, and pianist best known for her work with the Dresden Dolls and Evelyn Evelyn. Her first book, the New York Times bestseller The Art of Asking, expands on a TED talk she gave in 2013. - 5:30PM SATURDAY, OCTOBER 24 - OLD SOUTH SANCTUARY, 645 BOYLSTON STREET

• Louis Sachar is the Newbury Medal–winning author of Holes, which was also awarded the National Book Award for Young People’s Literature and was adapted into a 2003 film. Sachar’s most recent novel, Fuzzy Mud, is an environmental cautionary tale that blends suspense and humor. - SATURDAY, OCTOBER 24 - COPLEY SQUARE

• Moshe Safdie is an architect, urban planner, educator, theorist, and author. His works include Habitat 67 in Montreal and the Marina Bay Sands complex in Singapore. In 2015, Safdie was awarded the Gold Medal by the American Institute of Architects. - SATURDAY, OCTOBER 24 - COPLEY SQUARE

• James Wood is a professor of literary criticism at Harvard and a staff writer and book critic for the New Yorker. A 2009 winner of the National Magazine Award for reviews and criticism, he is also the author of the novel The Book Against God and a study of literary technique, How Fiction Works. His latest book is The Nearest Thing to Life. - SATURDAY, OCTOBER 24 - COPLEY SQUARE
results.name: Boston Book Festival (2-days)

results.description:
READ THIS:  The Oct 23rd Puja is SOLD OUT.  Please revisit our Meetup group soon and RSVP for the November Intimate Puja Circle! 

_____________________________________________

A Puja, in sanskrit, means reverence, honor, worship and adoration.  It's used by the Hindus, Sikhs, Buddhists, and others -- as a ceremony to honor a very special occasion; it's also used more often as part of a sacred ritual/practice to support opening to the wisdom of the Divine -- your Source.

_________________________________________

Here's what we are going to do:

_________________________________________

Intimate Puja Circles, created by Robyn Vogel, Come Back to Love Coach, is the place to:

• Be playful with other yummy, juicy, soulful singles, and couples

• Learn and practice Tantra, yoga, meditation, et al....

• Be in a room with folks who are willing to be honest, and open their hearts

• Experience deep connections with those interested in sacred sexuality, expanded orgasm, conscious relationship, spirituality  - people like YOU!

Tantric Intimacy (whether you are single or in relationship):

This special evening will begin with many invitations to connect with each other in light and playful ways -- always with the opportunity to go as deep as you choose.  Single or coupled, you'll experience Tantric Intimacy exercises as a way to say 'hello', get to know one another, mingle and connect. 

Here's what participants are saying!

"Thank you so much, Robyn!  I'm learning so much about myself through these Pujas and because of them would never have met my PARTNER!  Woo hoo!"

"The class was great; I  really enjoyed it. Very different from my normal way of life, you did create on a small scale what I was hoping for....creating the possibility to feel a deeper intimacy."

"It's so amazing to walk into a room of "strangers" and walk out feeling in love with everyone!"

"I didn't think I'd be able to connect with anyone there.  I was so surprised, and delighted, how easy it was to enjoy myself with every man in that room! Thank you Robyn, for your excellent facilitation skills. I felt totally safe!"

"We have to wait a whole month until the next one????"

"This is a very special event; a non-threatening, yet deep and authentic way to meet others. I've been online dating for years and it's just not for me.  I've met some really good people at your events."

"We love to come as a couple and meet others on a similar path."

"....and to think, they are happening RIGHT HERE in Boston!!


The Intimate Puja Circle itself will begin part-way through the night during which you'll have the chance to connect more deeply with others (one-on-one) -- this part of the evening will be facilitated, with a structure offered, however, you will have ample time to co-create with the beloved in front of you!!  You will be at choice and encouraged to ask for 100% of what you want.


Relax on a Friday night:

Once the formal part of the evening is over, there'll be time to dance, hang out, cuddle, snuggle, relax, process, and rest.  There will always be chocolate!


Q&A

1.  What if I'm in relationship? Being in relationship definitely does not exclude you from coming to the Intimate Puja Circle. These rituals will be invitations to connect with yourself and one another - and you will be at choice as to how you do that.  There are typically a mix of singles and couples at the events.

2.  What should I wear? Please be comfortable but also celebratory!  Wear yoga pants or something with a draw string around the waist; bring sarongs, scarves, dresses, etc.

3.  Do I need to bring anything? Yes, FRIENDS!!  And your water bottle.  You are also welcome healthy snacks to share after the Puja.  Organic fruit and chocolate are best.

4.  What if I have questions, I'm feeling a bit nervous: Please email me to set up a time to talk:  [masked]

Please note RSVPing on this Meetup site will not reserve you a space. The Intimate Puja Circles are limited in size so please pay in advance to reserve your space (and SAVE MONEY.)

**  Coming to an Intimate Puja Circle enables you to participate in our secret FB group as well as receive a special VIP invitation to the upcoming Intimate Puja Weekend Retreat DECEMBER 11-13.**
results.name: SOLD OUT Intimate Puja Circle

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

Dance with us from 7:45 pm -Midnight at The First Parish Cambridge Unitarian Universalist Church at 3 Church St., Cambridge, MA.


The fabulous, fun-filled event begins with a class from 7:45 to 9:15 and continues with dj'd dancing By Euphoria until midnight 

Class October 23: Margaux Medicine Dancer–Roth 5 Rhythms®The Gabrielle Roth 5 Rhythms® of movement® is a practice of awakening that invites us to be curious to the waves of energies that travel through all things.As we surrender into our own movement, the inspiring, self healing, meditative, spiritual and relationship focused practice invites us to just show up.Flowing: Earth bound and Curious

Staccato: Fire and Clarity
Chaos:Water and a Cacophony
Lyrical : Air and ConfettiStillness: Oneness and Completely

Your spirited activist and facilitator, Margaux Skalecki is a certified 2001 seasoned teacher and a humble keeper of the Roth 5 Rhythms since 1996. BFA in Dance Boston Conservatory and MA in Personal and Global Transformation through Education of Healing and Performing Arts. She holds certifications in Yoga for adults and children, ERYT 500 hour, Healing Reiki, Shamanism, Animal Communication and is a practicing Spirit Medium. She is the director of Being Seen Being Heard playful and profound possibilities of performance. Among many fabulous places, Margaux has shared her work and teachings at The Boston Conservatory, Berklee School of Music, The Dance Complex, Green Street Studios, La Mama, 42nd Street Theater, Merce Cunningham Studios, Omega Institute, Kripalu, Rowe Conference Center, Daughters of the Earth, Dance New England, and many other wonderful schools and studios. She travels nationally and internationally.

https://lh5.googleusercontent.com/Xw6DFxKoolieXFLOinZsT3cxjDSvJHlwp5nFwK_APFfkQoxOd9AH0axDeuBoL5bC8ugG_nihzmSRb8l4mKks6bz8sv0KoZCOYs7QNaKx0lT2zPKYkKbYyAu8uPvOLZx3ZA=s1600

"Euphoria" 9:30-midnight

DJ Tara~Ma: Founder and facilitator of Ecstatic Dance Providence for the last 5 years, Tara~Ma brings flowing, fluid heart centered grooves with a beat to raise your vibration while you align your body, spirit and mind. Get down to deep house, pray in the temples of Kirtronica and shimmy to a wide range of global rhythms. Tara~Ma debuted her DJing outside of the Ecstatic Dance realm at DNE Dance Camp. She is a regular guest DJ and contributor to the bimonthly conscious dance event "Nectar" held at the Dance Complex in Cambridge, MA. Find out more and hear her live recorded sets at:

https://soundcloud.com/tara-ma

DJ Bio: DJ Mantra: From humble vinyl beginnings to the newest technology, he has been in the mix spinning a wide variety of music from dance, rock, trance to top 40 and more, but world music, spiritual grooves and sacred music have spoken to him and have drawn him along his path. DJ Mantra Ji has spun global grooves from the local Boston area to the West Coast and back. Spinning tracks at different venues throughout the country.

Dancers of all ages and abilities are invited to dance barefoot, any way you like, with or without a partner, in a smoke and alcohol free environment. Children are welcome.

Dance Friday is an activity of the non-profit Movement Collective. Suggested Donation: $15 8pm-9:15, $10-15 after 9:30, $5-10 after 11,  under  23 years old $5-15, or donate 45 minutes of your time to help out.  We recommend casual, light-weight, comfortable clothing that you can  move in.

For more information, please call: 6I[masked], go to <a>www.dancefriday.org,</a> or visit us on Facebook at http://www.facebook.com/#/pages/Dance-Friday/[masked]?ref=ts

This months workshop will focus on recognizing our masks/archetypes that get in the way of us accessing our authentic selves.  We will explore the dynamic work of Carolyn Myss (Sacred Contracts) and through guided meditation, peel back the masks and let go of the committee members that govern us to reveal our true nature.

We will then communicate with the divine, angels, spirit and those who we love (only the highest and best influences through intention) and learn how to open our intuitive and deeper knowing to the world of spirit.

The cost of this workshop is $35 and you must pre-register at www.judygio.com

meta.description: Searches for recent and upcoming public events hosted by Meetup groups. Its search window  is the past one month through the next three months, and is subject to change. Open Events is optimized to search for current events by location, category, topic, or text, and only lists Meetups that have **3 or more RSVPs**. The number or results returned with each request is not guaranteed to be the same as the page size due to secondary filtering. If you're looking for a particular event or events within a particular group, use the standard [Events](/meetup_api/docs/2/events/) method.
meta.title: Meetup Open Events v2
